0.1: "Sire dere Darius on dese · þe digne Emperoure, Þe kyng without comparrison · of kyngis all othire, Of all lordis þe lord · þat leues in erthe, Predicessour of princes · & peree Read pere. to þe sonn, Þe souerayne sire of my soyle · þat sittis in my trone, In fang with my faire godis · þat I affie maste, To Alexander, þat of all · so augrily him letes, Oure subiet & oure seruand · þus we oure-selfe write. For it is wayued vs to wete · þat wickidly þou haues, Þur&yogh;e enmyte & enuy · elacion of pride, Be vanyte & vayne glori · þat in þi wayns kindlis, Puruayd þe pletours · oure partis to ride. For þou has samed, as men he Inserted in the margin: better omitted . sais · a selly nounbre Of wrichis & wirlingis · out of þe west endis, Of laddis & of losengers · & of litill theuys, Slike sary soro&yogh;is as þi-selfe · to seke vs agaynes, And wenes to wild all þi will · & þat worthis ful late, Þe prouynce & principalte · of Persye la graunt. For þou ert fere al to faynt · oure force to ministere; Þof þou had gedird all þe gomes · þat euire god fourmed, So, man, riued is oure rewme · þat þou may re&yogh;t lycken Þe store strenthe of oure stoure · to sternes of þe heuen. And slike a nekard as þi-selfe · a no&yogh;t of all othire, Is bot a madding to mell · with mare þan him-seluen. Forthi is bettir vnbynd · & of þe brathe leue, And feyne all with fairnes · & fayne at þou may. For mare menseke So; for menske. is a man · to meke him be tyme, Þan eftir made to be meke · malegreue his chekis. For all þe gracious godis · & gudnes on erthe, Þat sanys sete & soile · & sustaynes þe erth, Prayses ay þe Persyns · passing all othire, And for þe oddiste of ilka ost · honoures oure name. And slike a dwinyng, MS. dwinnyg. a dwa&yogh;e · & a dwer&yogh;e as þi-selfe, A grub, a grege out of grace · ane erd-growyn sorowe, Will couet &yogh;it as a king · with caytefes to lyte, To couir at combrid all þe kyngis · vndire þe cape of heuen! Ri&yogh;t as a flaw of fell snawe · ware fallyn of a ryft, Of a wysti wonn waghe · with þe wynd blawen, So with a flote of Fresons · folowand þi helis, Þou sekis fraward Sichim · þi-selfe wrothir-haile, And leuys as a lorell · þus oure lande to entire, And maa þi lepis & þi laikis · & quat þe liste ellis, As ratons or ru&yogh;e myse · in a rowme chambre, Aboute in beddis or in bernys · þare baddis ere nane. Bot I haue wilily waited · þi wiles & þi castis, And quen þou hopis all-þir hiest · to haue all þar will, I sall þe sett on a saute · & sla þe [with] my handis. . . . . . For-þi for pompe or for pride · þi purpose a-vise, . . . . . Turne þe, trechoure, be-time · þat þou na treson haue, And drawe a-gayn to þi den · vndire þi dam wyngis. Se quat I send to þe, MS. þi, altered to þe. son · þi-selfe with to laike, A hatt & a hand-ball · & a herne-panne; Slike presandis to play with · as pertines to babbis. For ai a child mot him chese · to childire geris; For mestire & miserie · vnneth may þou forthe Þine awen caitefe cors · to clethe & to fede, And supposis as a sott · to sese oure landis, And outhire darius to drepe · or dryfe fra his kythis! Bot by þe grace & þe gude · þat god gaue my fadire, So riued is þe rede gold · oure regions with-in, Þat qua sa had it on a hepe · haly to-gedire, It wald vs let, as I leue · þe li&yogh;t of þe son! For-þi bid I þe badrich · on bathe twa þine e&yogh;en, And on þe plegg & þe payn · & perill as folowis, All þi vanyte to voide · & þi vayne pride, And mew agayn to Messedone · or any mare fall. For be þe saule of my sire · bot if þou sone turne, We sall þe send sike a soume · of segis en-armed, No&yogh;t as Philips fant · salle fare with þi-selfe, Bot as a prince of proued theues · pyne þe to dede." Als sone as his sandismen · to þis sire come, Þai present him þe playntis · þe pistill him rechis, And Alexander belyue · be-fore all his princes, To all his ost euyn on · he openly declaris. And quen his kni&yogh;tis of þis clause · þe carpe vndirstode, Þen ware þai frekly a-frayd · of þe fell sa&yogh;es; And as sone MS. inserts him s; but it is struck out . as him-selfe sa&yogh;e · his seggis amoued, In bilding of his bachelers · he breuys þire wordis: "Quat now? my worthi werriouris · sa wi&yogh;t & sa noble, Mi bernes & my baratours · þe best vndire heuen; Lettis neuire it bro&yogh;t be on brade · for vpbraide of schame, &YOGH;e doute for þe indityngs · of Darius pistils. I sett &yogh;owe ane ensample · &yogh;e se it all daye, In thorps & in many thede · þar &yogh;e þur&yogh;e ride, At ilka cote a kene curre · as he þe chache wald; Bot as bremely as he baies The e is above the line . · he bitis neuir þe fastir. Bot in sum, I suppose wele · þat sothe is þe lettir, Þare as he tellis quyche a tunne · of tresoure he hauys. For-þi vs buse to be bigg · & bataill him &yogh;eld, Þe grete garisons of gold · sall gedire vp oure hertis." With þat comands þe kyng · his kny&yogh;tis be-lyue, Þe donesmen þat fra Darius come · with þe derfe lettir, Þat þai suld titly þam take · & by þe to&yogh;e throtis, And for þaire souerayne sake · þam send to þe galawis. Þan was þa messangers a-maied · as mervale ware ellis, With kene carefull crie · þis conquirour þai said: "Allas! quat lake lyse in vs lord · if it be &yogh;oure will, Þus causeles for oure kynge · encumbird to worthe?" "The sa&yogh;es of &yogh;our souerayn" · said þe kynge þen, "Nedis me to slike notis · as I had neuer etlid, Þat has &yogh;ow sent to my-selfe · no&yogh;t sa as him a&yogh;e; Loo 'litill thefe' in ilka lyne · his lettir me callis." "&YOGH;a," quod þai, "comly kyng" · & on knes MS. keies, altered to knes. fallis, "Þase ditis endited to &yogh;owe · sir Darius him-seluyn, For he knew no&yogh;t of &yogh;our kni&yogh;thede · ne of &yogh;our kid strenth; Ne wist no&yogh;t of &yogh;our worthenes · & wrate all þe baldire. Bot wald &yogh;e grant vs to gaa · & gefe vs &yogh;our lefe, Þen suld we bremely &yogh;our bill · to þe berne shewe." Þen lete þe lord þam allane · & went till his fest, Takis þam with him to his tent · & þam at ese makis. Sone as þai in his sale · were sett at þe table, "Sire Alexander, athill kyng" · quod all with a steuyn, "Comands with vs to caire · kni&yogh;tis a thousand, And we sall surely oure sire · þe send in þaire handis." "&YOGH;a, make we blis," quod þe kyng · "blithe mote &yogh;e worthe, For as for takynge of &yogh;our lord · sall na lede wynde." To Darius anoþir day · enditis he a pistill, A crest clenly inclosid · þat consayued þis wordis. Alexander, þe aire · & eldest childe bathe Of kyng Philip þe fers · þe fendere of grece, And als of Olimpades · þat honurable lady, To þe, Darius, on dese · þus dite I my lettir. Þou prince of all þe Persyns · þat peres to þe sonne, Þe conquirour of ilka cost · callid of þi-selfe, With all þi gracious godis · graithid in þi trone, All þus I send to &yogh;owe I my written above the line in MS. sawe · vndir my sele wreten. Sire, if we se with a suth · surely me thinke, Oure facultes, oure faire fees · oure fermes & our landis, We may no&yogh;t chalang þam ne clayme · ne call þaim oure awen, Bot all I deme it as det · & to a day borowid. For sen we riden on þe rime · & on þe ringe seten Of þe qwele of Fortoun, þe quene · þat swiftly changis, Ofte pas we in pouert · fra plente of gudis, Fra mirthe in-to mournyng · fra mournyng in-to Ioye. For now vs wantis in a qwirre · as þe quele turnes; Quen we suppose in oure sele · to sit alþir heist, Þan fondis furth dame Fortoun · to þe flode-&yogh;atis, Dra&yogh;es vp þe damme-borde · & drenchis vs euire. For-þi a we þat has wit · þofe he wele suffir, So sadly in soueraynete · he set neuire his hope For pride of na pro[s]perite · ne prise at him folewis, To olle ay on his vndireling · for ouer-laike a quyle. For any sele vndire son · a sott I him hald, Þat ay has deyne & dispite · at dedis of litill, Sen oft þe hauenlest here · is houen to þe sternes, And he þat graithist is of gudis · gird all to poudire. For-þi a depe dishonoure · &yogh;e do to &yogh;oure name, Ane emperoure þat on erth · is euyn to &yogh;oure-selfe, To me sa litill & sa lawe · slike lettirs to sende, And presand out of Persy · bot for a pure hethyng. For þou enherestis all þis erth · & euens to þe son, And callis þe kyng of ilka kithe · vndir þe cape of heuen, And þarto sittis, as þou sais · in sege as ane Aungell, To-gedire with þi grete MS. repeats with grete. gods · and on a gilt trone. Bot syn gostid godesses & gods · ere graythid neuir to dye, Bot ai sall last furth elike · on-lyue ouire Read euire. mare, Þai naue no will to my notis · ne wilnyng to haue, No dole ne no daliance · of dedely bernes. Bot I knaw I am coruptible · & caire &yogh;ow agaynes, Als with a dedly duke · to do my bataill; Bot þof MS. Bot þou þof; but þou is underlined . þou þe victor a-vaile · na vaunte sall arise, Ne lose, bot as a litill thefe · &yogh;ow limpid to encumbre. Bot chance it me, þat am a childe · þe cheuer to worthe, So þat be geuyn me þe gree · grete glorie is myn awen. For þan sall spring vp þe speche · & sprede out Inserted in the margin . of mynd, How I haue conquired a kyng · þe kidest of þe werd. Bot a tale &yogh;e me tald · I trow be na faile, Of þe ryfenes of þe rede gold · &yogh;our region with-in, Quilke plente is in Persy · of perell & of ellis, Þe somme of siluer & of siche · & of sere stanes, Þare-with oure wittes has þou wele · & oure will sharpid, And blid with þi besands · þe bataille to &yogh;eld, Made vs corageous & kene · &yogh;oure clere gold to wyn, And put a-way oure pouert · &yogh;e plede vs to hald. Bot as touchand þe trufils · þat &yogh;e to me sent, Þe herne-pan, þe hand-ball · þe hatt made of twiggis, Þare has þou prophesid apert · & playnely vs schewid, And faire affirmed vs before · þat sall fall eftir. For by þe ball, sir, I breue · all þe brode werd, Þe erthe at to myne enpire · enterely bees &yogh;olden. And be þe hat, þat is holewe · be-for þe heued bowed, I constru þat ilka kyng · sall clyne to my-selfe. Þan hope I by þe hernepan · þat þe hede couirs, Ouir-comers Read Ouir-comer. to be callid · & ouire-comen neuire. Now þou, þe grettest vndir god · graithis me trouage, With all þis dignites be-dene · þat I diuined haue." Þis brefe bedis þaim him bere · & besands þam rechis; And eftir armes all his ost · & airis on eftir forthire. Sire Darius for þe ditis · nere died he for angire, To twa of þe derrest of his dukis · ditis he þis pistill: "I, þe corounnest kyng · of kyngis all othire, To þe, sir primus, a prince · of Persye þe grettest, And als to ser Antagoyne · myn awen athill dukis, Þe soueraynest of my seniourie · my saroparis Read satroparis; see l. 1937. hatten, Se here I send &yogh;ow my seele · with salutis of ioye. Fra Alexander þe kyng · as I am in-fourmed, Is entrid with oure enmys · an endles nounbre, Þe Anglies of Asie · & has þam all stroyed, For-þi of life & o lym · my lege men I charge To prestli &yogh;ow apparaill · & pas þam agaynes, With all þe hathils & þe heris · & þe hi&yogh;e maistris Þat &yogh;e may semble in þe sidis · saudiours & othire. Þen chese &yogh;ow furth my chiftanes · & me þe child take, Laches me þis losengere · & ledis me him hedire, Þat I may him skelp with a skorge · & þen MS. þen þe; but þe is struck out . of Inserted in the margin . skire porpure A side slauyn him sewe · & send him to his modire; For now he proches for pride · & propurly he wedis, For-þi him bose to be bett · as a barne fallis. For it Written above the line in MS. a&yogh;e no&yogh;t slik ane Asald · nane abletus to off werres, Bot at þe bowlis as a brode · or with a ball playe." Þire princes, sone as þe pistill · was put þam in hand, Þan part þai þe proud sele · þe printe þai adhoured, Vn-lappis li&yogh;tly þe lefe · & þe line redes, And þus-gate agynward · þai graithid him anothire. "To þe kiddest kyng to a-count · of kyngis all othire, Sire Dari, with þi dere godis · drised on þi trone, Gouernoure of ilk a gome · & god all þi-selfe, Þi satrapairs, þi seniours · with seruage obeschen: Sire, wetis it wele, &yogh;oure worthines · & wenys it na langire, Þat þis child, with his chiftans · þat &yogh;e charge vs to take, Has reden all oure regions · & raymed oure landis, Departid all oure prouynce · & purely it wastid. And we þan lift vp a lite · & lent him a-gayne, Ferd furth with a flote · & him in þe fyld metis; Bot sone we bed him þe bake · & besely MS. & hi besely. we shapid Out of þe handis vn-hewyn · of oure hatill Read hathill. fais. And now haly all þe hepe · at &yogh;e Inserted in the margin. &yogh;oure help callis, Vn-to &yogh;oure mekill maieste · we mekely beseke, Þat vs &yogh;our lege & &yogh;oure lele men · it likid &yogh;ow to forthire, Or þan oure wirschip at-wynde · & wastid be þe regme." As radly as þe riche kyng · had red ouir þis pistill, Be þat mevis in A Inserted in the margin. Messangere · & maynly him tellis, Þat Alexander was at hand · & had his ost loygid A-pon þe streme of Struma The u is above the line. · þat strekis þur&yogh;e his landis. Sire Darius for þa ditis · was depely a-greuyd, Callis him his consail · a clause he him enditis, Mas a brefe at a braide · & it in brathe sendis, To Alexander as be-lyue · & all þus him gretes. ¶ "I, sir Dari, þe deyne · & derfe Emperoure, Þe kyng of kyngis I am callid · & conquirour bathe, Of all lordis þe lord · a-lose Read alosed. þur&yogh;e þe werd, And ane of þe souerayne sires · vndir þe vij sternes, To þe, my seruand, I send · & suthely þou knawes, And wete þou wele þur&yogh;e all þe werde · is wirschip oure name. MS. namo. For all þe gracious gods · at þe ground visitis, All ere done me to doute · ducsses So ( or ducsses) in MS. & othire. How burde þe þan be sa bald · for blod in þi heued, To moue þus ouir þe mountey[n]s · & ouir þe many watirs With slike a soumme ouir þe see · a saute vs to &yogh;eld, Or any maistrie to make · my maieste a-gayne? For wella Inserted in the margin. wide ware þe wele · wete þou na nothire, Bathe þi glorie & þi grace · þi gladnes in erthe, Mi&yogh;t þou þe marches of Messedoyne · mayntene þi-selfe, And gouerne bot þine awen gronde · agaynes oure Inserted in the margin. will. For-þi ware bettir vnbynde · or þou bale suffire, Remowe agayne to þi rewme · & rew of þi werkis. For certayne, nyf my seniourie · ne I my-selfe nouthire, All þe werd my&yogh;t a wedowe · wele þan be callid. For-þi turne þe be-time · or any tene worthe, Or at þe hate of my hert · a-pon þi hede kindill. Lend agayn to þi lande · nowe quen þou leue hauys, Þat I mete þe in my malicoly · my meth be to littill. For-þi to ken þe to knaw · my kyndnes here-eftir, Bath my grace & my glori · & my grete strenthe, Loo here a gloue full of graynes · I graythe þe to take, Of þe chesses of a chesboll · chosen for þe nanys. For may þou sowme me þire sedis · surely þou trowe, Þou mi&yogh;t a-count all oure kni&yogh;tis · & oure kyd ostis; And þou truches þaim to tell · þen tidis þe na noþir, Bot move a-gayn to Messedone · & meve MS. me, altered to meve. þe na forthire. Fyne, fole, of þi fare · & fange to þi kythis; For þis sede I þe send · vnsowmyd bees neuire. So ere we of all folke · folke to be nombrid, Or any wee to a-counte · vndire þe clere sternys." Now aires furth his athill men · to Alexander wendis, Vn-to þe streme of struma · stre&yogh;t with þa lettirs, And he þam redis in a rese · & reches to Added in margin . þe sedis, Tastis þam vndire his tuthe · & talkis þir wordis: "Here I se," quod þis sire · "be þire ilke cornes, Þat þe pupill out of Persy · ere passandly many, MS. meke many; but meke is struck out . Bot þam semes to be softe · as þir sedis prouys; For-þi how fele be all þe flote · it forces bot littill." Be þis was men of Messedone · fra his modire comen, And said þat semely was seke · & semed to die; And he þe waest of þe werd · wald worth hire to visite, Bot &yogh;it to Dary, or he went · he MS. his, altered to he. di&yogh;t þus a lettir.

1.1: Syr Dere Darius on dese · þe digne Emperour, Epistola darij. The kyng withowt comparison · of kyngez all oþer, Of al lordes þe Lord · þat leues in erthe, Predecessour of princez · & peir to þe Son, The souerane syre of my sole · þat sittis in myne trone, In fange with my faire god · þat I affye maste, To Alexander, þat of all · so augerdly hym letes, Oure seget & our siruant MS. souerent siruant; the former word expuncted. · þus our-selfe writtez. For it is wayfed vs to wete · þou haues wikedly, Thrugh enmyte & enuye · Elacion of pride, Be vanyte & vaynglory · þat in þi vaynes kyndeles, Purvayd þe pletours · oure partez to ryde. For þou hase sampned, als men sayn · a sellich nowmbre Off wrechez & of wyrlyngez · out of þe west ende, Off laddez & of losyngers · & of lityll thefez, Siche sary sorowez as þi-self · to seke vs agayns, And wenys to weld at þi wille · þat worthez full late, The prouince & þe principalite · of perse le graunt. Bot þou ert fere all to faynte · oure force to withstonde; Þof MS. Of. þou hade gederit it written above the line. all þe gomez · þat euer god formede, So, man, ryfe is owr reme · þat þou may wele lekyn Þe sture strenth of owr stoure · to þe sternez of heuen; And sike a neker als þi selfe · ane noght of all oþer, Is bot MS. bod. a maddyng to mell · with mare þen þi-selue. For-þi is better vnbende · & of þi brathe leue, . . . . . For mare menske is a man · to meke hym be tyme, Than after made to be meke · mawgre hys chekys. For all þe graciouse goddes · & goddesse on erth, . . . . . Praysez ay þe persens · passyng all oþer, And for þe oddest of ilke one oste · honours owr name. And slyke a dwynyng · a drawgh of þi-seluen, A grob, a grig out of grece · ane erth-growen sorow, Wyll couett &yogh;itte as a kyng · with catyffez litell, To couer & to combre all þe kyngez · vnder þe Cape of heuen! Right as a flaw of fell snaw · fallen wer fro þe drifte, Of a wistus wondyn wagh · with þe wynd blayn, So with a flote of fresons · folowand thi heles, Thu sekys fraward sychim · þi-selue with euell haille, And Leues as a losell · owr land for to entre, And make þi lepys & þi lakez · & qwat þou list ellys, As ratons or ronke myce · in a rowme chaumbre, About on beddes or in bernez · þar baddez er nane. Bott I haue willyly wayted · þi wilez & þi castez, And when þou hopys all-þir eldest · to haue at þou likez, I sall þe sett on a sawte · & slaye þe with my handez, And so sall, fole, for þi folez · be fenyshit on dawes. For þi pompe & þi pride · þi purpasse avyse, MS. to avyse; but to is better omitted. For yf þou shote ouer-sheet · þou shendes þi flayne. Turne MS. To me wrongly. þe, trechour, be tyme · þat þou no treson hable, And [drawe] agayn to þi den · vnder þi dame wengez. Se qwat I sende þe, son · þi-selfe with to layke, A hatt here & a hand-balle · & a herne-panne; MS. payne, corrected to panne. Slike presantes MS. presandez presantes. to play with · as pertenys þe to haue. For ay a childe most hym chose · vnto childer gammez; For mister & for michefe · vneth may þou forth Þine awne catef cors · to cloth & to fede, And &yogh;it supposes as A sott · to sesyn owr Landez, And Darius to drepe · & dryve owt of hys lys, corrected to hys. kythes! Bot be þe grace & þe goode · þat god gafe my fader, So ryfe is þe rede gold · oure regions within, At who so had it on a hepe · holy to-gedre, MS. to gredre. It wald hym lett, as I leue · þe light of þe Son! For-þi bid I þe badly · vppon payn of þi eghen, MS. eughen. And on þe plight & payn · & perle þat folows, All þi vanyte to voyde · & þi vayn pryde, And mefe ayayn to masydon · or ony mare falle. For, be þe sawle of my sire · bot yf þou sone turne, I sall send þe suche a sume · of segges enarmed, Þat noght as philip faunt · þou sall fare with þi-seluen, Bot as a prince reproued · sall be pynyd to dede." Als sone as euer hys sondesmen · to þis syre commyn, Thai present hym playnly · & þat pistill hym rechys, And alexander als byliue · before hys atell So in MS. princez, And to þe host euen ouer · it opynly declares. And when þe knyghtez · of þis clause vnderstonde, Than wer þai felly MS. fellyd. affrayed · of hys fell sawes; And als sone as hym-selfe se · hys seges ameyved, In beldyng of hys bachelers · he breues þees wordes: "What now? my worthy weryours · so wight & so noble, My bernes & my barotours · þe best vnder heuen; Lett neuer it be broght on brade · for vmbrayd of shame, Yhe dout for þe dityng · of darius pistell. I sett you an ensaumple · ye se it euerilke day, In thorpus & in mony thede · þare ye þorow ryden, MS. dyden. . . . . . For yf he bremely bays · he bitez neuer helder. Bot in some way, I suppose wele · þat soght is hys lettre, Þair as he tellez which tunne MS. tyme. · of tresour he hase. For-þi vs [bus] to be big · & batele hym &yogh;elde, Þe grete garison of gold · sall geder vp owr hertes." With þat commandez þe kyng · hys knyghtez belyfe, Þare Domesmen þat from darius come · with þe derfe lettrez, Þat þai suld titely þaim take · & be to&yogh;e nekez, For þair souerend sake · þaim send to þe galouse. Þen wer þees messyngers amaced · as mervell wer ellez, With carfull chere · to þe conquerour þai saydyn: "Alas! what lake lyes in vs · lord, be your lefe, Thus causles for owr kyng · encombred to worthe?" "The sawez of your soueren" · sayd þe kyng þen, "Nedes me now to seche notes · as I neuer attelytt, That he hase sent to my-seluen · noght as he awght; Lo! 'lityll thefe' in iche line · hys lettre me calles." . . . . . "Þis doyngez sir darius · indited you hym-seluen, For he knew noght your knyghthode · ne your kyd strenthez; Ne wist noght of yowr worthiness · & wrote all þe balder. Bot &yogh;e wald graunt vs to go · & gyfe vs owr lyfez, Than suld we bremely your blysse · vnto þe berne shewe." Þan lete þe Lord þaim alon · & lathys þaim to hys feste, Takes þaim with hym to hys tent · & makez þaim at ease. Sone as þees sandesmen in sale · wer sett at þe table, "Sir alexander, atell kyng" · quod all with a stevyn, "Comand with vs to care · knyghtez a thowsand, And we sall surely owr syre · you send in þair handez." "&YOGH;a, make &yogh;e blysse," quod þe kynge · "blyth mote &yogh;e worthe, For þe lachynge of your Lorde · sall noght a lede weynde." Bot to Darius on þat oþer day · indited he a pistell, A lettre clenly enclosyt · þat consaued þees wordes. "I, alexander, ayr · & eldeste childe bothe Epistola. Of kyng philip þe ferse · þe fender of grece, And als of olimphades · þat honorable ladye, To þe, sir Darius, on dese · þus dite I my lettre. Þou prince of all persens · þat apperys to þe son, The conquerour of ilke coste · callyd of þi-seluen, With all þi graciouse goddes · grathed in þi trone, All þus I send þow to say · vnder my sealle wrytten. Sir, yf we se þe sothe · surely me thynke, Our facultez or faire feys · owr fermez & owre goldes, We may noght chalynge þaim ne clame · ne calle þaim our awne, Bot all I deme as dett · vnto a day borowed. For yff we ryde on þi reme · & on þi renke settyn Off þe whele of forton & þe whene · þat whistely chaungez, Of[t] passe we in-to pouerte · fro plente of godez, Fro mirthe into murnyng · fro murnyng into Ioy. For now vs vantes in a whirre · as þe whele chaungez; When we supposye in howre-selfe · to sitte all-þar heldest, Þen fonndez doun dame forton · to þe flode-&yogh;ates, Drawez vp þe dame-borde · & drenchez vs for euer. For-þi a wye þat hase witte · of þe whele sofre, So MS. So doys he so sodandly; of which doys he is subpuncted . sodandly in hys souerente · to sett neron So in MS.; for neuer on. hys hope For pride of no prosperite · ne prise at hym folowez, To olle ay on hys vnderlinges · for ouerlayke a while. For ony ceyle vnder heven · a sot I hym halde, Þat ay hase dene & dispyte · of dedes of lityll, Syon oft þe haslokst her · is heuen to þe sternes, And he þat MS. þ, with ht above the line . grethest was of goddez · gird all to-geder. For-þi a depe disHonor · yhe do to your Name, Ane Emperour þat on þis erth · is euen to your-seluen, To me so lityll & so lawe · such lettres to wayfe, And presentes owt of perse · bot for a pure hethinge. For þou inheretes all þis werld · & euens vnto þe sun, And calles þe kyng of ilke kyth · vnder þe cape of heuen, And þarto sittes as þou says · in sege as an angell, To-gedre with þi grett goddez · on a gilt trone. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . I knaw I am corruptible · & caire þow agayns, Als a dedlich duk · to do my batell; Bot if þou þe victour availe · no vaunt sall þar rise, No lose, bot of a lityll thef · enlympyd you to combre. Bot chaunce it me, þat I am childe · þe cheuer to worth, So þat if be be, written above the line . gefyn me þe gre · grete glory is my awne. For þan sall springe vp þe speche · & sprede owt of mynde, How at I haue Conquired a king · þe kyddest of þe werld. Bot one tale &yogh;e me tald · I trowe be no fable, Of þe refuse of rede gold · your regions within, Which plente is in perse · of perle & of ellys, Þe some of siluer & of siche · & of sere stones, þar-with owr willes er replete · & our wittes sharped, And baldit vs with þi besaundez · þe batell to byd, Made vs coragiouse & kene · þi clere gold to wynne, And put away our pouerte · yhe pledyn vs to hald. Bot as tochand þe trufels · þat &yogh;e to me send, Þe herne-payn, þe hand-balle · þe hat made of twygges, Þair hase þou prophecied apert · & playnly vs schewed, And fair enformed vs before · þat falle sall after. For be þe bale, sir, I breue · all þe brode werld, The erth þat to myne empire · entirely is &yogh;holden. And be þe hatte, þat is holys Read holow. · & before þe heued MS. heuend; but see l. 1902. bo&yogh;et, I Constrew þat iche kyng · sall incline to my-seluen. Þan hope I, be þe harnepanne · þat þe heued Couers, Ouercommer to be callyd · & ouercomyn neuer. Now þe gretest vnder god · gyfes me truage, With all þar dignitez be-dene · þat deuised I Haue." THys brefe he biddez þaim Bere · & besaundes þaim reches; And aftyr armes hys oste · & ayres on forther. Sir darius for þis detes · nere dyes for sorow, And to two þe derrest of hys dukes · ditez he þis pistell: "I, Coroundest kyng · of kyngez all oþer, Epistola. To þe, sir Priamus, a prince · of þe gretest perse, And also to þe, sir antigon · myne awne athell dukes, The soueranest of my senory · my satrapers halden, Se here I send þou my sealle · with salutes of Ioy. For alexander the kynge · as I am informed, Is entred with owr enmys · ane endles nowmbre, In þe anglez of asy · & hase þaim all stroyde, For-þi on life & on lymez · my legemen I charge To pristly þou apperale · & passe hym agayns, With all þe hatellys & þe herez · & þe hye maisters Þat &yogh;e may assemble on þai sydez · saugeours & oþer. Chesse þou forth chiftanez · & me þis childe takes, Laches me þis losynger · & ledes me hym heder, And [I] sall hym skelp with a scourge · & þen in skyre purpure A syde slauyn hym insew · & send hym hys modre; For now he prokes for pride · & p[ro]prely wodez, For-þi he must be bett · as a barne falles. Bot it aught noght suche brolle · in none armez of werez, Bot at þe bulez as a brode · or with a bale to play." Þire princez, when þis pistell · was putt þaim in hand, Þai departyd þe prowde sealle · þe printe þai honour, And vnlappyd lightly þe leffe · & þe lines redyn, And þus agaynward · þ[a]i grathed hym one oþer. "To þe kyng to acount MS. acoaunt. The MS. has a tag to the final letter of acoaunt. · of all kyngez on erth, Epistola. Sir Dary with þi dere goddez · dressyd in trone, Gouernour MS. Geuernour. of ilke grome · & god all þi-seluen, Þi satrapers, þi senyowrs · with seruyce obidiens: Sir, wetes it your worthynes · & wenys no langer, Þat þis childe with hys chiftanys · &yogh;e charge vs to take, He hase riden all your regions · & raymet owr landez, Desperset all our prouince · & purely distroyde. And we þen liften vp a lite · & rydyn hym ayayns, Ferd forth with a folke · & hym in þe feld metyn; Bot sone wer bidden þaim þe bake · & besely echapyn Owt of handez to þe swerde · mony of owr athelles. And we now haly all þe hepe · þat &yogh;e your helpe callyn, Vnto your mykle mageste · we mekely besekyn, Þat vs your lege & your lele men · it liked &yogh;ou to forther, For owr worship is weynd · & wasted is owr remes." And als radely as þe ryche kyng · had red ouer þe pistell, Be þat mefys in a messynger · & manyly hym tellys, Þat alexander was at hand · & hed an hoste loget Vppon þe streme of streuma · þat straughit þorow þe land. Þen sir dary for þoe dedes · was deply agrevyd, Callys hys counsell · a clause he inditez, Makez a breue in a brayde · & in a breth sendes, To alexander als belyue · & all þus hym gretes. "I, Sir Dary þe digne · & derfe Emperour, Epistola darij. The king of kyngez am called · & conquerour bath, Of all Lordes Lord · lowsed þorow þe werld, And one of þe souerenest syres · vndir þe seuen sternes, To þe, my siruand, I send · & sothly I knaw, And wete þou wele all þe werld · worshippys my name. For all þe gracieux goddez · þat þe ground viseten, All er vndir my obedience · dredles I telle. How durst þou be so bald · for blode in þi heued, To mefe þus ouer þees montannez · & þes mony waters With syke a soume for to seke · a sawt vs to &yogh;elde, Or ony maistre to make · my mageste ayayns? For wele wyde wer þi wele · wete þou none other, Both þi glory & grace · þi gladnesse in erth, Might þou þe marche of masidon · mayntene þi-seluen, And gouern þine awen grund · agayns owr wyll. For-þi it wer better vnbenden · or þou bale suffre, Remefe agayn to þi realm · or þou sall it rewe. For certan, yf my senory · & my-selue ne wer, All þe werld might albido Read a wido. · wele þen be called. For-þi turne þe be-tyme · or ony tene worth, Or þe hate of my hert · on þi heued kyndle. Lend Agayn to þi Land · Will I Leue gefe þe, Lest þou mete with my malicoly · þi might be to lityll. For-þi to ken þe to knawe · my kyngdome her-after, Both my glory & my grace · & my grete strenth, Lo, her a glofe full of granes · I grath þe to rekyn, Off þe chefest of MS. oft. chessebollez · chosyn for þe nonest. For and þou may soume þees sedes · seurly þou leue, Thu may acount MS. acoaunt; see l. 1993. all owr knyghtez · & owr kyd ostez; And yf þou thynkes þaim to tell · þen tydez þe none oþer, To mefe agayn to masidon · & mell þe no forther. Fyne, fole, of þi fare · and fange to þi kythes; For as þis sede þat I send · vnsoumed is euer, So ben we of all Here follows ben we of all fo, crossed through . frekes · & folkez vnnowmyrd, Or ony weght to acount · vnder þe clere welkyn." Now ayres forth þees messyngers · & to alexander wendyn, Vnto þe streme of struma · streght with þis lettres, And þaim redes on a rase he · & rechez to þe sedes, Castes þaim vnder his tothe · & talkys þees wordes: "Here I see," quod þis sire · "be þir selue cornes, Þat þe peple out of perse · er passandly mony, Bot þaim semys to be softe · as þees sedis preuez; And þen how fele be all þe flote · it forcez bot lityll." Be þat was men of masidon · fro hys moder commyn, And þat semely was seke · & semyd to die; And he þe woest of þe werld · wald for hir to visytt, Bot &yogh;it to Darius or he di&yogh;t · he ditez suche a pistyll.

0.1: "Alexsaundere þe athill · aire oute [of] grece, Þe son of Ph[ilip] þe fers · & of his faire lady, Honoured Olimpadas · þe oddest vndire heuyn, To þe, ser Dari, on þi dese · þis dities I write. For I am sent, be þe sure · many sere letters, And namly now on newe time · fra myne awen kith, Out of þe marche of Messadone · þat mekill me greues, All oþer wais to wirke · & my will likis. Bot I warne þe, or I wynd · & will at þou knaw, Þat for na drede I with-draw · ne doute of þi pride, For baisting of þi bobance · ne of þi breme wordis, Bot for to se þat is seke · my semely modire. Bot wete þou wele þis, I-wis · with-in a wale time, Fra þat I fraist haue þat faire · of my fayre lady, I sall þe seke with a sowme · of seggis enarmed, Ane ost to noy þus to neuyn · all of new kny&yogh;tis. And for þe sake of þi sede · þou sent with þi lettre, Loo, here a purse full of pepire · my powere to ken, To se þi-selfe a similitude · how all þi soft grayns Sall vndire-put be all þe pake · vn-to þir peper-cornes." Þis pistill to Persyns · he with his pepir takis, Partis prestly þam to · many proude gittis, And þai haue la&yogh;t þam þar leue · & þe lettir fangis, And passis on to Persy · þe princes to schewe. Þan Alexander belyue · with his athill dukis, Rais him radly to ride · & remowis his ost; Fra þe streme of struma he stre&yogh;tis · & still mournes, And mevis him toward Messedone · his modir to visit. He aires þur&yogh;e Arabie · & armed þar he findis A duke of Darys þe kyng · þat drafe him agayne, A pere out of Persy · & prince of his ost, A maister man in þa marches · Amont was hatten. He girdis him with a ging · þe grekis he asailes. With Alexander all day · asperly fe&yogh;tis, Marres of þe Messedons · mi&yogh;tfull kni&yogh;tis, Dingis doun of þe dukis · deris þam vn-faire, Fra morne to þe mirke ni&yogh;t · maynly þa cocken, Se&yogh;es doun on aythire side · segis out of nounbre. Begynnys sone in þe gray day · as any gleme springis, And so to sett of þe son · sesid þai neuire. Þus thre dais out a thraw · þai threp ay elike; So lange, sais me þe lyne · lastid þe bataill, Sike scoures were of blude · of schondirhed bernes, Þat foles ferd in þe flosches · to þe fetelakis; Sa store & stithe was þe stoure · þe story me tellis, Þat for soro&yogh;e of þe si&yogh;t · þe MS. of the; of being added in the margin, but smeared out . son Added in the margin . on þe heuen Kest away his clerete · & his clippis suffirs, For bale to blische on þe blode · at on þe bent flo&yogh;es. With þat oure gomes out of grece · gedirs vp þar hertis, Fey fallis in þe fild · fele of þire othire, Þe pouwere of Persy · in partis many Se&yogh;es sidlings doun · slayn of þaire blonkis. And quen þe duke of ser Darys · þa dedis be-haldis, Amonta þe mi&yogh;tfull · his men þan he fangis, And vneth limpid him þe lee · þe lyne me recordis, Fra his faes with a fewe · þe filde to de-voide. And slike a pas, sais þe prose · to Persy he ridis, Þat &yogh;it þe Added in the margin . selfe sandismen · he in þe sale fyndis, Þat fra þe streme of struma · were apon stedis wysid Fra Alexander & his ost · with his athill pistill. And &yogh;it ser dary on his dese · þa dities a-visis, Held þe lettir in his loue · & at þe ledis fraynes, Quat he said of þe sedis · þat he Added in the margin . him-selfe sent. And þai swiftly him sward · & swyth þus him tellis: "Þe kyng him ka&yogh;t," quod þe kni&yogh;tis "& on þe cornes bitis, And wele he geses be þe graynes · &yogh;oure gomes ere fele, Bot a thing, he said, he sa&yogh;e · þat solast him maste, Þai ware bot soft, he suposed · for so þe sede proued." Þan pullis him vp þe proude kyng · & on þe pepire tastis, Said, as it tuke him by þe tonge · "his tulkis ere fewe, Bot, be his kni&yogh;tis as kene · as me þis cornes shewis, All þe werd war to waike · his wrothe MS. to wrohe, altered to wrothe to in the margin . to with-stand." MS. hbith stand. Þe mody man Amonta · þan melis þir wordis, "&YOGH;is, he ledis bot a lite · lord, with &yogh;oure lefe; Þare is Added in the margin. bot fewe at him folo&yogh;es · bot fe&yogh;tand bernes, Bot mare fersere in feld · fell neuire of modire. For I my-selfe with a sowme · set þaim agayns, With of þe Persyns proude · a pake out of nounbre, Felire þan his folke · be full fyue thousand, And &yogh;it vs fell all to ferre · þe fayntir to worthe; For þai haue hedid of oure hathils · & a hepe woundid, Fey falne to þe fold · many fers erlis, Bet doun oure bachelers · my banir to-rased, And a selly somme · slayne of my kni&yogh;tis. "Now happy be &yogh;ee," quod þe hathill · "all in hert beris Þe honouris of þat odd clerke · Homore þe grete." "Mekill dere," quod ane Doctoneus · "of &yogh;ow I deme sall, And he of þe takyng of Troi · tald all his lyue." Þen wyndis he to A wath toun · was Wyothy hatten, And come so to Caldipol · anoþer kid cite, So to the watir of wintir · as it þe writte callis. Þare nere was fey for defaute · enfamyschist his ost, Kni&yogh;tis kest vp a crie · & kenely þam menes: "Loo, oure foles ere in fere · fodeles to dye;" Þai pleyne more þe pouirte · & þe pite of þar horsis Þan þe soro&yogh;e of þam-selfe · by þe seuynt parte. 1.1: "I, alexander, eldest · ayr out of grece, Epistola. Þe son of Philip þe fers · & of hys faire lady, Honored olimphades · þe oddest vnder heuen, To þe, sir darius, on þi dese · þis ditez I write. For I am send, be þe sure · mony sere lettres, And nomely now on new tyme · fro my awne kithes, . . . . . All oþer-wyse to wirke · þen my wille liked. Bot þis I werne, or I wende · & will at þou knaw, Þat for no drede I withdraw · þe dow of þi pryde, MS. proyde, or peryde (like per in piper, l. 2023); read pryde. For basyng ne for bobas · ne for breme wordes, Bot for to Se þat is Seke · my awne Semelych Modre. Bot wete þou wele þis, I-wisse · in a wale tyme, Fra þat I fraysted haue þe fare · of my faire lady, I sall þe seche with a soume · of seggez enarmed, One oste to ney vs to newyn · & all of new knyghtez. And for þe sake of þi sede · þou send with þi writte, Lo, here a purse full of piper · my power to ken, To se þi-selfe a similitude · how all þees softe granes So vnder-put [be] all þe pake · of þis pete cornez." Thys pistyll to þe persens · he with þis peper takys, Partes pristly to þaim · mony proude gyftez, And þai haue laughten þair leue · & þe lettrez fangett, And passyd vnto perse · þe prince it to shewe. Then alexander · with hys atell Dukez, Rachez hym radly to ride · & remevez hys ostez, Fro þe streme of struma · he moved & stilly murnez, And mefez on toward masydon · hys moder to viset. He ayers toward araby · & armyd þar he fyndez A duke of Darius þe kyng · þat drafe hym agayns, A Pere owt of perse · & prince of hys hoste, A maister man of þe marche · amonta was callyd. He girdez in with a gyn · þe grekes assaylez, And with alexander all þe day · asperly feghtez, Marres of þe masidons · mightfull knyghtez, Dynges downe of þe dukez · deres þaim vnfaire, Fro morne vnto mirke nyght · manly þai feghtyn, Slew downe on ather syde · seges owt of nowmbre. Began in þe gray day · when þe gleme spronge, And so to þe sett of þe son · sessyd þai neuer. þus iij dayes in a thraw · þai threpyd euerelike; So lang, says þe line · lastyd þe batell, Slyke showrez of shire blode · of shenderet bernes, Þat folez faired in flosshez · to þe fete-lakez; So sture & styff was þe stoure · þe story me telles, Þat for sorow of þat fight · þe son of heuen Lost hase is clarite · & hys clepys sufers, For bale to Blissh on blod · þat on þe bent flowes. With þat owr gomes owt of grece · gerdyn vp þair hertes, And fellyd fele in þe feld · feyle of þis oþer, Þe power owt of perse · in parteez mony Sweyd sleghtly downe · slayn of þair blonkes. And when sir Darius duke MS. ye duke; but ye is subpuncted . · þis dedes bihaldyn, Amonta þe mightfull · hys men þen he fannges, And vneth limpyd hym þe lyfe · þe line me recordes, And fro hys faes with A few folke · þe feld he deuodes. And suche a passe, þen says þe prose · to perse he rydez, Þat &yogh;it þe some sendesman · he in þe sale fyndez, At fro þe streme of strema · was on stedes wysett Fro alexander & hys hoste · with hys athell pistyll. And &yogh;itt sir darius on þe dese · on þis dytes awysez, Held þis lettre in hys loue · & at þe ledes franes, What he sayd of þaes sedes · þat he þaim send hed. And þai MS. þai hym, but hym is subpuncted . swyftly hym sware · & sothly hym tald: "The kyng þaim kacht," MS. katht. quod þe knyghtes · "& on þe kirnels bote, And wele he gessed be þe granes · your gomes er softe, Bot on MS. ony, corrected to on. thynge, he sayd, he sayd repeated; but once expuncted . he sawgh · þat solast hym mekyll, Thai wer bot softe, he supposyd · for so þe sede preved." Þan wendes he to a wale towne · was worthyly haldyn, And Come so to cadypolez · ane oþer kyd cite, So to þe water of wynter · als it þe writte calles. "What aylez you nowe?" quod alexander · to hys athell Dukez, "My barons & my baratours · biggest on erth, That hase þe angers of armes · ay to now sofferd; Wheþer euer your hertes · for horse-fleshez abaytez? May we noght lympe, if ony lyfe · leng in our brestes, To couer be case at a cleke · coursours a thouusand? And yf vs demyd be þe dome · to dye all at ones, Þan standes in stede noght of A stra · all our styffe stedes. For-þi The i above the line in MS. I rede," quod þe renke · " We rydyn on Forþer, And passe we to som oþer place · where plente is in, Thare we may fang at þe full · þe fode at vs wantes, And bath our folk & owr folez · fyll þaire wambes." Then prekys he forth with hys princez · to suche a place wendes, Luctus it þe lettre · & þe line calles; Thare as hys saugeours hase fondyn · þe fulth of þe vitale, Bath to bern & to blonke · byde whils he liked. When he was fulle þar & fed · he flittes hys ostez, To tergarontes he ti&yogh;t · þar telde was a mynster; Py&yogh;t doun hys pauvilons · & passyd to þe temple, Sir appolyn to adoure · & oþer alde goddez, To offre in þat oratory · with honour in he wendes, And of som sperete to spire · how he spede suld. Bott on &yogh;acora hym sayd · a semlych Nonn, So in MS. þar was none oþer answer · bot ane oþer day to abyde. Þan drafe hym for[th] þe dere kyng · &, on þe day after, He soght into þe sinagoge · & sacrifice makez, And appolyne als belyue · hym aukwardly answers, 'Sir ercules þis emperour' · hym euer onon clepys. Than alexander all in ire · angerly spekys: "Now fynde I wele," quod þe freke · "þat false er þi wordes, For þou nevens a new name · þat I neuer hight; And þou a god," quod þe gome · "þat is grete Ioy!" Then sekys he forth with a soume · & to a cyte wendes, Þat Ilke towne hight tebea · þe tretez so it calles, And þar he biddez all þe burgh · þat foure bald knyghtez Suld be lett with hym wende · & in hys werys lenge. Þen tenyd þe tebe folke · & tit to þe &yogh;atez, And withstode his strenth · & strode to þe walles, Bad hym buske on belyue · & abyde þar no langer; For if he dyd, withowtyn dowte · þe dede þai hight hym. Þan fangez vp þe fele kyng · a ful fenyd laughter, Sayd, "&yogh;e of tebe er triest · & thethiest on erth, Off all þe seges vnder sun · þat citesyns er called; Most heyly ye be auancett · & hight in hert. And alexander als belyfe · all vmbe þe cyte, Mase iiij Mille Read thousand, which is intended by this contraction for Lat. mille . to fonde · with flanes & bowes, Byddes þame to bend vp · & brathly with arowez To wound þe wyes within · þat on þe wallez hoved. And two thouusand be tale · he tytely Commandez, Of wele busked bernes · in brenes & in plates, All þe sydes of þe cite · þat sichus had bigged, And amphion, þe athell kemp · anone to distroye. And iiij Mille Read thousand, which is intended by this contraction for Lat. mille . he fonge · to fyre þe iiij &yogh;ates, Bot thre Mille Read thousand, which is intended by this contraction for Lat. mille . of thra men · to thraw with engynez. Hym-self with slengers & slyke · he somned Or soumed. a men&yogh;e, To heyd & to help hys hynes · if any harme limpyd. Now er is seges all sett · & þe saute neghed, Were wakned be-twene · werblet trompez; Our peple with pavyce · presen to withowt, Halez vp hemp cordez · hurlett owt arows; Oþer athells of armes · alblastrez benden, Whirres owt qwarels · wappyd thrugh males. Som with gunnez of þe grekys · gyrdyn vp stones, To tene þe tebet folke · þat on þe toure fighten; Som bradyn oure þe barres · in blysnand wedes, And faire fest on a fyre · all þe foure &yogh;ates; Þat all þe burgh at a brayde · was on a blasse kyndlett, And þo þat sunde wer vnslayne · as seges þaim &yogh;olden. Than was withowt in þe ost · als þe buke tellys, A syre, þat sicistreus Or sicisterus. · was seget to name, A mery man, a messyngere · þat manly was Ioynet Read Ioyed. To see þe cite be so sone · shendit to brandes. Ane-oþer athell vnder hand · þat Hisman was callyd, One maister of musike · a man of þe cite, Ayrez hym to Alexander · & in hys hert wepys, Als wha sa, "Prince, of your place · som pite &yogh;e haue." Then lokys þe lord to þe led · sayd, "lettred berne, Whare to fenys þou þis fare · for-with my eghen I see?" "Sir Conquerour," quod þis clerk · "your MS. pore. corage to bynde, And in riddyng of our riche towne · your reuth for to calle." Than was þe wale kyng wroght · & wittily Commandes To bete into þe bare erth · all þe burgh walles; And when all kyndlett was on colez · & castyn vppon hepys, Than ayrez he on with hys ost · more worship to wyn. A gentilman full ioyles · þen iornays hym after, Folows þe folke ay on fote · as þe faire ryden, A sege of þe same cite · þat syre was & maister, That callyd was clytomacus · to cry after socour, Hys ledes þat left wer on-lyue · a lyte of þe cite. Then askyd þai at sir Apolyn · all with a stevyn, "Yf it worth sall to wy · whil þe world standes, Oure burgh ayayn to be beld · þat brytynd is to noght?" Than galez þar god þaim ayayn · & þus-gates he spekes: "The tulke þat teld mon your town · sall teld vp & rerre, Sall thre tymez haue þe tro · of some kynne gamez Off were or of wristylyng · for so hase werdez shapyn. And when þat worship is won · within a wale tyme, Than sall he sett vp [him] selfe · þe cite als beforne." Thus answers þaim þis old god · & ossus on þis wyse, And þai als fayne, all þe flote · als foule is on morne. Than Ayrez hym on sir Alexander · with hys athell Princez, To þe castell of corinthy · he commys with hys ostez, With þe peres of þai partez · to play on þe towrez, Als all þe syres of þat sydez · hem-selfe hed required. The multitude Wher to muche · oF men for to reken, That wer þar semblyd & set · þat feght to be-hold. Quod alexander als belyue · to all þat þar stodyn: "What gome sall þis gamen · begyn vpon first?" Then commes furth Clytomacus · & to þe kyng sweres, The tulke owt of tebe · I tald you beforne; "If it your mekyll mageste · might any thyng please, I wald to wakyn oure welth · now wrastyll a turne." Þen makes þe prince hym a place · & prestly hym maches, And he hym grydes to þe grund · & þe gre wynnez. "Now fathfully, quod þe feyle kyng · "þus fall þou thrisse, Thu sall be crownyd, or I go · for kyddest of gamme." Þen &yogh;ode he eftsons to · & hys euen castes, Thrynges to þe thryd tyme · & þe thro wynnes. And þen Commandes þe kyng · a croune on heued, Als for þe fee of þe play · pi&yogh;t-full of stanes; Then byde hym bedels belyfe: · 'breue vs þi name.' "Sirs, be my soght," quod þe seghe · "siteles I. e. city-less; so also town-less in line 2288. I hyght." "Whi so, my worthy wristiller?" · þe wale kyng sayd, "How tydes it þe at tounles · þi to-name is called?" "My louely Lord," quod þe lede · & law he declynes, "Before &yogh;e Come suche · & þe crowne wered, I hed a cyte my-self · & seges enowe; And syne &yogh;e aught þis empyre · & I am depriued." Then trowyd trewly þe kyng · at tebet he neuynd, And Bedels & bail&yogh;ais · he bad a-none crye, Before hys peple so pert · & hym þe power grauntez To set hys cite vp agayn · & of hym-self hald. Þan passys he to a prouud toun · platea was haten, þar was sti&yogh;let one strasagera · þat was a styffe Prince, Dose hym in with hys Dukes · to Dicnas Read Dianas. temple, And fand a pure prophett · apparelt in wales. And als sone as sho hym see · sho sayd þees wordes: "Welcom, wye, þat þe werld · sall wynne with þi handes." Þe secund day before þe sun · he þat cite weLdit, To þe temple he tight · tithanndez to herken. "What is Written above the line in MS. þi will," quod [the] woman, "sir, to witt · & how þou me franes; For þou lossez all þi Lordschips · within a lityll dayes." "What & hase þu ossed to alexander · þus aydom wordes, And me þus? vnably · þinē habet þou werys." "Nay, tene þe noght, for trewly · þus tyde bus it nedes." And so it worthed, for in a wrath · þe wale kyng swyth Hym of hys principalite depriues · & þen þe Prince fondes Anone vnto athens & on · of þe athell Planettes; So in MS.; but corruptly. And þai sayd, saire suld he sike · bot he þe cite &yogh;elde. And alexander with hys ost · þen ayres on ferþer, Attellys hym toward þe terme · & of þe tene heres, And such a word he þaim wayffez · be writte fro hym-seluen. . . . . . . . . . .

0.1: "I Alexander, þe aire · & eldest childe hatten Of kyng Philip þe fers · þat fest am in grece, And of þe quene Olimpades · þe oddest vnder heuen, To all &yogh;ow of Athenes · þus etill I my sa&yogh;es. Fra þat my fadere was fey · & farne out o lyue, And I was sett in his sege · with septour to regne, Sethen went I with my werriours · in-to þe west endes, And ay with-out any armes · þaim all at anys &yogh;olden, All Europe to myn enpire · enterely þaim geuyn, Euyn to þe Occiane · out of ald Rome. Qua þat vs rekinly resayues · na riddour þai tholid, And all at othire wais wro&yogh;t · we wast þam for euire. And now fra þe marche of Messedone · I meued opon late Þur&yogh;e þe anglis here of Afle · with myne athill dukis, And so þe Thebies þam ti&yogh;t · þe toun to defende, And I þar pompe MS. ponpe. & þaire pride · to poudire declined. To &yogh;ow now write I on þis wise · þat, wald &yogh;e Added in the margin. me send Ten fyne Philisofours so is written above the line . · to fand with my wittes, &YOGH;oure bur&yogh;es ne &yogh;our bri&yogh;t bees · bidd I þan nothire, Bot at &yogh;e knaw me for kyng · & call me &yogh;our lord. For & &yogh;e nyk now to myn empire · &yogh;our nekis for Added in the margin. to bowe, Þan bos &yogh;ow bigger MS. biggis. to be · þen all my bald princes, Or laite anothire ladis-man · a-losed mare of strenth Þan I my-selfe or my seggis · be þe seuent dele." Þire athils of Atenes · þir augard clerkis Þan reuerenst þai þe riche seele · & red ouer þe pistill, Syne kest vp a crie · with a kene voice at anys, Sum in comending of his carpe · & on clene it spitid. A Filisphire þan on first · before þe folke risis, Ane Eschilus in erde · & ernstly he spekis, Þe douth & all diuinours · be-dene he comaundis, Þat þai suld corde be na cas · vn-to þe kingis hestis. With þat all samen on a sopp · semblis þe pupill, A doctour, ane Domystyne · þai derely beseke To consaile þaim als in þe cause · & ken þam þe best. And he rekinly rase · & rekyns þire wordis: "I be-seke &yogh;ow now, my citi&yogh;ens · if þat &yogh;e safe vouche, Bot sobirly a sete quile · my sa&yogh;es for to here. Sirs, if &yogh;e fele &yogh;ow so fers · his force to with-stand, Aires agaynes him with armes · admitts no&yogh;t his sa&yogh;es. And if MS. inserts fy, struck out . &yogh;e fynde &yogh;e be to faynt · fulfillis his will, Vn-to his mekill maieste · mekely &yogh;ow bowe. For Sexes in sum time · surmountid all kyngis, &YOGH;it li&yogh;t he law at þe last · for all his lethire prid. Bot Alexander with his armee · in alkin rewmys Has happend &yogh;it ai hedire-to · þe herre of his faes; Vnnombirable ere þe notis · to neuen of his weres, And &yogh;it betid neuir þe time · þat euire tuke he schame. Ware no&yogh;t þe tulkis out of Tire · þe tidiest on erth, Þe kiddest kni&yogh;tis to a-count · vnder þe cape of heuen, Quat bathe for corage & kene · & connyng in armes? Loke quare it profet þam a peese · all þaire proud strenth. Was no&yogh;t þe Thebes þar-to · þe threyest MS. theyest; with a third e above y. of othire, Þe worthiest wees of þe werd · & of witt clerest, Fra þat þaire cites ware sett · þe sotelest of weres? Quat seruyd all þai sapient · or sle&yogh;t MS. sele&yogh;t; altered to sle&yogh;t. of batall? Of Poliponenses þe pupill · with þis prince fo&yogh;ten, And þat þam lethirly con like · by þe lattir ende, For þar þe kyng of þaire kythe · was killid doun & heded, His renkis raymed all þe route · & all þe rewme &yogh;olden. Wate &yogh;e no&yogh;t wele þur&yogh;e all þe werd · how wirdis with him cheues? Hase he no&yogh;t cites butt saute · sesyd out of nounbre? And for Strasagirs þe strang · he of his strenth priued, &YOGH;e meue al þus malicoly · his maieste a-gayne. Þare do &yogh;e no&yogh;t &yogh;our deuire · þat dare I wele proue, It was þe gilt all of þe gome · & no&yogh;t of þe gud lord. With þat all of Atenenys · þis aunceant maistir, And clene all þe clergy · comensure & othire, Þis diuinour Domestyne · bedene þai comendid, A-cordis þaim to his consaile · & kendly it prased. Þan amed þai to ser Alexander · onane for to send A croune all of clere gold · clustrid with gemmes, Of fyfty ponde with þe payse · as þe prose MS. prorose. tellis, Þis tresoure tire þai him to · & tribute him hetes. Now ere þe sandismen MS. sandisment. · sett on þaire horsis, A Ientill man þat Iowell · enioyned was to kepe, Þat was full sekirly & soft · all in silke falden; Bot clerkis to þe conquirour · caired with þaim many. Þan was ser Darius dred · & sembled derf ostis, His kni&yogh;tis, his consaill · & carpis þire wordis, Said:"lo! my seris, now may se · &yogh;our-selfe with &yogh;our e&yogh;en, How Alexander in his armes · all-way encreses, In valour & in victori · & vertues so noble; Þare as I thret him as a thefe · thedis to dispoyle, Now werrays he full worthily · as wi&yogh;t man suld, Constreynes with his contenance · kni&yogh;tis to him bow. If þai were sary & so · na selly me thingke, For ay þe hele of þe hede · helpis all þe menbris. Þan callis to him þe conquirour · a clerke of his awen, Ane Philip, his fesisiane · his fare to behald; Of al manere of medcyne · man þat maste couthe, A &yogh;onge berdles barne · as þe buke tellis, Said: "lat li&yogh;tly my lord · for in a litill stonde My-self with a serop · sall saue &yogh;ow be-lyue." Þan permeon þe proude · a prince of his ost, Þat held þe erth of Ermonye · & enmyte hadd Vn-to þis clerke of þe kyngis · & be no cause els Bot for þe lede was loued · & with þe lord chereschest; Þan ames he to ser Alexander · on ane slike a pistill: "Kepis &yogh;ow," quod he, "conquirour · & caches no&yogh;t his drenke; For Darius eftir his deth · his do&yogh;ter has him hi&yogh;t, And &yogh;ow to sla be som sle&yogh;t · to sese him his landis." &YOGH;it was þe berne no&yogh;t a bene · baist of his wordis, He asurid him so sadly · þe serep he takis, Þe licor in his awen looue · þe lettir in þe tothire, And in-to Phili[pi]s face · fast MS. face face fast. he behaldis. He bad him dred neuire a dele · & it drink swyth, And þan þe pistill of þe prince · he put him in hand. Þe leche lokid ouire þe lynes · "my lording," he said, "I am no&yogh;t gilty of þis gile · be all þe grete gods!" As fast was he fysche-hale · & Philip he callis, Halsis him full hertly · & of his hele thankis, Said, "wele knew þou my kynd · lufe þi concience, First suposid I of þi serop · syne sesid þe þe lettir. "Mi louely lord, be &yogh;our leue · lattes him a-pere, Þe tulk at sike a trayne · has touchid to my-selfe." Þan eftir ser Permes his prince · prestly he sendis, And þare þe trechoure was tane · & for his trayne hedid. Þan mouys he furth with his men · & Medy he wynnys Enterly to his empire · & Ermonye þe mare. Till a dissert þan he drafe · was dry & na watere, Þur&yogh;e Adriac till Eufraten · & ames þare his tentis, And mas a brig ouire þe bourne · of Barges MS. Bargos. with cheynes; Comandis his kni&yogh;tis ouire to caire · & þar þai vncachid MS. cachid, with vn above . hertis. Þai sa&yogh;e þe streme so stife · it stonaid þam all, For ferd þe festing suld faile · & þai in þe flode droune. Þan mas he laddis ouire to lend · & lokars of bestis, And monestis þam ilk modire-son · him maynly to tell. &YOGH;it was his baratours a-baist · & þen þe berne writhis, Fandis him first on be-fore · & all folo&yogh;es eftir. Þan passid þare out of Paradese · twa proude Flummes, Þur&yogh;e Medy & Messopotane · þai move, as I fynd, And so to In the margin . Babilon þai bowe · ane is þe bourne of Tygre, Þe tothire is Eufrates full euen · & rynnes so to Sylus. Þan cutis MS. tutis. þe kyng in to þe cablis · & to his kni&yogh;tis sais: "Lo! þof vs fall now to flee · we may na ferryre wend; Þare I rede," quod þe kyng · "oure bakis neuir to turne, And if we did, with-outen dome · to die all at anes; For he þat folowid has ai þe floure · & he at fled neuire. Bees li&yogh;t & laches &yogh;ow a lose · it is a lord gamen. For I make a-vow at Messedone · we sall na mare see, Till all þe barbres vs bow · þan may we blith turne."

1.1: I alexander, ayre · & heldest child both Epistola. Off kyng philip þe fers · þat fessit am in grece, And of þe whene olimphades · þe oddest vnder hevyn, To all you of atthenys · þus atthill I my sawes. Fro þat my fader was fey · & fallyn out of lyve, And I was sett in hys sege · with septour in hand, Syne went I with my weryours · in-to þe west ende, And þai withowtyn armys · þaim all at onys &yogh;eldyn, All europe to my empyre · enterly þai geven. . . . . . Who þat rekenly vs resaued · no raddour tholett, And all þat other-wyse wroght · we wastyd for euer. And now fro þe marche of massydon · I mefed on late Torow þe anglez of asy · with myne athell Dukez, And so þe tebes þaim ty&yogh;t · þe toun to defende, That I þair pompe & þair pride · to powder haue declined. And now writte I on þis wise · þat, wold &yogh;e me send Ten MS. Then. fyne philosophirs · to fond with my wittez, Your burghes ne your bryght bees · bidde I none oþer, Bot þat &yogh;e knaw me for your kyng · & calle me your Lord. For nyk yhe to myne empyre · your nekkys for to bowe, Þan bus you bigger to be · þan all my bald Princes, Oþer lates ane oþer lodesman · alosed more of strenth Then I my-self & my seges · be þe seuynt dele." Þoes athels of athens · þes awgerd Clerkez Þen reuerenst þai þe riche seale · & red ouer þe pistell, Syne kestyn vp a clene voyce · & cried all at onys, Some in Commendyng of hys carpyng · & som in dyspysyng. Than A philisofre MS. philipofre. on þe frist · before þat folke ryses, Ane Esculus in þat erde · & egirly spekes, Þe MS. &yogh;e. Doughty & all Dyuynours · be-dene he Commandez, Þat þai suld acord be no case · to þe kyngez heste. With þat al sampnes in a sopp · assempbles þe peple, A Doctour, ane Domestyn · þai derly besekyn To Counsell þaim in þat cause · & ken þaim þe best. And he þan rakenly rose · & rekens þees wordes: "I Beseke you now, my citesyns · if þat &yogh;e saue woche, Bot soberly a sete qwyle · my sawys for to herkyn." And sayd, "if &yogh;e feyle you so ferce · hys force to withstond, Ayres ayayns hym with armes · admittes noght hys sawes. And if yhe fynd &yogh;e faynt · fulfyll þan hys wylle, Vnto his mekyll mageste · mekely you bowes. For sexes in som tyme · sirmountyd all kyngez, &YOGH;it li&yogh;t he lawe at þe last · for all hys lethir pride. Bot alexander with hys armes · in alkyn realmes Hase happynd ay &yogh;it hyder · to þe hyer of hys foes; Vnnowmerable er þe notez · to nevyn of þe weres, And &yogh;itt betyd neuer þe tyme · þat euer toke he shame. Wer noght þe tulkez of tire · þe triest of þe werld, Þe kyddest knyghtez to acount · vnder þe cope of heuen, What bath MS. has þe after bath, but it is struck out . of corage & kene · & connyng of armez? Loke quar it profett þam a pese · all þair proude strenth. Wer noght þe tebettes þarto · þe tithiest of oþer, The worthiest wyes of þe werld · & of witte clerest, . . . . . What seruyd &yogh;itte all þar sapience · & sleghtes of were? Of poliponenses þe peple · with þis prince feghten, And þat þaim lederly con like · &yogh;it at þe latter ende, For þar þe kyng of þe kyth · was kyllyd downe & heued, Hys renkes raymet all þe route · & hys realme &yogh;olden. Wayte &yogh;e noght wele þorow all þe werld · how all thyng with hym goys? . . . . . And for strasagera þe strang · he of hys strenth priues, &YOGH;it &yogh;e make you malicoly · hys mageste ayayns. Þarto yhe do not your Diuour MS. Dinuour. · I dar it wele prefe, It was þe gilt of gome · not of þe gode Lord. For had he noght trasped hym vnto · I take on my saule, . . . . . And for þe graunt of þe sir alexander · is all þe werld famed For one of þe curtasest kyng · þat euer crowne weryd, And wete &yogh;e wele þat suche a wye · þat is so wyse haldyn, He wald neuer sussprise · no sege vnder heven." With þat all þise athenez · & þa auancet maisters, And Clene all þe clerge · commensour & oþer, Thys Diuinour domestyn · by-dene þai commendyn, Acorde þaim to hys counsell · & kenly it prasen. Then ameyd þaim to sir alexander · anone for to send A Crowne all of clene gold · clustred with gemmys, Of fifty pound was þe passe · as þe prose tellys, Thys tresour tire þai hym to · & tribute hym highten. Now er þe sandesmen in sute · sett on þar blonkez, A gentilman þat Iowell · inioneyd was to kepe, Þat was full sarkenly & full soft · all in sylke falden; Bot clerkes to þe conquerour · cayred with þaim none. Then meffyd forth þe messyngers · myles bot a few, And li&yogh;t all belyue · at þe lordes tentes, Knele downe before þe kyng · & hym þe crowne raughten, And &yogh;erly tribute hym to gyf · &yogh;apely hym highten. Than tase þe godman þair giftez · & gretly þaim thankes, And vnderstondes in a stound · how it stode clene, And of þe eggyng of EscuLus · þat ertyd hys foes, To withsitte hys sawe · & serue noght hys pistyll. The dytes of domestyn · & so dyd of both, Þat Counsellyd hys Commaundment · to kepe on all wyse. Yit neuer-þe-leter to þo ledes · a letter he enformed, In presydence hys Awne prince · reportand þes wordes: "I, kyng Philipp son þe ferce · & hys fayre ladys, Honourd olymphades · þat I obey most, I kepe neuer kyng to be called · ne cache me þat name, To Better Til. all þe barberon blude · bowe to þe grekys. I attellyd neuer athens · with armes to entre, Bot you questions to enquire · to wete with my writtes. And purposed ay out of reproue · your persens to leue, Bot &yogh;e þe contrary clene · in your conscience doys shew. Bot whilke of yow as foundes frist · on fote vs agayns, Sall neuer voyde my dysdane · ne my derfe Ire. And &yogh;e at thynkys wykkydly · & wyrkys agayns; For as þe grane is of þe grase · & þar growez þe frute. The tebettes tulkyd Perhaps for tukkyd. vs with tene · atyred þaim in armys, &YOGH;itt for all þair riallte · resaued þai þair mede. And for strasagera þe stout · &yogh;e styfly me blame, Thar as he giltyd me ayayns · I hym gradit haue, I wrate to you me to wafe · ten wise clerkez; Yhe kest out Commandmentes · & knew noght my strenth. I might a-coup you of þat cause · & I it kyth wald; Bot I forgyfe you all þe gilt · & grefez me no more. For-þi beys glade now, all þe pake · &yogh;e sall no grefe sofre, The Diuynour Domestyn · for &yogh;e hys domes halden." And fro þai consaued hed þe clause · & construed þe pistyll, Thai wer þe meriest modersons · þat might on morne rise. Now fonndes he furth þe fele kyng · & flittes hys ostez, . . . . . Without þe burgh on a bank · beldit he hys tentez, And þar hym-self with a soume · in a sege lenges. Þe MS. To þe. ledes out of lacydon · belyfe þaim assembled, Sayd: "bow we neuer to hys body · for bale vppon erthe, MS. erthd. Ne lett vs neuer be so lethir · þat we leke worthen To þise out [of] athens · for it wer opyn MS. orpyn. shame; For þai wer basyt for hys beste · & ferd for noght; Bot be we knyghtly & kene · oure corage to shew." With þat þai &yogh;arken to &yogh;ates · & &yogh;oden to þe walles, Some in Iompons & in Iesserauntez · som Ioned in platez. A grayne of þe grete see · glad þaim all vmbe; For-þi buskys þaime þe burgesse · a batale withowt, Pressen forth at posternes · vnto a place wenden, Shalkez shotten into shippez · all in shire malys, Arches with arows · with atterd barbes, Gone þaim into galays · & grathen þaim þarforne. Bowyn bernes into bargez · with Basynettes on heued, MS. heuend. Sparthys spitous to spend · & speres in handes, Þai crossyn ouer toward þe kyng · als kene men shulden, With als fele on þe flode · as foughten within. Þe lord hym lokez on þe ledes · & a lityll Smylez, And Send þaim vnder hys sealle · þis saughez in a pistyll. "Myself, philipp þe fell kyngez [son] · as I first sayd, epistola. & als of olimphades · I only you rede, Þat þe ende of your elders · enterly &yogh;e holden, And rooues Or roones. noght at þe rayne-bowe · þat reche &yogh;e ne may, And þe power of persyens · so purely &yogh;e trasten. Lettes se, nemmys yow a name · & naytes your strenthe; Bot bowes first fra your bargez · & blythly þam woydez, For fest I al in a fyre · þe foly is your awne." The ledes owt of lacidon · when þai þe lettres herd, War drery, bot [for] all þe dole · þai dight þaim to fight. With þat þe kyng & hys knyghtes · vmbelappes þe cite, Sett all þe Galays on gledes · brynt doun þe wallez; The cetyners & þe sergeantes · all þat vnslayne weryn Bowes þan to þe baratour · both bodes & lyfez. "&YOGH;e knowe wele," quod þe conquerour · "my Commyng was full easy; Bot for Above the line in MS. &yogh;e fonge me not fair · nowe fyryd er your shippez, Your borgh es bryttynyd & your berne[s] · I byd you my|seluen, &YOGH;e suld nott study ne stem · þe sternes to byholde. For he þat steppys on a stegh · when þe stoure faylez, Þen fallys hym þe festyng of hys fete · & falle hym byhofys; So ryght as sixes was slayne · some tyme with your aldours, Als ettled &yogh;e Sir A[lexander]. · bot þar your kast faylyd." When he þis sagh hed þaim sayd · þe Cyte he þam grauntyd, Fondes forth with hys folke · þair franchez þaim lefys. Thys souerayne with hys seneours · throghe secyll he wendes, thoght to ryde & to rame · þe regions of Barbers. Þen was sir darius a-drede · & derfly þan sembles Hys knyghtes & hys Counsell · & carped þes wordes, Sayd: "sirys, nowe may &yogh;e se · your-self with your eey, How A[lexander] in hys armys · alway encreses, In valour & victory · & vertus so noble; þar as I thratt [him] as a thefe · thedes to dispoyle, Nowe warreys he full worthily MS. worthtly. · als wi&yogh;t MS. with. man suld, Constraynes with hys contenance · knyghtes to bowe. Þe more I speke hym dispite · & in my speche endered, The heyar I here hym enhaunsyd · & hersud hys name. A ball & a brayne-pan · I to þe berne send, For burde & for bobance · þe bab with to play. Hym þat I Counte bot a knaffe · may now be callyd [maister]; For whar he ffoundez apon fold · dame fortoune hym sewes, For-thi vs hafe buse in hert · þe heyle of our peple, And for no pompe ne no pryde · hys person to dispyse, For hys loyse, ffor all hys hattellayke · is losyt þorow þe werld. And þe more I meng our maieste · þe more it debates, Catchword —þe grace. The grace of þe grete god · I gesse, wele hym helpes, Of pris þe hegh provynce · vnto þis prince lefys. When we hope all þe heldest · to herye hym with armes, Þen am I raddest all our realme · be raymed from vs first." Sone as sir Dary to hys dukez · devysed hase þees wordez, Þen answers hym oryather · on of hys awne brether, "Now hase þis gome oute of grece · so gretly enhaunsed, And we þe lande shuld leve · & he þe landes entre. Bot wald &yogh;our maieste þe maners · of þis man sewe, &YOGH;e myght your realme haue in rist · & other landes wynne. For A[lexander] always · or ony of hys bernes, Nates hym-self in ony nede · & so hys name rysys." . . . . . "Sir, on my perell," quod a prince · "he passes all oþer; Þe wee wyrches all with witte · & worthes ay þe better; For-þi of þe lyon, as I lefe · laght he hys byrth." "What knawez þou þat?" quod þe kyng · & þen þe knyght answers: "Sir, I was send on a sond · my-self on a tyme, To philip hys fader · to feche hys trowage; þar hed I syght of þe segge · hys sapiens I herd. For-þi ples it yowur person · &yogh;our princes assembles, Off medy & of mesopothany · þe men of ytalle, The peple of appolomados · þe peranthez folkez, And mo þen hewen Sic; read houen. to your heystez · a hundreth & fyfty. Let vs gedir to vs our gomez · our goddes wyll vs help; And when he seys vs suche a sowme · sore wyll he drede. &YOGH;a, bot þen a wolfe, quod þe we · wyll wery mony flokkez, And so þe grace of þe grekez · ouergose þe barbres." By þis sir philip son þe fers · of fightand bernes Had semblyd hym a sowme vnsene · & þus says þe text, Two hundreth thousand in thede · all of thro knyghtez. Rydez furth in aray · remewys hys tentes, And thoght to loge þar & rest · & ease hym þat nyght. Vntill a water he wendes · as þe writt shewys, Þat with þe marche-men · of Mocian es haldyn; Clerar þen cristall · & cold as a chyll; And þarin couett þe kyng · hys Cors to be bathyd. With þat þai wan of hys wedez · & wessh hym all ouer, Whar-þorow he hynt suche a harme · þat hetterly hym grefyd. The chele after chawfyng · enchafys so hys harmes, Þat he was fallen in a feuer · or he lest wende. Þen murnyd all þe massydons · as murvell wer ellez. When þai hym sawe so be seke · sayd ichone to oþer: "Be þis disease to sir Dary · & to hys dukez knawyn, He sall vs sett on a-saute · & surely vs Combre." Yff þai wer sory & so · no selly me thynke, For ay þe heylh of þe hede · helpis all þe membrys. Þen callys to hym þe Conquerour · a clerke of hys Awne, On philipp, hys fysycyan · hys fare to byholde; Off all maner of medycine · man þat most kowth, A &yogh;ong berdles The d is above the line . bern · as þe buke tellys, Sayd: "letes lyghtly my lord · for in a lytyll stounde My-self with a Syrope · shall safe you bylyfe." Þen was þar permeon þe prouud · a prince of his hoste, Þat held þe erth of Ermony · & enmyte hed Vnto þis Clerke of þe kengez · & be no cause ellez Bot for þe lede was lofed · & with þe lord cheryst; Þen says he to sir A[lexander] · anone suche a pystyll: "Kepys you," quod he, "Conquerour · & kachez nott hys drynkez; For Darius after hys deth · hys doghter hase hym hyght, And you to sla by som slyght · to seyse hym hys landez." Yitt was þe bern not a beyne · bassyd of hys wordez, He assuryd hym so sadly · þe syroppe he fangez, Þe licour in hys Awne lofe · þe letter in þe toþer, And into philipp face · fast he byholdes. He bad hym drede neuer a dele · bot drynke it Swyth, And þen þe pistyll of þe prince · he put hym in hand. The leche lukyd ouer þe lynes · "my lordyng," he sayd, "I ne am noght gylty of þis · by all þe godes owte!" Als fast was he fyssh-hole · & philip he clepys, Halsys hym full hertly · & of hys heylle thankez, Sayd, "wele knew þou my kynde · þi conscience I lofe, First suppyd of þi syroppe · syne sesyd þe my letter. "My lofely Lord, be &yogh;our leffe · lettes hym apere, The tulke þat suche a trayne · has attachyd to my-seluen." Þen after for permeon hys prince · prestely he sendes, And þar þe trechour was tane · & for hys trayne hated. Þen mevys he forth with hys men · & medy he wynnez Enterly to hys empyre · & Ermonye þe more. To a deserte þen he drof · was dry & no waterez, Throgh andriake to eufraten · & settes þar hys tentes, Here follows —And þe knyghtez of þe coste as þai þe case seghen; but this is l. 2641, out of place . And askez a brigg ouer þe burne · of bargez with chynez; Commandes hys knyghtez ouer to carye · þai hed kokell hertes, Seghen þe streme be so styff · þai stoned þe helder, For lest þe festynyng had faylyd · & þaim þe flude drenchyd. Þen makys laddes ouer to lend · & lokers of bestes, And monyshyd þen iche moderson · þaim manly to sewe. &YOGH;itt wer hys baratours abaist · & þen þe bern wrothed, Foundez first on before · & all folows after. þar passys owt of paradyse · twa brade flomes, Throgh medy & mesopothany · þai mouen, as I fynd, And so to babyloyne þai bowe · þat is þe burne of tigre, Þat oþer is eufrates full euen · rynnez so to Nilus. Þen Cuttes þe kyng in two hys cablys · & to hys knyghtes says: "Lo! þof vs fallys nowe to flee · we may no ferre wend; Þarfore I breke," quod þe berne · "our bakkez neuer to torne, And if we did, withowtyn dome · to dye all at ones; For he þat folows hase þe floure · & he flees neuer. Be light & lachys þou lose · it is a lordez gamme. For I make a-wowe þat massydoyn · shall see vs no more, Tyll all þe barbrens vs bowe · þen Above the line in MS. may we blyth bee."

0.1: Now has ser Darie þe derfe · of dukis & princes Heued vp a hoge ost · & fyue hundreth kni&yogh;tis Ere chosen to chiftans · & chargid þaim to lede; Trottis him on to Tigre MS. Tirgre, corrected to Tigre. · & þare his tentis settis; Þan mett þai on þe oþire morne · with a mekill nombre, Sire Alexander þe hathill · armed on blonkis. Þe multitude ware to me · meruaile to reken, Þat sammed was on aiþir side · many sadd thousand. Now ere þe baners out bred · & þe bate ne&yogh;is, Blew bemys of bras · buskis to-gedire, Þe crie of þe clarions · þe cloudis it persyd; For þe dewt Read dowt. of þe dyn · daunced stedis. Bathe þe twa batails · bremely assemblis, And aithire segg with his sowme · so&yogh;t vn-to vn in the margin . othire. Kni&yogh;tis on cursours · kest þan in fewtire, Taches in-to targetis · tamed þaire brenys. Þare was stomling of stedis · sticking of erles, Sharpe schudering of schote · schering of mailes, So stalworthly within a stond · sterid þaim þe grekis, Þat of þe barb[r]yne blod · all þe fild flowis. Sone as ser Darie þe deth · of his douth sees, Þe pite of þe Persens · him prickis in his saule, Sees his mene&yogh;e so mynesch · & his men fangid, A few þat fresch ware vndefoulid · & to þe fli&yogh;t tournes. &YOGH;it was ane of his ost · ane odd man of strenth, A burly berne & a bald · as þe buke tellis, A segg at he ensurid had · to sese him his do&yogh;tir, If he mi&yogh;t sla with any sle&yogh;t · þe seniour of grece. He cled him all in clene stele · a conyschaunce ouire, Þat made was & merkid · on þe messedone armes, Aires him to ser Alexander · in all-þir-mast puple, As he a hathill ware of his · behind him he stelis, A bri&yogh;t brynnand brand · he braidis out of shethe, And þur&yogh;e-out þe helme in-to þe hede · he hurt him a littill. And þe kni&yogh;tis of oure cost · as þai þe cas sa&yogh;e, Þan fange þai þis ilk freke · & be-fore þe kyng bryngis. "Quat now? my worthi werreours?" · þe wale kyng said, He wend wele at he ware · a wee of his awen, "Qui has þou brest so my brayn · & with a brand wondid &YOGH;our sekire seruant in same · all were I sire callid, All ware I halden as for hede · &yogh;our helpere at nede?" "Nay, hope &yogh;e neuire," quod þe hathil · "ser hi&yogh;e emperoure, Me any Messedone to be · þou ames of þine awen, Bot of cruell kind · comen of barbres. And þis I did for ser Darius · his do&yogh;tir me hi&yogh;t, And cordid on þis condicion · to couple hire to wyfe, And he went out of þe werd · to wild all his regne, To hew þi hede fra þi hals · & anys it him shewe." Þan callis oure kyng him his kni&yogh;tis The first i above the line . · þaire consaile to frayn, "Quat sall be done him for þis dede?" · & þai bedene sware, Sum, at he hangid suld be hi&yogh;e · sum þe hede priued, Sum bedis in a bale-fire · brin him to poudire. "Quat has he fauted?" quod þe frek · "þof he him forced haue Þe charges MS. changs, with stroke above gs. of his chiftan · chefely to fill? He þat him demes to þe dede · he dampnes him-selfe, And di&yogh;tis him his awen dome · & þat dare I proue. For demed I any of my douth · ser darye to spill, As &yogh;e þis gentill man enioyne · suld him be iugid þen." He latis þe Persyn in pesse · pas with his hele, Mekill for his mayn strenth · & for his mi&yogh;t praysed. As sone as Darye þe derfe · of þis dede heris, Þat he was In the margin. sauyd vnslayne · he semblis his kny&yogh;tis, Vp to a mi&yogh;ti montayne · his men þaire he schewis, And gessis him wele þare to degrayd · þe grekis maistir. Þan fandis he furth in-to þe fild · & fled als beliue, And Alexander with his ost · him asperly folowed Ri&yogh;t to þe bu[r]&yogh;e of Batran · & bildid þare his tentis, Mas him glad MS. ginge glad, with ginge struck through. with his ginge · & to his godis offirs. Þe cite þan he assailid · & sesid on þe morne, With all þe bur&yogh;es þare a-boute · & busked þare his sete. Þare fand he tresour vntald · & als þe trew spouse Of ser Dary, bath his dame · & all his dere childire. Now dose him fra Darius · a dereworth prince, Aires to ser Alexander · adoures him lawe, "I haue erdid with &yogh;oure enmy · ser emperoure," he said, "As soiet serued haue I þat sire · many sere wyntir; And all my trauaill I tint · for tuke I no gudes. Bot wald it now &yogh;our worthines · to wend with my-selfe, A ten Mille vs take · of tulkis enarmed, I sall &yogh;ow hete in &yogh;oure hand · to haue at &yogh;oure will Sire Dary, with þe mast dole · of his derfe erles." "Nay, leue, lat ane," quod þe lord · "þen leue I MS. leuē þ e ; with þ e altered to I. no straungers, Þat þou be willi in þi witt · to werray þine awen, Ne tell þou me no&yogh;t þat tale · I trow no&yogh;t þi wordis." Be þis ser Dary fro his dukis · deuysid his pistill: Þe kyng of kyngs was callid · & clere god bathe, Þus, vndirstand I, was þe stile · & sti&yogh;t in þare-eftir: or estir. "&yogh;our satrapaires, &yogh;our seruant · with seruand obeschen; Sire, we haue wayued to &yogh;ow writtis · &yogh;it write we þe same, How þis maistir of Messedone · has on oure marchis entrid, Brynd vp oure biggingis · bretted oure kni&yogh;tis, And we ouire-sett be to sare · to suffire any langire. For-þi &yogh;our dignite bydene · we drerily be-seke, A gayns þe force of oure faa · vs forthire a quile." Quen he had red all þe rawis · for rancour he swellis, And out on-ane to Alexander · all þus he writis. "I, Dary, with þe dignite · þe diademe of Persee, Of all þe kyngis þe kyng · þat corouned was euire, To þe, my seruand, I say · as me was sent late, How þi lawnes & þi litillaike · þou lickyns to my hi&yogh;t. Bot parde, þi prouidence · inpossible it semes, A heuy As to be houyn · vp to þe sternes, A thing threuyn is & thike · & þarnes þe wyngis, And fautis þe fethirhames · & þe fli&yogh;t-loomes. For-þi þi mynd neuir þe mare · lat mounte in-to pride For chance of na cheualry · þat þou a-cheued hase. For vertu ne no victori · ne vant noght þi-selfe; He þat enhansis MS. ens enhansis; with ens expuncted. him to he&yogh;e · þe heldire he declynes. I haue herd of þi hendlaike · of heraudis & of othire, Of þi noblay now o newe time · a-nentes my modire. Bathe to my wyfe & to my barnes · quat bounte þou shewis, Quat curtassy & kyndlaike · I ken alto-gedire. Bot surely all þe seson · þat þou þam so pleses, Þou fangis me neuire to þi frynd · fyne quen þe likis. And if þou wirke þaim all þe wa · & wrak at þou may, Þe mare vnfryndschip þarfore · fall sall þe neuire; For-þi to put þam to pyne · I pray þe no&yogh;t wande, For myn angire on þine arrogance · sall at þe last kindill." . . . . . Quen he Above the line. had lokid ouir þe lines · he la&yogh;es at his wordis, And ditis agayn to ser Dary · þis dete þat folo&yogh;es: ¶ "I, Alexander, þe eldest · & all myne ane Of kyng Ph[ilip] & his fere · þat frely lady, Honourd Olimpades · þat anely me fosterd, To þe kyng of Persy · þis prolouge I write: Sire, vanite & vayne-glori · & vices of pride Þa ere þe gaudis, as I gesse · þat all gods hatis, And ilka dedly douth · þai driffe þam to punesch, Þat has dri&yogh;ten of vndedlynes · dra&yogh;en þaim to name. Þis similitude to þi-selfe · I say all-to-gedire, Þat a-suris so in þi surquitry · & sesis neuire-mare To bost ne to blasfeme · blyn will þou nouthire. Bot for þi gold & þi gudis · a god þou þe makis, Þou vp-braydis me for þe beute · þat I þi blod schewid, As to þi modire I mene · & to þi mery childir, Þare mas þou þe to malicole · & meenes for litill. I wro&yogh;t it noþire for þi will · ne for þi Above the line. wale threte. If I kid þam curtassy · it come fra my-selfe, Haly of oure awen hert · & of oure hynd thewis; Ne we prid vs for na prouwis · predestayned we ere, Oure gods gayn vs þare-to · þat gretly þou spises. Latt now þis lettre be þe last · & loke to þi-selfe, For sekire & on my surement · I seke MS. se slk, blotted, and altered to seke in the margin . &yogh;ow agayns." Þis brefe he bedis þam to bere · þat bro&yogh;t him þe toþire, And takis þam of his tresoure · & twynnes with þaim faire.
