Quen þai to Persy ware past · a pistill he enfourmes, Wrate a writt of his will · so sendis to his princes, His seruandis & his seneschalls · out of sere rewmes, And þus comandis he þam clene · þe kyng his stile. ¶ "I, Alexander, þat as aire · avaunced is in grece, Þe son of Ph[ilip] þe fers · as I first tald, And als of Olimpades · myne honurable modire, Þus send I to my satraparis · my princes & my dukes, My pers out of MS. oft. siphagoyne · salutis & grace, Of þe sele of Surry · my seggis & myn erles, My kni&yogh;tis out of Capados · & all my kid lordis, Þe ledis out of Landace · & all þe landis out-by. I comand &yogh;ow on þe clere faithe · þat &yogh;e my croune a&yogh;e, Þat belyue to Alysaundire · þat is myn awen cite, Þat ilkane of &yogh;ow send be your-selfe · of sere slayn bestis, Of fresch & of fyne wro&yogh;t · fellis a thousand, Sum grayne to be neþire gloues · graythid to my kni&yogh;tis, Sum pured pelloure depurid · to put in oure wedis, Lat kest þam apon camels · þat in þat kith lengis, And aires with þaim to Eufraten · þis erand haues in mynd." Þan was a man, as me mynes · in þe morne-qwile, Was of ser Daris a duke · þe derfe Emperoure, Ane þat Nostanda was named · & a noble prince, Þat certified his souerane · þir sa&yogh;es in a pistill: ¶ "Sire Dari, duke of ilk a douth · & dri&yogh;ten þi-selfe, Þe grete glorius god · graythid in þi 'þi' blotted in MS. trone, Nostanday, to &yogh;our nobilnes · þat ay my nek bowis, With seruage to &yogh;our senurie · my-selfe I comand. It semed no&yogh;t &yogh;oure seruand · sire, vndistreyned Vn-to &yogh;our mekill maieste · þis mater to write, Bot I am depely distressid · þis dede for to wirke, And made þis myscheffe to myn · malegrefe my chekis. For wete it wele &yogh;our worthines · þat of our wale faes crossed through . princes Twa of þe tethiest ere tint · & termynd of lyue, Þat lost was now þe last day · a litill fra Tygre, In batail apon bent fild · in-bland with þe grekis. Þare was I gird to þe grond · & greuously woundid, Vnnethe it cheuyd me þat chance MS. can chance; can struck out. · to chape to þe fli&yogh;t MS. fil&yogh;t. ; And oþire many of oure men · mi&yogh;tfull kni&yogh;tis, And erlis of all &yogh;our empire MS. emperire. · enterely deuydid, &YOGH;oure lore & &yogh;our legaunce · lethirly forsaken, MS. saken forsaken; with saken struck out. Aires þaim to ser Alexander · & on-ane &yogh;eldis. And he þaim faire vndirfange · enfeffid þaim belyue, In palais, in prouince · in principall regnes." Þen to Nostanda on next · þus notis he a lettir, Þat he suld semple him a sowme · & set þaim agaynes. Anothire pistill lete he pas · to Porrus of ynde, To come & helpe with his here · & he In the margin. him þus swaris: ¶ "I, Porrus, þat possessid am · þe partyse of yynde, And am þe coron be kynd · of clene all þat Iles, Sire Dary, with þi dyademe · drest on þi trone, To þe In the margin. þat salutis I send · þe sele of myn armes. Þou prayes vn-to my person · my powere to sempble, And &yogh;ow enforce with my folke · &yogh;our faes to withstand; And I am boun at &yogh;our bode · & buxsom was euire, To he&yogh;e & to help &yogh;our hest · quen I my hele lastis. Bot now a langour me lettis · þat I la&yogh;t haue, Slike a seknes for-sothe · is on my-selfe halden, Þat I ne may streyne me ne stere · for stondis so hard, Bot lyse in langwysches & lokis · quen my lyfe MS. lefe, corrected to lyfe. endis. And as warysche I [of] my warke · þat I am in wonden, As me is wa for þi wo&yogh;e · & þi wrange bathe, I may no&yogh;t ryde &yogh;ow to reschow · my reuthe is þe mare. Bot I sall leue & be lechid · for-þi be li&yogh;t-hertid; And I be couird of my coth · care for na grekis, Amay þe for na Messedoynes · ne men vndire heuen; For I sall hele all in hast · & hale to &yogh;oure kythis With ten legions at þe last · & all of lele kny&yogh;tis." Be þis Rodogars þe riche · þat renewid lady, Þe dere dame of Dari · of þis dede heris, Þat hire awen child with Alexander · amed eft to fe&yogh;t, And sorowis selcuthly sare · & sendis him a pistill; ¶ "To kyng MS. kynd, corrected to kyng. dary MS. 1 dary. þe derfe · þe derrest of my childire, Rodogoras þe riche quene" · þis rauth scho him writis: "Bald baratour on bent · borne of my bosom, Here send I þe, my swete · salutis & ioy. Þou has heuyd vp þi huge ost · as I haue herd tell, Samed all þi saudiours · & semblid þi pupill, And etils to ser Alexander · eft to assaill. Wete þou wele it is no&yogh;t worthe · ware þe be tyme; For had þou gedird all þe gomes · I gesse, of þe werd, &YOGH;it to with-stand him a stonde · þi strenthe ware to littill. For godis prouidence apert · ay prestly him helpis, Sauys & sustenes him-selfe · & socurs him euire. For-þi hoo with þi hautes · & þine vnhemed wittis, A-vaile of þi vanite · & of þi vayne pride, Obey þe to þe baratour · þe best I con rede; Magnifie him with þi mouthe · & meke þi hert, For any hathill vndire heuen · þat at he ne hade may, Mare sekire it ware him to forsake · þen sewe any forthire; In pese & in pacience · possede at he mi&yogh;t, [Þan] Be excludit out of his erd · & euire-mare duell." . . . . . Quen he þis rawis had rede · he rewfully wepid, His eldirs & his ancestris · als he remembris; Þo&yogh;t how pride þaim depriued: · & here a passe ende.

1.1: Nowe hafys sir Dary þe derf · of dukez & princez Hefyd vp a hoge hoste · of fyfe C knyghtez Er chosyn for chyftanes · & chargett þaim to lede; Trottes on to tygre · & þar hys tentes settes; Þen mette þai on þe toþer morne · with a muche nombre, Sir Alexander & hys athell men · armed on þar blonkez. The multitude to me · wer mervell to Reken, Þe[r] sammed was on þat oþer syde · mony sad hundreth. Nowe er þes baners oute brade · & þe bates neghez, Blew bemes of brase · & buskyn to-gedre, Þe cry of þe Clarions · the clodez it persyd; And for doute of þe dynne · dauncen stedes. Both þe two batels · bremly assemble, And seggez with hys soumez · soght vnto oþer. Knytes on þair coursours · kestyn in fewtre, Tachyng into targettes · tamyd þair brynnes. þar was stomblyng of stedes · stykkyng of Erles, Sharpe shoderyng of shote · sheryng of malys, So stalwartly in a stounde · steryn þaim þe grekez, Þat of þe Barbren blode · all þe bent flowez. Sone as sir Dary þe deth · of hys doghty hedys, The pite of þe persyens · hym prikkez in hys sawle, Seys hys meyn&yogh;e so amenyst · & hys men fonged, A ffew þat fresh wer vndefowled · to þe flyght turnes. &YOGH;yt was on wer of hys oste · an odde man of Strenth, A borely berne & a bald · als þe buke tellys, A segge þat he sured hed · to seyse hym hys doghter, Yf he myght slae with ony sleght · þe seneour of grece. He clad hym all in clene stele · a Conyscaunce ouer, Þat mad was & markyd · on massidons armes, Kayres hym to sir A[lexander] · in all þe most prese, Catchword —as he. As he an athell war of hys · b[e]hynd hym he stelez, A bryght brynnand brand · he brade owt of sheth, And þorow þe helme into þe heued · he hurt hym a lytyll. And þe knyghtes of þe coste · as þai þe case sawgh, Þen fange þai þis ilke freke · & byfore þe kyng brynggez. "What nowe? my worthi werayour" · þe wale kyng sayd, He wend þat witterly it were · a wee of hys awne, "Why hase þou bryssyd so my brane · & with a swerd woundet Your sekir seruand in same · all wer I sir clepyd, All wer I haldyn for hede · &yogh;our helpar at nede?" "Nay, hope neuer MS. nereuer. ," quod þe athell · "sir hegh Emperoure, Me ony massydon to be · þou myssys of þi Awne, Bot of þe cruell kynde · Comen of þe barbrys. And þus I dyd, for sir Darius · hys doghter hyght me, And cordytt vnder þis condicion · to coupill hir to wyfe, And qwen he went of þis warld · to weld all hys realme, To hewe þi hede from þi halse · & onys it hym shewe." Now kyng Alexander callys þen hys knyghtes · þair counsell to frayne, "What suld be done hym for þis dede" · & þai bydome Read beden. sone, Some, þat he hanged suld be · & some þe hede pershed, MS. prishyd. Some bydes in a bale-fyre · hym bryn all to poudre. "What hase he fautyd?" quod þe freke · "þof he hym forsyd hafe The charge of hys chiftane · chefely to fylle? He þat hym demys to be dede · he dampnes hym-seluen, And dytes hys awne dome · & þat dar I prefe. For demyd I ony of my doghty · sir dary to spyll, As he is Read &yogh;e this. gentell-man enjoyne · suld hym-self be iugged þen." He lattes þe persen in pes · pas with hys heyle, Mekyll for hys mayne MS. maynte. strenth · & for hys myght doys prayss. Als sone as sir Dary þe derfe · of þis dede herys, Þat he was saffed so vnslayne · he sembles hys kneghtez, Vp tyll a maghty So in MS. mountane · hys men þar he schewez, And gessys hym &yogh;itt degrad · þe grekyn maister. Þen foundez he forth in-to þe feld · & fled als belyfe, And A[lexander] with hys hoste · hym asperly folows Right to þe burgh of batran · & byggyd þar hys tentes, And makez hym glad with hys geng · & to hys goddez offers. Þe Cyte þan he assaylyd · & sesyd it vppon þe morne, With all þe burghes þar aboute · & buskett þar hys sete. MS. fete. þar fand tresour MS. turesour. vntalde · & þe trew spouse O[f] sir Dary, both hys dame · & hys dere chelder. Now doys hym on from Darius · a darworth prince, Kayres hym to alexander · & adours hym lowe, "I haue erdyd with your enmite · sir emperour," he sayd, "As sugett seruyd þat syre · mony sere wynter; And all my travell I tynt · for tuke I no gudez. Bot wald now your worthynes · to wende with my|seluen, And ten thouusand vs take · of tulkez ennarmed, I shall you hete hym in your hand · to haue at your wille Sir Dary, witt þe most dele · of hys derfe Erles." "Na, leyfe, lett be," quod þe lord · "þar leuyn þe no lede, Þat þou be willy in þi witte · to werre þine awne, Na tell þou me not þat tale · I trowe noght þi wordez." By þis sir Dary fro hys dukez · devyse[d] hath a pistyll: The kyng of kyngez he hym cald · & clere god both, Þus, vnderstandyng I, was þe style · & styght in þar-after: "&YOGH;our satrapers, your soueraynte · with seruise obeysshyng; Sir, we haue send to you writtes · &yogh;itt writte we þe same, How þis maister oute of massidoyne · our marches hath enteryd, Brynt vp our biggenges · bryttynd our kneghtez, And we ouersett be so sore · to suffre ony lenger. For whi your dignite bedene · we derely besekyn, Ayayne þe force of our foes · vs furthers a while." When he had rekkend all þe rawes · for rankour he swellez, And oute anone to A[lexander] · all þus he writtez: Epistola. " I, Dary, with þe dignite · þe dyademe of pers, Of all kyngez kyng · þat Crouned was euer, To þe, my seruand, I say · als me was sent late, How þou Read þi. lownys in þi lityllake · þou likens to my hert. Bot parde, þi prouydens MS. peruydens. · inpossible it semys, A hevy asse to heff · on hye to þe sternes, A thyng þat thryffyn is and thyke · & þarnes MS. &yogh;arnes. wengez, And fawtes bath þe fethirhames · & þe flyght-lomes. For-þi mynd neuer þe more · to mounte þe to pryde For chaunce of no chevallry · þat þou chefyd hase. For vertew ne victory · avaunte noght þi-selfe; He þat enhaunses hym to hygh · þe lawer he declines. I haue herd &yogh;it of þi hynlake · at harhaldes & at oþer, O[f] þi noblay nowe anew · anence my awyn modre. Both to my bird & my barnes · qwat bounte þou schewys, What curtasy & hyndlake · I ken all-to-geder. Bot surly all þe seson · þou þaim so ples, Þou fonnges me neuer to þi frend · fyne if þou likez. . . . . . Þe more frendship þarfore · fall shall þe neuer; For-þi put þaim to pyne · I pray þe nogh[t] wonnd, For my angre on þi arrogaunce · sall at þe last kyndyll; Þarfor do þou þi best · god forbyd þou MS. þan, altered to þou. spare." When he lukyd ouer þe lynes · he smyllys at hys wordes, And dytes ayayn to sir Dary · þe deteys þat folows: " I, A[lexander], þe eldest · & all my one Epistola. Of kyng philip & hys fere · þat frelich lady, Honord Olymphades · þat only me fosterd, To þe kyng owte of persye · þis proloug I writte: Sir, vanyte & vaneglory · & vicys of pride Þes er þe gawdes, I ges · þat þees goddes hatez, And iche dedly do · þai dreffe þaim to ponysh, Þat hase dryghten of vndedlynes · drawyn þaim onone. Þis similitude of þi-self · I say all-to-geder, Þat assurys so þi surquidry · & seses neuer more To bost & to blasfleme Read blasfeme. · blyn wyll þou nowþer. Bot for þi gold & þi gudez · a god þou þe makys, Þou vpbardez Read vpbradez. me for þe bewte · þat I þi blude schewyd, As to þi moder I mene · & to þi mery childer, Þou makys þe to malycole · & menys þe for lityll. I wroght it nowder for þi wille · ne for þi wale thoght. Yff I kyd þaim ony curtasy · it Come of my-seluen, Holy of owr awne hert · & of our hend thewys; Na we pride vs for no prowez · predestinate vs here, Our goddes gyffyn vs þar-to · þat grettly þou dispysys. Latt nowe þis letter be last · & luke to þi-seluen, For sekerly withoute surement · I seche þe agayns." Þis brefe he biddes þaim bere · þat broght hym þe toþer, Takys þam of hys tresour · & twynnys with þaim faire. When þai to persye was past · a pistyll he enformes, Wrote a writte of hys wille · & wafed to hys Princez, Hys seruandes & hys senescals · oute of sere landes, And þus Comandes he þaim clene · þe kyng in hys style. " I, A[lexander], þat as heyr · avaunsyd am in grece, Þe son of philipp þe fers · as I first told, And also of Olympades · my honorable lady, Þus send I to my satrapars · salutez of grace, My peres oute of prynphagoyne · my princez & my dukez, Of þe seneour of surry · my seggez & my erlez, My knytes oute of Capadoce · & all my kyd Lordez, The ledes oute of Landace · & all þe Landes vmbe. I command you on þe Clere fayth · þat &yogh;e my crowne awe, Þat als belyfe to alexaunder · vnto my awne Cyte, Ilk one send be þaim-self · of sere slayn bestes, Off fresh & of fyne slayn · fellys a thouusand, Some grayne to be grathyd · to my bernez byhofe, Some puryd pelour & depuryd · to put in our wedes, And cast þaim vppon camels · þat in þat kyth lenges, And karys with þaim to eufraten · þis erand haue in mynd." Þe[n] was a man, as me of menys · in þe morne-while, Was of sir Daryus a duke · þe derf emperoure, One þat Nostandy was namyd · a noble Prince, Þat certyfyed hys souerente · þees sawez in a pistill: " Syre The e is above the line in MS. Dary, duke of iche douth MS. Syre duke of a Dary iche douth; with a above the line. · drightyn þi-seluen, Epistola. The grete glorius god · grathyd in þi trone, Nostandy, to your nobelnes · & ay my neke bowe, With seruage to your senyoury · my-seluen I Comaund. It semyd not your seruand · [syre], vndistreynyd Vnto your mekyll mageste · þees materys to writte, Bot I am depely distryssyd · þis dede for to wirke, And made þis mischeff to mene · mawgre MS. mawgra. my chekez. For wete it wele &yogh;our worthynes · þat of our wale princez Two of þe tithiest er tynt · & termyd of lyfe, Þat lost wer nowe þe last day · a lityll fro tygre, In batell on bent feld · in-bland with þe grekez. þar was I girde to þe ground · & greuously woundit, Vnneth me chefyd in þat chaunce · to chape to þe flyght; And oþer mony of owr men · mightfull knyghtes, And erls of our empire · enterely distroed, Þat oþer your legeance · lethirly forsakyn, Karyn þaim to sir A[lexander] · & onone &yogh;elden. And he þaim fair vnderfongez · & feffys þaim in Landes, In palacys, in prouynce · & principall regnes." Then to Nostady on next · notez he a letter, Epistola. Þat he suld semble hym a sowme · & sett þam agayns. A-noþer pistell lete he passe · to porrus of Inde, To Come & help with hys heer · & he hym þus aunswers: " I, Porrus, þat possessyd am · þe partyes of Inde, And am þe crowne by kend · clene of all þe yles, Sir Dary, with þi diademe · dressyd in þi trone, To þe with salutes I send · þe sealle of my Armez. You pray vnto my person · my power to assemble, And you enforce with my folke · &yogh;our foes to withstond; I am bowne at þi bode · & buxme was euer, To hye & to helpe at &yogh;our hest · whils my hele Lastes. Bott nowe a langor me lettes · þat I laght haue, . . . . . Þat I may strene me ne stirre · for stoundes þat I haue, Bott lyse & lukes lang · when my lyfe endes. And as euer I warysh of werk · þat I am woundit in, As me es wo for þi wogh · & þi wrange both, I may not ryde you to rescew · þe reuth is þe more. Bott I shall lefe & be lightyd · þarfore be &yogh;e light; And be I couered of my cothe · kare for no grekys, Remefe you for no massydons · ne man vppon erth; For I sall hele all in hast · & hye to your kythez With ten legions at þe lest · & all of lele knyghtes." Be þat Rodogors þe ryche · þe reuerent Lady, The dere dame of Dary · of þis dede herys, Þat hir Awne Childe with A[lexander] · etlyd &yogh;itte to fight, And sorows selkouthly sore · & sendes hym a pistyll; " To kyng Dary þe derf · þe derrest of hir childer, Rodogors þe riche whene" · þus rathe scho hym writtes: "Bald baratour on bent · berne of my-seluen, Here send I þe, my swete · salutes of Ioy. Þou hase hefyd vpp þi hoge hoste · as I haue late herd, Sammyd all þi sougeours · & semblyd þi peple, And ettlys þe sir Alexander · efte to assayle. Bott wete þou wele it is not worth · & were ye be tyme; For hed þou gedderyd all þe gomez · I gesse, in þe werld, To withstond hym a stoure · þi strenth wer to lityll. For goddes prouydence a-pert · ay prestly hym helpys, Saffys & socours hym-self · & sustayns hym euer. For-þi hoo with þi hatness · & þi vn-hemmyd wittes, Avale of þi vanyte · & of þi vayn pride, Obey ye to þis baratour · þe best I can rede; Magnyfye hym with þi mouth · & mekyn þi hert, For ony hatell vnder heuen · for power þai haue may, More sekir þai wer to forsake · & sewe ony forþer; In pease & in pacience · possede þat he myght, Þen be exclud oute of hys erth · & neuer in ease dwell." Sir Dary for þoo dytez · was deply diseassyd; When he þoo rawez had redde · rewfully he wepys, Hys alders & hys auncesters · als he remenbrys; Thoght how pride þaim depriffyd · & here a passe endes.

0.1: Þen aires him on ser Alexander · furth with his princes, To þe cite-ward of Susys · him-selfe he aproches. Þare-in ser Darius duellid · with his derfe ostis, So ne&yogh;e he come to þa cliffis · he kend ouire þe cite. With þat comaunds he he[s] kni&yogh;tis · to cutt doune belyue Bowis of buskis & of braunches · of bolis & of lindes, And bynde to þaire hors feete · of bobis of herbis, Bath to Meeris & to mulis · & all maner of bestis. Þe popill out of Persy · þat slike a pake sa&yogh;e, Beheld on he to þe hillis · & heterly was stroub[l]id; Þai ware so woundird of þat werke · & wetirly it semed As all þe grond & þe greues · had glid þaim agayns. So ne&yogh;e þe cite he so&yogh;t · & sett vp his tentis, Þat thre days to þat thede · him tharne & na mare. Said: "let ane dryue to MS. & to; with & subpuncted . Dary · & bede him dryffe sone, Or put him to my powere · & plede we na langire." Þe same ni&yogh;t in his slepe · him soda[n]ly a-perid Amon, his awen god · in aung[e]ls wyse, In a mery mantill · of mervailous hewis, Meuand as a Messedone MS. Messedono. · in Marcure fourme; Said: "vn-to Susys my son · na sandisman þou send, Bot fange my fygour to þe fast · & fand furth þi-selfe, Clethe þe with my conyschaunce · & for na care drede, I hete þe haly my help · na harme sall þou suffire." Þan slade he sli&yogh;ly a-way · & he fra slepe ryse, A breme blasand blis · in his brist rysys. He knew his kni&yogh;tis þat cas · & þai him clene redd, Þat he In the margin . suld graythe him to ga In the margin . · as him his god chargis. Þan callis to him þis conquirour · ane of his kid prince[s], Emynelaus, þat his erlis · & his ost In the margin . ledes, Hend & hardy of his hand · a huge man of strenthe, And þare-to lede lelist to his lord · leuand of lyue. He bad him boun him belyue · & on a blonk worth, Anoþire foole with him fange · & founde with himselfe. Strad vp him-selfe on a stede · in starand wedis, And on a cursoure þe kni&yogh;t · with MS. on with; on being struck through . a collt folo&yogh;es. To þe grete flode of Granton · to-gedire þai ride, Þai fand it forsen þaim be-fore · a fote-thike yse. Þat is þe streme of Strama · with many steds clepid, And &yogh;it þe pure propure name · in percynne tonge. Þan Alexander belyue · his wedes he changis, Þis renke with his Ronsees · he ridis ouire & leuys. "A! lat me lend with &yogh;ow, lord" · þe lede MS. bede. him besekis, "For drede þat angire or a-ventour · or any slike fall." "Nay, houe þou here," quod þe kyng · "vn-to my hame-come. He þat I saw in my slepe · sall be my sekire helpe." With þat he braides on þe blonke · & broches him in þe syd, Bowis him to-ward þe bur&yogh;e · as bri&yogh;t as ane aungell. ¶ Þis reuere at I first rede · be rewle of his kynde, As wele in seson of Somere · as in þe sad wintre, And þat is neuer bot on ni&yogh;tis · so naytely it fresys, Till any powere to pas · or preke on with stedis. &YOGH;it has þe floum, as I fynd · a forelange obrede, And euire-ilke mornyng it meltis · for mi&yogh;t of þe son; With slike a reryd þan it rynnes MS. remes, corrected to rynnes. · þe romance it witnes, Þat qua so tuke it in þat tyme · tint ware for euire. Be þis enproched him oure prince · vn-to þe proude cite, Band his blonke at a barrere · with-out þe bur&yogh;e &yogh;atis. Þe Persyns of his passag · was passyngly wondird, And gesses him to be gode · for glori of his wedis. "Quat dones man ert þou?" quod Dary · & drafe him agayne. "Sire Alexander," quod þis athill · "has all þus me sent, Bedis buske þe to batell · quat bade makis þou here? Outhire &yogh;are þe &yogh;apely þar-to · or till his &yogh;okke bowe." "Qweþire þu be he?" quod þe hathill · "so hately þou spekis, Þou melis no&yogh;t as a minister · a messangere bowis; Þou carpis euyn as a In the margin. kyng · þat closid ware in pride. Bot I am dred neuire a dele · of all þi bald sa&yogh;es. Bot for þi souerayne sake · þat sent þe þus hedire, &YOGH;it sall þou sit with my-selfe · & soupe or þou wynde." He ra&yogh;t him þan be þe arme · & reuerence MS. reuercence. him makis, And to his palais a-pert · with princes him ledis, Þare aires him in ser Alexander · & all þus he thinkis, "Þis ilke bar-bryn berne · grete beute me schewys, Þat here þus hyndly be þe hand · ledis to his Innes; Þis hame with help of my god · I haue sall he[r]|eftir." So silis he furth with þe sire · in-to a somere-hall, Þare sesonde was a soper · þe sotelest vndire heuen. Sire Darius drawis to þe dese · & oþir dere princes, Settis þis sire with him-selfe · lete serue þaim to-gedire. Þat bild was all of brynt gold · as þe buke tellis, With þe bath, þe bordis & þe benkes · beten of þat ilke. Þe wessell to vyse on · was verraly þe same, And all þe sale of a MS. same a; with same struck through. sute · set full of stanes. Þe popill of Persy · opon þis prince waitis, Þe litillaike of his like · lathely þat þai spyse; Bot þe wisedome & þe worthenes · & of þe wale thewis Þat in þat cors was enclosed · kend þai full litill. Butlers full besyly · bro&yogh;t vp þe wyne, In grete gobletis of gold · graythid full of &yogh;ymmes; And Alexander belyue · as he In the margin . had ay dronken, With þat he clekis vp þe coupe · & putis in his bosom. Anoþire boll was him bro&yogh;t · & bathe he deuoydid, And &yogh;it he threw to þe thrid · & thrast in þare-eftir. Sone as þe MS. as a þe. clientis þat knew · at of þe coupe serued, Þai knele doun before þe kyng · & him þe cas tald. Þan has ser Dary dedeyne · & derfely he lokes, Rysys him vp renysch · & re&yogh;t in his sete, "Quat faris þou with," quod he, "frynde? · a fon þe besemes; Quy voydis þou my vessell? · it is a vile schame." "Sire, it is þe custum," quod þe kni&yogh;t · "in oure kyngis fest, Þat, be it ane, be it oþire · þat þai of drinke, Þe gestis sall haue þe goblettis · & þaim gud þinke, To wild & wende with a-way · & wirke quat þaim likes; Bot sen þis vse is here vn-honourable · here I þam leue;" Braidis þaim furth withouten bade · þe butlers þaim yeldis. "Now sothely," quod þan ilk a segge · softly to-gedire, "Þis maner at he melis of · is menskefull & noble." Þan was þare ane proude pere · a prince at þe table, Anepo, þat on Alexander · all-way be-haldis, Þan mynes him anes in Messedone · he had þe man sene, Quen he was sent to his syre · to feche þaire trouage. His vertuse & his vysage · his voise he remenbris, His fourme & his fetoure MS. fetuore. · his figoure a-vysis, He studis & he stuynes · he stemes with-in, "Is þis no&yogh;t Philip son þe firs · þe fedare of grece?" With þat he sle&yogh;ly vp so&yogh;t · & his sete leuys, Dro&yogh;e him euyn to ser Dary · þare he on dese bydis, Said, "surely, ser, þis sandisman · þat sittis &yogh;ow be-forne Is Alexander him awen self · or all myn ame faillis." Sone þis gouernour of grece · is of þis gaude ware, He torkans with & vndire-tuke · he touched of him-selfe, Herd a nyngkiling of his name · & naytis him to ryse, Buskis him vp at a braide · & fra þe burde rysys. He tas a torche fia a tulke · þat by þe table standis, Felly fangis it in MS. l in; the l being an imperfect h, due to his following. his fist · & to his fole wyndis, Fyndis him faire him before · þare he him feste hade, Ra&yogh;t him radly þe reyne · & on his rige worthis. With þat he brochis his blonke · þat þe blode fames, Sparis out spacly · as sparke out of gledes. Be þe li&yogh;t at he led · laches he þe way, And fandis fast to þe fli&yogh;t · with a fers will. Þe pepill of þe palais · quen þai his passe sa&yogh;e, Rusches vp in a res · rynnes in-to chambres, Sum araies þaim in ringis · & sum in row brenys, . . . . . With hard hattis on þaire hedis · hied to þaire horsis, Prekis eftir þe prince · prestly enarmed. MS. enr enarmed; with enr struck through . Bot now was ni&yogh;t on þam ne&yogh;ed · þat noyd þaim sare. Sone ware þai willid fra þe way · þe wod was so thike, Sum on bu&yogh;es & on brerys · blemysched þe face, Sum ware dreuyn doun in dikis · sum in depe myrys; Bot Alexander at myn ame · þaire a&yogh;e is a-schapid, Ay trottis him to þe trod-gate · as him þe torche wyssis. Sire Dary as a drery man · duellis The e above the line . at hame, With princes in his palais · all pense he sittis, Þe baldnes of þis baratour · he besyly remembris, Þat skapid so sone skatheles · fra all his schathill dukis. Þan was an ymage within · as I am enfourmede, Of Sexeres þat sum-quyle · þat cite had to welde, MS. &yogh; welde. Forgid all of fyne gold · & fettild [in] his seete; Vndire þe souerayne sege · þare sett ere þe lawis. And sodanly þat semylacre · as tellis þe textis, It all to-paschis in-to peces · & to poudire dryuys. Þan was þe wale kyng waa · & wepand he said: "Þis be-takens trombling of my tild · & tene of In the margin . my regne." And Alexander all þat quile · asperly rydis To þe grete flode of Granton · & it on a glace fyndis. Or he was so&yogh;t to þe side · &yogh;it sondird þe qweryns, His hors it hunyschist for euire · & he with hard schapid. Þan aires he with Emynelows · euen to his princes, And derfly on þe toþir day · a douth he assembles, Twa hundreth thousand on a throm · all of threuen kni&yogh;tis, Cairis him vp to a cliffe · & comfurthis his hostis; "Sall neuir þe Persyns pake · be pere to þe grekis, And if þai ma ware be many · mayes no&yogh;t &yogh;our hertis; Full many flees may fell · bot a fewe waspis." And all þe company clene · comendid his wittis.

1.1: Fast kayrez hym on sir A[lexander] · with hys athell princez, To þe cyte-ward of susys · hym-self he aproched. þar as sir Dary in dwellyd · with hys derfe hostes, So negh he Come þe clyffe · he kend ouer þe cyte. With þat he Commandes hys knytes · to cutte downe be-lyffe Þe bowes & þe bobbez & braunches · of bulesse & of lyndez, And bynd vnto þair blonnkez fete · of buskez & erbes, Both to merys & to mulez · & all maner of bestes. The peple oute of persye · þat suche a pake seghen, Byheld on high to þe hyllez · & hetterly wer stourbed; Þai wer son wondderytt of þat werke · þat witterly þam semyd As all þe ground & þe gravez · had gane þaim ayayns. So negh þe Cyte he þame soght · & sett vp hys tentes, Þat thre days to þat thede · he tharnyd & no more. Sayd: "latt on dryfe to sir Dary · latt drysse hym to feght, Or put hym to my power · & plete we no lenger." Þe same nyght in hys slepe · to hym sodanly aperyd Nota sompnium Alexandri. Amoyn, hys awne god · in angels wyse, In A mery mantyll · of mervalous hewys, Meuand as a massydon · in mercurius forme; And sayd: "vnto Susys · no Sondesman þou wafe, Bott fonge þi figour to þe fast · & fonde furth þi-seluen, Cleth þe with my Conysaunce · & for no care dred, I hete þe holy my help · no harme sall þou hynte." Þe[n] slode he slyghtly away · when he fra slepe rysys, A breme blasand blysse · in hys hert kyndels. Be-knewe hys knyghtes of hys case · & þai hym clene redyn, Þat he shuld grath hym to go · as hys god chargyd. Þen callys to hym þe conquerour · one of hys kyd princez, Emenylaus, þat hys Erlez · & hys hoste ledes, Hende & hardy of hys hand · & hoge man of strenth, And þarto lelyst to hys lord · of all ledes oute. He bad hym bowne hym belyfe · & on a blonke worth, Anoþer fole with hym fange · & found with hym-selfe. Strode hym-self vp on a stede · in a starand wede, And on a cou[r]sour þe knyght · with a colt folowd. To þe grete flode of gratun · to-geder þai ryddyn, And fyndyn it frosyn þaim byfore · a fute-thyke ysyd. Thys is þe streme of Struma · with mony stedes clepyd, And &yogh;it pure propre name · in persyens tounge. Then A[lexander] als belyfe · hys abytt chaungez, Thys renke with hys rounsey · he rydes ouer & lefys. "Na! latt me lend with þe, lord" · þe lede hym bysekys, "Lest anger or aventur · or ony suche falle." "Nay hofe þou here," quod þe athyll · "vnto my agayn|Come; He þat I seght in my slepe · shall me sekir helpe." With þat he brades on hys blonnke · & brochez hym in þe sydes, Bowys hym on toward þe burgh · als bright as an angell. Thys reuer þat I first rede of · be rewle of hys kynde, Als wele in seasun of somer · as in þe sad wynter, And þat is neuer bott of nyghtys · so nataly it fresys, To ony power on to passe · or preke with a stede. &YOGH;it hase þe flode, as I fynd · a furelenth of brede, Nota naturam aque de struma. And euerilke mornyng it meltes · for myght of þe son; With suche a rerde þen it rynnys · þe Romayns it wittnes, Þat who tuke it in þat tyme · war termyd for euer. Be þis aprochyd hym þe Prince · vnto þe prouude Cite, band hys blonnke at a barre · withoute þe brode &yogh;atez. The persyens of hys passage · wer passandly wounderyd, And gessyn hym all to be god · for glory of hys gere. "What domesman art þou?" quod Dary · & drofe hym ayayns. "Sir A[lexander]," quod þis athell · "hase all þus me send, Byddes þe to batell buske · what bode mase þou here? Ouder &yogh;are þe &yogh;apely þarto · or to his &yogh;okke bowe." "Wheder þou be he?" þe hathell sayd, · "so hetterly þou spekez, Þou melles noght as a messenger · a mynyster bowez; Þou Carpys likar to A kyng · þat Closyd wer in pride. Bot I am dred neuer a dele · of all þi derfe sawez, &YOGH;itt for þi souerand sake · þat send þe þus hyder, Þou shall sitt with my-self · & soupe or þou wende." He raght hym by þe right harme · & reuerens hym makys, And to hys palays full pert · with princez hym ledes, Þar kayres hym on Sir A[lexander] · & all þus he thynkez, "Þus ilke barberen berne · grete bewte me schewez, Þat here þus hyndly be hand · hase lede me to Innes; Thys home MS. holme; but marked for correction. with helpe of my goddez · I hafe sall her|after." So sylez forth with þis Sire · into a somer-halle, Thar sesund was a soper · þe sotellest vnder heuen. Sir Darius drawys to þe deyse · & oþer dere princez, Settes þis sire with hym-selfe · lete serue þaim to-geder. Þat belde was all of brynt gold · as þe buke tellys, With both þe burdez & þe benche · betyn of þe same. The vessell to vyse on · veraly of þe same, And all þe sale of a sute · sett full of Stanes. The peple oute of persey · apon þe prince waytyn, Þe lityllayke of hys lyth · lothly þai spysyn; Bot þe wysdome & þe worthines · of hys wale thewe&yogh; Þat in þat cors was closyd · knew þai full lytyll. Botlers full besely · broght vp þe wynez, In grete goblettes of gold · grathyd fulle of gemmys; And A[lexander] als belyfe · as he hed onys drunkyn, With þat he clyght vp a cupe · & cromys in hys bosom. Anoþer boll was hym broght · & both he devoyded, MS. dovoydede. And &yogh;itt he threwe The h is above the line in MS to þe thryde · & thristyn þar-after. Sone as þe clyentez it knew · þat of þe cope serued, Þai knele downe bifore þe kyng · & hym þe case taldyn. Þen hase sir Dary disdayne · & darfly he lukes, Rerys hym vpp & remevys · in hys sete riche, "What farys with," quod he, "frende? · a fonne þou be|semys; Whi woydes þou my veseall? · it is a vyle schame." "Sir, it is our costome," quod þe knyt · "in our kyngez fest, Þat, be it one, be it oþer · þat þai of drynkyn, The gestes sall haue þe goblettez · & þai gude thynke, To wyld & wynd away · & werke what þaim likez; Bot sen þe vse is here vn-honorable · here I þam lefe;" Brades þam forth with-owtyn bode · þe butler þaim &yogh;eldes. "Nowe, sir," quod euerilke segge · softly to oþer, "Þis maner þat he mellys of · is menskefull & noble." Then was þar one, a prouude · prince at þe tabyll, Anepo, þat on Alexander · alway byholdes, Þen menys onys in massydon · he had þe man knawyn, When he was sent be hys sire · to sese þair truage. Hys vertuez & hys visage · hys voyce he remenbris, Hys forme & hys facion · hys fygure he visys, He stodes & he staddes with · & stempmys hym within, "Es noght þis philyp son þe fers · fennder MS. founder, altered to fennder. of grece?" With þat he shyllghly vp slayde · & hys sete left, Droght hym euen to sir Dary · þar he on deyse bydes, "Þat surely sir, þis sondesman · þat sittes yow aforne Is A[lexander] hym-self · or all my ame falys." Sone as þis gouernour of grece · apon þis gaud MS. gauyd. wates, He torkys with & vndertuke · it tochyd of hym-self, Harde a nyckyng of hys name · & natys hym to ryse, Buskys hym vp at brade · & fro þe borde voydes. He takys a torche fro a tulke · þat be þe burde standes, Felly fange it in hys fyst · & to hys fole wendes, Fyndes hym faire hym bifore · þar as he hym fest had, Raght hym radly þe reyne · & on hys rigge ascendes. With þat he brochez hys blonnke · þat þe blode folows, Sparrys oute sarply Sic; for spacly. · as MS. &. sparke doys on gledes. By þe light þat he hed · lacchys on hys way, And fonndez fast to flyght · with a fers wille. The peple of þe palays · when þai hym passe sigh, Þai russhyn vp in a reys · rynnyn into chaumbres, Some arays þaim in rynggez · some in rawe brenys, Some in stalwart stuffe · & some in stele plates With hard hattes on þair heddez · hyen to þair blonnkez, Prikkyn after þe prince · prestly ennarmed. Bot þen was nyght on þaim negh · þat noyed þaim sore. Sone wer þai welt fro þaire way · þe wod was so thykke, Some of bowez & of breres · blemyst þe face, Some wer drefyn into dykez · some depe mires; Bot A[lexander] at my ayme · þar augerly eschapys, And ay trotes on þe troyde-gate · als hym þe torche vysys. Sir Dary as a drery man · dwelland in hys trone, With princez in hys palays · all pensey he sittes, The baldnes of þis baratour · he belyfe remenbris, Þat scapett so sone schatheles · fro all hys schatell dukez. Þen was ane ymage within · as I am enformed, Off serexies þat some-while · þe Cyte hed to weld, Forgyd all of fyne gold · & feteld in hys sete, MS. fete. And vnder þat souerent segge · y-sett war þair lawez. And sodanly þat symylacre · as says me þe text, All to-paschys into peces · & into powder dryfez. Þen was þe wale kyng woo · & wepand he sayd: "Þis betokyns trublyng of my teld · & tene to my realme." And A[lexander] þe while · asperly rydes To þe grete flude of grantum · & it as glas fyndes. And be he soght to þe syde · &yogh;itt sounderd þe qwernes, Hys hors it honyshyd for euer · & he with hard schapyd. Þen kayres he with Emenylaus · euen to hys princez, And derfly of þat oþer day · of doghty he assemblez, Twa C M in a thrume · all of trefe knytes, Cayrez hym vp to a Clyff · & comforthez hys hostez; "Sall neuer þe persiens pakke · be pere to þe grekez, And þof þai war mo be mony · mayse nott in hertes; Full fele fleys may nott felle · bott a few wasspez." And all þe Company clene · Comendyd þan hys wittes.

0.1: Be þis ser Dary was di&yogh;t · whit his dere erles, Heuyd vp a huge ost · & hast him to ryde, His ginge & all his garysons · in glyssynand wedis, Gaes him on to granton · & graithes þare his tentis. His stoure was so stalworthe & store · & strange to a-byde, He had of men out of mynde · many mayn hundreth, Þat sike a si&yogh;t & a sowme The me above the line . · of seggis enarmed Was neuer sene, I suppose · sen þe sege of troy. Þe chiftayne had chariotis · chosen for þe nanes, Ten thousand be tale · tried for þe were. And þai ware sett aþire side · full of sythe-bladis, Kene keruand as knyfes · & cursers þam drowe. Þe next day be þe none · new note ryses, Aithire freke with his folke · in þe fild metis, And bald bernes on bent · banars vnfaldis, Put pennons on pollis · payntid of siluir. Alexander as belyue · is armed vp clene, Bounes him to his blonke · þe best vndire heuen, Þat was þe blonk Bucifal · as þe buke tellis, A foole worth MS. with, altered to worth in the margin . fyfty of þe firste · þat in þe flode drouned. He spynnes him out a grete space · fra he[s] peris all, Couers him full clenly · & closed in his gere. Þe powere out of Persy · quen þay þe prince sa&yogh;e, Frayed was of his fourme · so ferdfull him semed. ¶ Now ere þe batails boune · with braggins in trumpis, Þe breme bemen blaste · beres to þe welken. Alexander allþire first · on þaim all In the margin . he settis, And aithire ward In the margin . at a wapp · wi&yogh;tly inIoynes. Archars & all men · asperly fi&yogh;tis, Þare was Iusting o Ioy · Iopons a-tamed; Siles doun on aithire side · selcuth kni&yogh;tis, Sum darid, sum dede · sum depe wondid. So fell MS. felle felle. fli&yogh;t was of flanys · as I fynd wreten, Of arrows & of all quat · þat all þe aire blindid; Hogere on to be-hald · þan of MS. oerf. haile-stanes, And all þe fild full of folke · fyue mile large. Als sone as þe son vp so&yogh;t · þe sla&yogh;tere begynnes, And so to þe son-sett · slakid þai neuire. Be þat þe barbryne blode · be-gan to discende, Þe proudest of þe Persyns · past out MS. ont. of lyue. Sone as ser Dary it deuysid · & se&yogh;is his foke faile, With þat he bedis þam MS. þam þaim. þe bake · & bidis na langir; Þen quen þai MS. þaim. fange to &yogh;e fli&yogh;t · was furth in with euyn, And mirke out MS. ont. of mesure · na man þaim a-pered. For-þi þe chariotis in þe chace · choppid þaim to deth, Þe cartis þat I carpid of · with þe kene sythis, Þare fell as fele þam before · of fotemen & othire, As risonis Or risoms, or risoins. in a ranke fild · quen riders it spillen. Sire Dary dryue in þe derke · & his douth folows, Gaes him on to grantun · vn-to þe grete burne, Fand it frosen him before · as fell for þe time, Past him on with his pers · a pake out of nombre. His folke fellis all þe flode · a forelange o brede, Þe streme fra þe a strande · stre&yogh;t to þat othire. Sone fra him-self was at þe side · it sonders behind, And all at lent ware on-loft · loste þar þe swete. Þus many deed þat day · as þe buke tellis, Of pollis out of Persye · withouten þe grekis, Thre hundreth Mille thra men · þat tharned MS. thrarned. þaire lyues, With þe fooles & þe folke · þat þe flode drouned. Þis senioure out of Susys · to his cite wendis, Fallis doun on his face · flat in þe sale, "Wa is me!" quod he, "wriche · wa is me vnhappy!" Si&yogh;is selcuthely sare · & sadly he wepys, "I þat was stra&yogh;t to þe sternes MS. stremes. · am streken now to grond, Now craton, now caitefe · now am I kast vndire, Þat had of the Orient all ouire · homage vmqwile. Wist any we quat him suld worth · þis werd wald he leue, Full sympill in a seteqwile · seke to þe cloudes, And þai at mast ere of mi&yogh;t · smyten all to poudire." With MS. þat with; þat struck out . þat reufully he rase · & renkis out he sendis, To Alexander belyue · & all slike a pistill. ¶ "I, drery kynge on my dese · Darius of Persy, To Alexander þat Aire · þat all has to wild, Þe lege lord of my lyfe · to lose or to saue, Þus send I to my souerayne · salutis & ioy. So wyde is þe wisdom · þat wonne[s] in &yogh;our saule, Þat wele &yogh;e wate, of all men · at I worthid here before, Ye are wise. Of all þe notis þat ere now · & quat on next sewes. For-þi &yogh;our werke ay be witt · &yogh;e wirke vnreproued. Sire, I knawlage me a creatour · & come of a woman, Heues no&yogh;t &yogh;our hert vp to hi&yogh;e · take hede to &yogh;our end; It limps no&yogh;t all-way þe last · to licken with þe first, Quat suld a kni&yogh;t mare to kepe · bot conquire his enmy? Was no&yogh;t Sexes him-selfe · þe souereynest in erth, And cheued him of cheualry · chekis out of nombre? &YOGH;it for his will out of worde · was won in-to pride, In þe lede here of Elanda · lithirly he feyned. Þinke þat allanely of god · þis ouirlaike þou haues, For-þi haue mercy on þi men · þi meche we MS. de. beseke, Als of &yogh;oure grete gudnes · to grant vs oure modire, Oure bride, oure barnes out of bande · for besandis eno&yogh;e, For all þe feete MS. fadirs feete; with fadirs struck out . at oure fadirs · in þe fold MS. fuld, corrected to fold. hade, In Battri & in þis bild · þe bur&yogh;e of Elanda, Þe maistri & þe maieste · of Mede & of Persy, With all þe Iolyte & MS. & oi; oi struck out . Ioy · þat Iubiter vs lenes." Þe seggis at fra Susses · was sent with þe pistill Aires to ser Alexander · onone hit MS. it hit. him reches; And he dos on before his ost · openly to rede, And all his kni&yogh;tis for þe carpe · ware kenely reioysed. Þen was ane Permeon, a pere · a prince of his oste, Enclynes him doun to þe kyng · said: "kid emperoure, Resayue þis risches, I rede · þat &yogh;ow þis renke bedis, And lyuers him his ladis · & all his lele childire." Þan Alexander belyue · þa hathels he callis, Þe berne at bro&yogh;t MS. bor&yogh;t. him þe brefe · said: "bowis to &yogh;our lord, And say, In the margin . me wondirs, I-wisse · if he it wete wald, For any mede a-pon mold · his meneyhe to lyuire? If he be fallen vndire fote · & his folke streyned, And vencust of oure violence · quat vailis him his hestis? His person & his prouynce · he put it in my will, And &yogh;eld him vndire my &yogh;oke · þan &yogh;erne I na mare. And if [he] grant him no&yogh;t de-grayd · bot for þe gre threpis, Bid buske him eft to þe bent · vs bataill to &yogh;eld." Þus monest he þe messangers · þaire maistir to say, Geuys þam giftis full gude · & lete þam ga swyth. And þan comands he his kni&yogh;tis · þe corses vp to gedire, Of all þe douth at was dede · & di&yogh;t þam in graues. And at wondid was, I-wis · as þe writt tellis, To serche þaire saluys & þar saris · with surgens noble. At þe grete flode of Granton · now graythis he his tentis, Honoured þare his ald MS. h ald. gods · & offirs þam nouches; Þare fand he palais vp pi&yogh;t · & many proud hames, Sum-quile of Sexes ware sett · þe sire of þo landis. Þa bildis he bedis þam to brin · sone of his bone rewis, And bad na beren be sa bald · a brand for to kyndill. Þare was a brade bent fild · was beried full of kni&yogh;tis, Of ald peres out of Persy · prince & dukes. Þe Messedones in þe mold · mynes to þe graues, Fand coupis all of clene gold · & costious stanes, Þe sepulture of a sire · þat of Surre was kyng. Him was þe name Ninus · was in a noke fonden, Was of ane athill amatist · & all within with is in the margin . grauen, Plantid full of palmetres · & many proud fowles, And slike a clerete it kest · þu[r]&yogh;e kynd of it-selfe, Þai MS. þ t . mi&yogh;t haue kend without þe kist · þe corps all|to-gedire. Þare was a tenefull toure · & tulkis in-closid; Sum ware þe handis of hewen · & sum wondid ho&yogh;es, Sum þe e&yogh;en, sum þe eres · & egirly cries On Alexander eftir help · & he þam all liuers. He wepis on þam for wa · said, "wa is me, my childire!" And ilkane of his talentis · he takis ten thousand. Þus ware þai di&yogh;t of ser Dary · for he dedeyne hade, þat þai MS. þat, corrected to þai. ware comen doun of kyngis · & be no cause ellis. Be now þe douth of ser Daris · þe derfe messangere Fra Alexander agayn · his answare him bro&yogh;t; And he þan girdis out to grete · eft graythis him to fy&yogh;t, To þe honoryd here out of ynde · þus ordans a pistill. "Þat þe sceptoure & þe soile · sesid am of Persy, To Porrus vndire my present · plesance & ioy. First wrate I to &yogh;our worthines · &yogh;it write I þe same, To help vs at þire hathill men · þat haue þat haue in the margin . wald my regne, And, be &yogh;e sure, þe same way · is to &yogh;our-self ettild. For he þat werrais vs with · þe wildare of grece, Is wrawid & wrathfull of will · & wode as a lyon, . . . . . And if I sande men & sammen · seggis out of nombre, And cokke with þe conquirour · till I be cald drepid, &YOGH;it me is better on þe bent · in bataile be slayne, Þan se þe lose of my ledis · & ay leue in sorowe. For-þi &yogh;oure lordschip as legeman · I lawly be-seke, As I þat am in angwisch · myne askyng to fill; Ten schilling of my trew gold · a man þat is armed, And fyue to a fote-man · faithely I hete. &YOGH;it sall I ordane to &yogh;our ane · quare-euire oure ost liggis, A ix score of new geere · of nurtrid maydens. Bucifalon þe bald stede · sall bathe be oure awen, And þe armes of Alexander · & all þe pilage." ¶ Now flees þar fra þe fell kynge · a fone of his kni&yogh;tes, To Alexander beliue · & all þus him tald, How þat ser Dary with his dukis · eft drissis him to fi&yogh;t, Had prayd eftir powere · to Porrus of ynde. Þan ordans him þis honorable · with his ost flitis, Agayn þe Persyns king · him ordans to ride, For þe name of an Emperoure · ne wald he neuire fange, Or þen þat souerayne ware slayne · or &yogh;ild him his regne. MS. rege, altered to regne. Sone as þe kyng of þat kith · of his come herys, Þan was he ferly a-fri&yogh;t · & his folke bathe. Than kest þam twa of his kni&yogh;tis · him causeles to spill, Þai trowid þan of Alexander · to adill þaim a mede; Þire traitours on þis trechoure · trowthis has strakid, Lendis þaim on-loft to þe lorde · la&yogh;t out swerdis. "Quat sall I dre&yogh;e," quod ser Dary · "my dere-worth childire? First cald I &yogh;ow my clyentis · þat now I call lordis, Semes &yogh;ow no&yogh;t it suffice · my sorowe with-out, Þat as a bitand brand · me brettens with-in, And slaa &yogh;e me þus sudanly? · þe se[n]ioure of grece, He MS. &yogh;e. will me wreke on &yogh;oure werke · wers þan of thefes!" Þar MS. þai. meuyd þaim MS. þai him. na mercy · bot maynly him woundid, Þat doun he hildis all to-hewyn · þaire handis be-twene. Þan dryfes furthe þa dones men · & halfe dede him leuys, Famand Famend, altered to Famand. out of fresch blod · & here a fitt end.

1.1: By þis sir Dary was dight · with hys derfe Erlez, Hefyd vp a hoge hoste · & hastyd hym to ryde, Hys genge & hys garyson · in glasynand wedes, Gose hym to grantum · & grathez vp hys tentes. Hys stoure was stalwort & sture · & strang to abyde, He hed of men for to mynd · mony mayne hundreth, Þat suche a sight & a some · of seggez enarmed Was neuer [sene], I suppoyse · sen þe seyge of troye. The Chyftanys hed chariottes · chosyn for þe nonest, A Ten thouusand be tale · tried for þe were. And þoo wer sett on ather syde · full of sythe-blades, Kene keruand as knyffes · & coursours þaim drawys. The next day be þe none · new note rysys, Ather freke with hys folke · in þe feld metyn, And bald bernez on bent · banerys vnfaldyn, Puttyn penons on pollez · payntyd with syluer. A[lexander] als belyfe · es armyd vp Clene, Bownez hym on hys blonnke · þe best vnder heuen, Þat was þe bald bucyfall · as þe buke tellez, A fole worth fyfty of þat · at in þe flude drownyd. He spedes hym on a grete space · fro hys pers all, Couerys hym full clenly · & closys hym in hys gere. The power of persee · when þai þe prince see, Was ferly frayd of hys forme · so ferdfull he semyd. Nowe er þe batels bowne · with braggyng of trompettes, The breme beeme blast · beryd to þe welkyn. A[lexander] all-þar first · on þaim all settes, And ayther ward at a wappe · wigh[t]ly enioynez. Nota bellum inter Darium & Alexan|drum. Archers & all men · asperly shotyn, þar was Iustyng of Ioy · Iopons attamyd; Seghen downe on ather syde · semelych knytes, Some dasyd, some dede · some depe woundytt. So fell flyght was of flonys · as I fynd writtyn, Of arows & of alblastres · þat all þe Ayre blyndyd; Huger to byhalde · þen þe hayle-stormes, And all þe feld full of folke · fyfe myle large. Als sone as þe son hup soght · þe slaghter begynnys, And to sett was þe same · sesytt þai neuer. Be þat þe barbaryn blode · began to desend, MS. defend. The proudest of þe persyens · passyd owte of lyfe. Sone as sir Dary devysyd · & sawe hys doghty falle, With þat he biddes þam þe bake · & bydes no langer; Þen qwen þai fange to þe flyght · was nerehand euen, And merke withowte mesur · na man myght þam folow. For-þi þe chariottes in þe chase · chopyd þaim to deth, The cartes þat I Carpyd of · with þe kene sythez, Þai fell all fey þaim byfore · with fotemen & oþer, As ressynnys in a ranke feld · when men ouer rydes. Sir Dary dryfys in þe dirke · & hys doghty folows, Goys hym on to grantum · vnto þe grete burne, Fande it frosyn hym byfore · as fell for þe tyme, Passys ouer with hys perys · a pak oute of nowmbre. Hys floke fyllys at Read al. þe flud · a furelonge of brede, The streme fra þat one strande · streght vnto þat oþer. Sone fra hym-self was at þe syde · it sounderytt byhynd, And all þat lent wer on-lofte · lost haue þe swete. Þus mony deyd þis day · as demys me writtes, Off polles oute of persye · withoute þe prouude grekys, Thre C Mille I. e. Three hundred thousand. of throo · þat tharnyd þair lyfez, With þe folez & þe folke · þat þe flude drynched. Þis seneour vnto susys · hys awne cyte wendes, Fallys downe on hys face · flatt in þe sale, "Wo is me!" quod þe wreche · "wo is me vnhappyn!" Sighez selkouthly sore · & sadly he wepys, "I þat was straught to þe sternes · am strykyn nowe to ground, Nowe a crathan & a knaffe · nowe am I kest vnder, Þat had of the Orient all ouer · homage vmwhile. Wist ony wee qwat hym suld worth · þis werld wald he lefe, Full symple in a sete-while · sekyn to þe clodes, And þai þat most er of myght · meltyn all to powder." With þat he rewfully rose · & renkes oute he sendes, To A[lexander] als bylyfe · & all suche a Pistyll. " I, drery Kyng on my dese · Darius of Perys, Epistola. To A[lexander] þe heyr · þat all hase to weld, Þe leyge lord of my lyfe · to lese or to safe, Þus send I to my soueren · salutes of Ioy. So wyde is þe wisdome · þat wonnys in your saule, Þat wele &yogh;e wate of all þat was · & worth here byfore, Off all þe notes þat er nowe · & what on next sewys. For-þi &yogh;e wirke euer by witte · ye werke vnreprefytt. Sir, I knalegh me a creatur · & Comyn of A woman, Hefys nott your hert to hye · bott hedes to your ende; It lympys nott allway þe last · be lykkynd to þe first, Quatt suld a knyght more Couett · þen conquer hys foes? Was not Seryxes hym-self · þe soueranest on ground, And chefyd hym nott of cheualry · chekez oute of nombre? &YOGH;itt for hys will oute of warde · was wonne into pride, In þe lede of Elanda · lythirly he fynyd. Thynke howe only of god · þis ouerlake þou fonges, For-þi haue mercy of þi man · þi myght we besekyn, All of þi grete gudenesse · to graunt vs our moder, Our birde, our barnez oute of bandes · for besaundes enoghe, For all þe feetez þat our fadir · in þe molde Read folde. hyddyn, In battrye & in þis beld · þe burgh of elanda, The maistre & þe maieste · of medy & of perse, With all þe Iolyte & Ioy · þat Iubiter vs lennys." Þe segges þat fra susys · was sent with þis pistill Caryn þaim to A[lexander] · onone & it hym raghten; And he doys one before hys hostez · it opynly to rede, And all þe knyghtes for þe carpe · wer clenly reioysyd. Þen was one permeon, a pere · A prince of hys hoste, Enclynes downe byfore þe kyng · sayd: "kyd Emperour, Resaue, I rede, þis rechez · þis renkez þat þou byddes, And leuerys hym hys lades · & all hys leue childer." Þen A[lexander] als belyfe · þis athell he clepys, Þe bernes þat broght hym þe breve · sayd: "bowys to your Lord, And says, me wonderys, I-wysse · yf he it wene suld, For ony mede vppon molde · hys meyn&yogh;ey to delyver? Yff he be fallyn vnder fote · & hys folke strenyd, And vencust of our vyolence · what valys hym hys heestes? Hys person & hys prouynce · let put in my wyll, And &yogh;iff hym vndir in &yogh;oke · I &yogh;arne hym no mare. And yff he graunt hym nott degradyd · bott for þe gree threpys, Byd hym buske hym eft to þe bent & batell vs &yogh;eld." Þus monyshest he þis messyngers · þair maister at say, Gyffys þaim gyftes full gude · & byddes þaim go swyth. And þen commaundez he hys knyghtes · þe corsez vp to gedder, Of all þe doghty þat was dede · & dight þaim in grafys. And all þat woundytt was, I-wysse · as þe writte tellys, He gart seke þair sarys, & þaim salue · with suurgers Read surgens. noble. At þe flude of grantum · nowe grathez he hys tentes, Honours hys olde goddes · & offers þaim ouchez; Þair fande he palays vp pight · & mony prouude homez, Some-while of Serxes was set · þe syre of þair landez. Þose beldes he byddes þaim bryn · & syne of hys bode rewys, And bad no berne be so bald · a brand for to kyndyll. þar was a brode bent feld · was full of beryd kyngez, Off olde perys oute of pers · of Princez & Dukez. The massydoyns in þe mold · mynyn into þe grafez, Founde coupes all of clene gold · & costyous stonez, Þe sepulturre of a syre · of Surry was crownyd. Hym was þe name Ninus · was in a noke founden, Was of ane athyll amatyst · & all within grafen, Plantyd all with palmetres · & mony prouude fowlez, And suche a clarett Read clartee. it kest · þorow kynde of hym-seluen, Men myght haue kend withoute kyst · þe cors all|to-geder. þar was a tenefull toure · & tulkez inclosyd; Some was þe harmes of heven · & some þe lygez wantyd, Some þe hoghez, some þe eres · & egerly cryden On A[lexander] after help · & he þaim all delyuerys. He wepys on þaim for woo · sayd: "woo is me, my childer!" And ichone of hys talentes · he takys ten thouusand. Þus war þai dyght of Sir Dary · for he disdayne hed, Þat þai war comyn of kyngez · & be no cause ellez. Be þen þe Doghty of sir Darius · our derf messengers Fro A[lexander] ayayn · hys Answer hase broghtyn; And he þen gyrdes oute to grete · & grathez hym to fyght, To þe honourd heere oute of Inde · þus Ordayns he a pistyll. " That þe septour & þe soyle · sesyd am of pers, To porrus vnder my prynt · plesaunce & Ioy. First wrote I to your worthynes · &yogh;itt write I þe same, To help vs Anest þees athell men · þat hery wald oure realme, And, be &yogh;e sure, þe same way · is to your-selfe etteld. And he þat werrys vs · is þe weldar of grece, Es wrawyd & wrathfull of will · & wode as a lyon, As wawes of þe wild see · when wynd þaim dis|trobles; And þof I somme & samme · seggez oute of nombre, And cok with þis conquerour · tyll I be cold drepyd, &YOGH;itt is me better on þe bent · in batell to fayle, Þen see þe losse of my ledes · & ay lefe in sorow. For-þi your lordship as lege man · I lofely beseche, As I þat am in angres · my askyns fullfyll; Ten schelyng of my trew gold · a tulke þat is armyd, And fyfe to A foteman · faythfully I hete. &YOGH;itt shall I ordayne to your one · whar-euer our hoste liggez, Nyne score of new gere · of norturryd maydens. Bucyfall þe bald stede · sall als be your awne, With þe armez of Sir A[lexander] · & all þe oþer pelage." Nowe fleen þai fro þis fell kyng · a some of hys knyghtes, To A[lexander] als belyfe · als þus hym told, How þat Sir Dary he added here, but struck out . with hys dukez · dressyd þaim to fyght, Had send after power · to porrus of Inde. Þen ordayns hym þis honorable · & with hys hoste flyttes, Ayayns þe persyen Prince · he purpose to ryde, For þe name of emperour · wald he neuer fonnge, Or þat soueren wer slayn · & seysyd to hym þe realme. Sone as þe kyng of þat kyth · of hys Come herys, Þen was he ferly affrayd · & hys folke both. And þen kest two of hys knyghtes · to causles hym spyll, Þam afterward of A[lexander] · attelland a mede; Þees tratours on þat trichory · trouthez han stroken, Lenden þaim on-loft to þe lord · laghtyn oute swerdes. "What sall I dre," quod sir Dary · "my dere worthy childer? First cald I yow my clyentes · þat now I calle Lordes, Semys you nott it shuld suffyce · my sorow now withoute, Þat as a bytand brand · me bytes within, And sla &yogh;e me þus sodonly? · þe senyour of grece, He will me wreke on your werke · wers þen of theffes!" þar mevyd þaim no mercy · bott manly hym woundit, Þat downe he heldes all to-hewyn · þair handes bytwene. Þen dryfen forth þoo Domesmen · & halfdede hym lefes, Fomand oute of freche blode · & here a fytt endes.

0.1: Quen Alexander of þis athill · þis auntir hadd herd, How he was di&yogh;t of his douth · & to þe dede woundid, He stre&yogh;t him to struma · & ouire þe streme ridis, So&yogh;t him in Sussys · him-selfe with his ost. Þe pepill out of Persy · quen þai oure prince see, Þan &yogh;ode þai furthe & vn-&yogh;arkid · þe &yogh;atis of þe cite, Resayues him full rially · with reuerence & ioy, Said: "welcum be þou, werraiour · þat all þe erd loutis!" Sone as þir weried wi&yogh;tis · was ware of hes come, Þat slo&yogh;e so þaire souerayne · þat neuire sake hadd, Þai he&yogh;e þaim to holes & hyrnes · & hydis þaim belyue, Þo&yogh;t, or þai wist of his will · þai wald no&yogh;t apere. Þan gase he vp be degrece · the grecen maistir, Passis in-to þe palais · a paradyce semed, Was on þe make of þat mote · no&yogh;t Here follows we, struck through . mervalled a litill, Þat compast was of Cusys · þat kynge was of Persy. Þe flore vndire þe fote · fynely was paued, Couerd all of cristall · & oþire clere stanes. &YOGH;it ware þe wawes of þe wanes · wro&yogh;t, as I rede, Polischid all of pure gold MS. gold gold, but corrected . · & of plate werkis. And þat was streken full of sternys · & of sere gemmys, With bri&yogh;t blasynand bees · as bemes of þe son. Þe hathill hedis vp-on he&yogh;e · & hogely he wondirs, Þat euire suld emperoure in erth · slike ane herde wild. Quen he had ferlyd his fill · apon þat faire hame, Þur&yogh;e-out þe sale þan he so&yogh;t · in-to þe selfe chambre, Þare quare þe lord in lay · with laythely woundis, Girdid out as gutars · in grete gill-stremes, &YOGH;it was þare lyfe in his like · litill if it semed, At ilk blast of his breth · þe blode fra him glidis, Sire Alexander him avysis · & authly him thinke; Þe pure pete of his payn · persid his hert. Þan nymes he fra his awyn neke · an emperoures mantill, And þat he In the margin . couirs ouire þe kyng · & clappis him in armes, With grym gretyng & gro · & grysely terys; Bad: "comfurth þe, ser conquirour · & of þi care ryse, Don a&yogh;ayne þe dignite · þe diademe of Pers, And all þe ri&yogh;tis of þi rewme · resayue as before. My pure powarfull gods · I prestly pauoure, Þine empire & þine erytage · enterely þe to &yogh;eld; Suld neuir na gome be to glade · þofe he grete ware, Of his ne&yogh;bour noy · enentis him-selfe, Quen fortune foundis him fra · & him þe fete schewis, And all þe welth him at-wendis · & þe werd changis. Brynge furth þi banes, & with my brand · I sall þi dede venge." Þis sa&yogh;e sobband he said · & þe segge wakyns, Hyndely hildis him vp · & his hand kyssis, Þe brest & þe bare necke · & breues þire wordis: ¶ "A! Alexander, athill son" · & augrily granys, "Þe depe distruccion of &yogh;our dome · has many day bene In the margin. knawyn, Þat all þe welth of þe werld · worthis at þe last To cayrayne & corupcion · clene all-to-gedire. Þe warnes of þi wale gode · þat wist all before, And fully feld all þe fare · þat fall suld on erthe; On þis maner made he man · þur&yogh;e his mi&yogh;t first, Suld no&yogh;t be foun in him fast · ne ferme ne stable, Bot houande here a hand-qwile · & hingand in payse, Now in leuell, now on-loft · now on lawe vndire. All werdly þing, I-wis · þur&yogh;e þe will of oure lord, In-to þe contrare clene · is at a clamp turned. For had he wor&yogh;t For wro&yogh;t. ay to wees · welth & na nothire, So grete had bene vayn glorie · glotony & pride, Suld nane haue gessid þat grace · come of god, bot of þaim-selfe; So fra þe makare o mold · suld many man haue erryd. . . . . . So feyle had bene þe frelettis · folo&yogh;and oure kynd, We had bene drawen all bedene · in-to disspaire clene, And of þe godness of god · no&yogh;t a grew Here follows st. standing alone . traisted. For-þi he wald of his will · his werkis to be changand, Þat, quen a hathill ware ouire hi&yogh;e · in happ & in welthe, Þat he knew no&yogh;t his creatour · bi-cause of his pride, In-to þe dike of debonerte · droune bud him nede. Þis was his will at it worthid · wene þou na nothire, Þe gome his god at for-gatt · for any grace here, His welth to wite all a-way · & wickidnes apere, To ken þe caytefe to knaw · qua caused him on first. Þe same ensampill of my-selfe · now is betid, þou sees; So grete I grew of my gods · & gold in my cofirs, Þat kindly gods creatoure · I kend no&yogh;t my-selfe, Bot for his felo&yogh;e & his fere · faithly me leued, Þus prosperite & pride · so purely me blyndid, I couthe no&yogh;t se fra my sege · to þe soile vndire, Þat at me failed þan to fynd · fast at myn e&yogh;en. Be þe myrrour now of meknes · I may a myle knawe, If any hathill be so hard · with vnhapp woundid, So at he hopis him no helpe · of þe he&yogh;e fadire, Þan liftis oure lord him on-loft · his langour he breggis, In-hanses him in hand-quile · & heues him to welthis So he&yogh;e, þat he for vn-hele · se&yogh;es no&yogh;t his dri&yogh;ten. Lat þan him knaw his creatour · in kindling of ioy, Þat he þat lawene has a lede · may lyft, if him thinke, And he þat bringis him on-loft · breten all to poudire. Þi saule, son, in-to surquitery · lat seke neuire þe hi&yogh;hare, For gre þe graunt ere Read is. of god · & no&yogh;t Added in the margin. of þi grete strenthis. If all þe limp as þe list · loke to þine ende, For die þe bose, quen all is done · & ay þi day scortis. ¶ Me þink MS. Me þink me. my lyfe as to þe len&yogh;th · is like to þis werke, Þat þis coppis opon kell-wyse · knytt in þe wo&yogh;es, With þe lest winde of þe werd · þat þe werd touches, Þe note anentis ilk ane · & all to no&yogh;t worthis. Lo! so þe quele of qwistsumnes · my qualite has changid! I, þat was &yogh;ustirday so &yogh;ape · & &yogh;emed all þe werld, To day am dreuyn all to dust · to dolour & paynes, Has no&yogh;t o maistri so meche · as mi&yogh;t of my-selfe. My dere son," quod Daryus · "it drawes nere þe tyme; My banes, on my benyson · bery with þi hand, With þe proued princes out of Pers MS. Perers. · & with þe proude grekis, And þe maistirlings of Messedoyne · &yogh;e me to mold bring. Lat þan oure kyng-domes a-corde · & cock we na langir, Bot ay perpetuall pes · oure partys betwene. Vn-to &yogh;oure mekill maieste · my modire I comande, Rodogarus þe riall · & rewis on my bride; My do&yogh;tir Rosan þe riche · resayues to &yogh;our spouse, It comys wele of hi&yogh;e kyn · kyngis to descend. Tak tent to þat at I tell · be tendire of my kni&yogh;tis." And with þis speke at he spake · þe sprete he &yogh;eldis. Þan was his body enbawmed · &, as he bede, grauen. Þis bald baratoure him bare · & as a barne gretis, So did þe pepill out of Persy · bot for his pite mare Þan for þe dethe of Dary · be dowble of þe twa. And Alexander belyue · as he was enterid, He meues agayn to þe mote · & on þe morne eftir, Vp to þe souerayne sege · with Septour he wyndis, Þat Cusus þe conquirour · of clere gold maked. Þe mody men of Messedone · þe maistirs of Persy Þan put þam in-to presens · as þe prose tellis; Sire Darius awen dyademe · þai did on his hede, A coron, ane þe costious · þat euire kyng weryd, On þe propurest of proiecte · þat euire prince bere. Þe massy werke was þe menest · made of þe noble, Þe pride þar-of for to proue · it pyned any cristen; It gaue so glorius a gleme · of gold & of stanes, Þat as þe loge for þe li&yogh;t · lemed as of heuen. Þe sete þare him-selfe satte · in soyte with þe croune, Þat was lift a-pon loft · on oþire litill segis, Seuyn cubet of clere gold · was countid þe hi&yogh;t. And vij degrece was þar grayd · for gate vp of kingis, And þai ware Ientilly Ioyned · in a Ioyly wyse. Þe first an athil Amatast · as I am infourmed, And of a Smeth [s]maragadane · Smyten was þe toþir; Þe thrid of a Topas a-tyred · & trelest & grauen; Þe ferd degre a Granate · a gracious gemme; Þe fyfte was of ane Adomant · all-to-gedire makid; Þe sext of gletirand gold · gayle was forgid; Þe ouirmast, all of þe erth · with-out oþire werkis, Apon þis wyse ware þai grayd · & for grete cause. Þe first was of an Amatist · þat all chaye demes Riche, said þe romance · & ronkenes of wynes, Lattis na dronkynnes MS. droncynnes, altered to dronkynnes. þam dere · þat douth at it beris. Þe same wyse mon a wee · waite to him-selfe, A kni&yogh;t at couettis to clym · to kyngs astate, Him bus haue warnes him with · of wit & of mynde, Þat he wirke no&yogh;t on þe wethire halfe · for wathe apon erth. Þe s[e]cunde was of Smaragdone · þat ay þe si&yogh;t kepis; Quat berne as beris it him on · it bri&yogh;tens his e&yogh;en. So bus a kyng to consaile · haue a MS. ai. clere hert, To se at syttis him to se · & sagely to wirke. Þe thrid was a Topas, I trow · at to þe trone lengis; Þat is so clere of his kind · þe clause me recordis, Þat qua-sum-euire in þat ilk · his ymage behaldis, Þe face is to þe fold-ward · þe fete to þe firment. So comes it wele for a kyng · to knaw till his end, How ay þe top to þe taa · is turned at þe last. Quen fortune festis him · he fendis beliue, And all his dignite bedene · driues in-to poudire. Þe ferd was a granate, I gesse · goules althire fynest; Is nane so redy, as I rede · of all þe riche stanes; Slike color a&yogh;e a kyng wele · in conyschance to bere, Þat he schape to na schauadry · þat schend suld his fame. Þe fift was all of adomant · as þe buke tellis; Þat is he þat is so hard · þat hurt may nane tole; MS. thole tole; with thole struck out. Is nothire stele ne na stane · so stife it may perce, And growis out of þe grete see · in graynes & in cragis. If any Naue MS. aue, altered to Naue in the margin. to it ne&yogh;e · þat naylid is with iryn, Þen cleuys it ay to þe clife · carryg & othyre; Bot blode of body, sais þe buke · bees it neuire percid, MS. lansed, altered to percid. Or þe natour of anothire thing · þat nedis no&yogh;t to reken. Þat same kynd suld a kyng · of his craft vse, So stable & so stedfast · to stand in his werkes, Þat for na prayere ne pres · ne plesaunce on erthe, Out of þe rake of ri&yogh;twysnes · ren suld he neuire. Þe Sext was of gold · graciously hewen, Of all metals o mold · þe maistir & þe syre; Þe same cure is a kyng · be kind of his leggis, To gy & gouerne MS. gounere. his gomes · þe grettest he is makid. Þe seuynt vp to þe sege · was of þe selfe erth, Þat is na mare for to mene · as me my mynd tellis, Bot ilka kyng suld him knaw · cried of þe soile, And to þe same sustenance · sodanly to worthe. Þus sett oure syre in his sete · with septoure in hand, In pelour & in pall · & proud men him by. Þan lete he lettres belyue · with ledis out to send, Þur&yogh;e all þe prouynce of pers MS. perers. · promicid þis werkis. "Þe kyng with-outen compere · of kyngis all othire, Of all þe lordis now þe lord · þat lefis apon erth, Sire Alexander, athill son · of Amon his dri&yogh;ten, And als of Olimpades · anyly consayued, To þe souerayns & þe Senescalls · þe sires & þe maistris, And all þe pers out of persy · princes & dukis, Þe Iustis & þe gentils · & Iugemen of lawe, Bathe citi&yogh;ens & seriant · salutis of grace. Syn it lokid has þe largenes · of þe lord of heuen, Þat me þis diademe of Dary · demed is & graunted, And to be In the margin . here þus enhansid · in his hi&yogh;e trone, &YOGH;e sall be glad of my degre · & gretly reioyd, And ordans aiquare ouire all · honourable princes, Gouernours & gardens · of all þe grete bur&yogh;es, As was in Darius days · to deme men þe ri&yogh;t, And clene all þe clientis · to kepe þaire demayndes. Ilk a pepill his possession MS. posseciion, altered to possession. · in pes mo&yogh;t he broweke, Armoure & actons · y latt all þat be kepid, MS. kepis. Caires þam to castells · & in kinge houses, And none so bald, ere I bide · to bere þam na mare. And fra þis marche to Messedone · quils I am maistir here, Þe passage in aithire part · sall playn be & open, Þe comers out of aithire coste · to caire vndistrobbed, With message & Marchandise · & al manire of nedis." ¶ Now is his pistils all past · & pese he comandis; "Quilke of my fryndis ere þe folke · þat my faa slo&yogh;e, Þat was þe drepars of Dary · now doo þam a-pere, Þat þai may weld for þis werke · wirschip to mede. My mekill mi&yogh;tfull gods · I maynly &yogh;ow swere, And on þe lay at I leue · & be my lufed modire, Here the Dublin MS. ends . Þe worthe wage þaim wayue · þat þai haue wele serued." Þan all þe pepill out of Persy · pouret out to wepe; Bathe Besan & Anabras · as þe buke tellis, Þat ware þe banes of his body · baldly þam shawis; Said: "we to-hewid him [with] oure handis · hi&yogh;e emperoure." Þai wend wele þaim to wyn · a waryson for euire. Þan bad he bernes þaim to bynd · & bringe þaim be-lyue Vn-to þe gudmans graue · & hewe of þaire hedis. "Allas, my lord," quod þa ledis · "& &yogh;e so late swore, To &yogh;our worthi gods, &yogh;our wale dame · we suld no waa suffire!" "Siris, as &yogh;e worthi ware, I-wisse · I wate wele I hi&yogh;t, And bot &yogh;our harmes were vnhid · I held no&yogh;t myne athis. For sen I wan in-to þe werld · my witt has bene aye, Quen treid was a trechory · þe tulkis to be hedid." Þan he did þaim to deth · as dri&yogh;ten him praysed, Þe prouynce pi&yogh;t is in pes · & princes ere maked, An MS. And. ald derling MS. derlingis. of Darius · was duke made of pers, Request of þe rials · ane of his riche vncles. Oure emperoure, quen þis was endid · erly on þe morne, With all þa alyens him by · & ancient lordis, He gase a-gayne to de-grece · vp to þe gilt trone, Dobbed in his diademe · & di&yogh;t as be-fore; As Dary demed, or he deid · his do&yogh;tir he comandes, Mad Rosan þe riche · radly to apere, Hire hede vn-helid was on hi&yogh;e · & hild all in trissis, Vm-by-clappid with a coronacle · of costious stanes; As þe manere of þat marche was · he wedd hire to wyfe, And in þe sege with him-selfe · to sitt he hir makis, Comands hire as a conquyres · of kny&yogh;tis to be louted, And all þe pepill out of Persy · was passandly ioyed. Þai gone agraythen vp þaire gods · on gilten segis, Sayed: "þou ert duke of ilk dome · & dri&yogh;tin þi-selfe!" Þan was he fraid in his flesche · bad, "feyne of &yogh;our wordis! I am a coruptible kyng · & of clay fourmed!" Þan out onone to Aristotil · & to his awen modire Of all his weris & his welth · he wrate alto-gedire; And a&yogh;t daies all bedene · he dites in his pistill, For reuerence of Rosan · to revell & halowe. Al be þe metire bot mene · þus mekill haue I ioyned; Forthi, lordis, be &yogh;our leue · list &yogh;ow to suffire. Now will I tary for a time · & tempire my wittis; And he þat sti&yogh;e to þe sternes · sti&yogh;till vs in heuen!

1.1: Q[u]hen A[lexander] of þis athell · þis aunturs had herd, How he was dyght of hys doughty · & to þe deth woundit, He straght hym on to struma · ouer þe streme rydes, Soght on to susys · hym-self with hys hostez. Þe peple oute of persye · when þai þis Prince see, Þen &yogh;ode þai furth & vn&yogh;arkyd · þe &yogh;ates of þe Cyte, Resaved hym full ryally · with reuerence enogh, Sayd: "welcom be þou, weryour · þat all þe werld loutes!" Sone as þees warryd wightez · was war of hys come, Þat Sloghen so þair souerent · þat neuer þaim gilt made, Þai hyen þaim to holez · & hyden þaim belyfe, Þoght, or þai wist of hys wyll · þai wald not apere. Þen goyse he vp be degrees · þe greken maister, Passyd vnto þe palacys · þat paradyse semyd, Was in makke of þat mote · noght mervaylled a lytyll, Þat Compast was of Susys · þat kyng was of pers. Þe flore vnder fute · fynely was pafvyd, Couered all of cristall · & oþer clere stonez. &YOGH;itt wer þe wallez of þe wane · wroght, as I rede, Polyshyd all of pure gold · & of plate werkes. And þat was strengkyllyd full of sternez · & strykyn with gemmys, With bright blasenand beys · as bemys of þe sonne. Þe hathell hedes vp on hight · & hugely he wounderez, Þat euer suld Emperour in erth · suche a place welde. Qwen he had farlyd hys fyll · on þees fair homez, T[h]rogh-oute þe sale þan he soght · vnto þe self chaumbre, þar as þe lord in lay · with lothlyche woundes, Gyrrdand oute as gutters · in grete gylle-stormez, &YOGH;itt was þar lyfe in hys lyre · lytyll yf it semyd, Att Iche blast of hys breth · þe blode fro hym &yogh;ettes, Sir A[lexander] on hym avysys · & trewly hym thynkez; Þe pure pite of hys payn · persyd hys hert. Þen nymmez he fro hys awne neke · ane emperours mantell, And þat he Couerys ouer þe kyng · & clepys hym in harmez, With greme gretyng & grone · & gryslyche terys; Bad: "comforth þe, sir conquerour · & of þi care ryse, Þu dose ayayn þi dignite · þe dyademe of pers, And þe rightez of my realme · resayve als before. My pure powerfull goddes · prestly adoure, Þine empyre & þi herytage · þe purely to &yogh;eld; Suld neuer no gome be glad · þof he grett wer, Off hys neghburs noye · anentes hym-seluen. When fortune fundes hym fro · & hym þe fete schewys, And all þe welthe MS. wethche. þat he weldes · & þe werld chaungez, Bryng fforth þi banes, & with a brand · þi bale shall I venge." Þis sagh sobband he sayd · & so þe segge wakyns, Hendly halsys hym vmbe · & hys hande kyssys, Þe brest & on þe bare neke · & brevys þees wordez: "A! Alexander, athyll son" · and augerdly gronys, "Þe depe distruccion of þi dome · hase mony day ben knawen, All þe welth of þis werld · waystes be þe last To caryon & corrupcion · clene all-to-geder. The wyssyng of þe wale god · þat wist all before, And fully fele all þe fare · þat falle shuld on erth; On þis maner made he man · þorow hys myght first, Suld not be funde in hym fastnes · ne ferme be ne stabyll, Bot hofand here an hand-while · & hyngand on payse, Now in leuell, nowe on-loft · nowe in law vnder. All wordly þ[i]ng, I-wys · þorow wyll of þat Lord, Into þe contray clene · is at a clampe turnyd. For hed he wroght ay to wees · welth & none oþer, So grete had ben vaneglory · glotony & Pride, Suld nane haue gessyd þaim grace · of god, bott of þaim|seluen; So from þe maker of man · myght mony haue erryd. And had he shapyn Ay to shalkez · shendship & illys, So fele had ben þe frekes · folowand our kynd, We had ben drawyn all bedene · into dispare clene, And on þe gudnes of god · noght a dele traistytt. For-þi he wald of hys will · all warkys to be chaunged, Þat, when on athyll was so wele · in happe & in heyle, Þat he knew not hys creatour · be-cause of hys pryde, Into þe Dyche of debonerte · drench must hym nede. Þis was hys wille þat it shuld þus worth · wete þou no noþer, The gome þat hys god forgatt · for ony grace here, Hys welth to wyte away · & wrychednes to apere, To ken þe catyff to knaw · who causyd hym on first. Þe sampyll of my Awne self · þou seys nowe betyd; So grete I grew of my gudez · & gold in my coffers, Þat kendly goddes creature · I knew nott my-seluen, Bott for hys felow & hys fere · faythfully me made, Þus prosperite & pride MS. proride. · propyrly me blyndyd, I kouth noght see fro my seyge · to þe sette vnder, Þat at me faylyd to fynd · fast at my eeyn. Be þe myrrow[r] of mekenes · I may a myle knaw, Yff ony hathell be so hard · with vnhappe woundit, So þat he hopys hym no help · of þe hye fader, Þen lyftes þe kyng hym on-loft · hys langor abreggez, Enhaunses hym in hand-while · & hefys hym on-loft So he, þat ere For ere, read he. for vnsele · segh nott hys Dryghtyn. Lete þen hym know hys creature · in kyndyllyng of Ioy, Þat he laghtnes may lede · & lyft when hym thynkez, And þat brynges hym abowe · bryttynd all to powder. Þi sawle, sir, into Surquydry · latt sech neuer þe heyere, [ Leaf 40 is lost .] What berne þat berys it hym on · it brightyns hys syght. [ ; leaf 40 being lost .] So buse a kyng to consayve · hafe a clere hert, To se þat sittes hym to see · & sagely to wirche. The thryd was a topas, I trowe · þat to þe trone longyd; Þat is So clere of hys kynde · þe clause it recordes, Þat who-someuer in þat ilke · hys vysage behaldes, Þe face is to þe foldward · þe fete into þe welkyn. So comys it wele to a kyng · to knaw to hys ende, Howe ay þe topp to þe toes · is turnyd at þe last, When fortoune fraystes frely hym in-fere · he fyndes hym belyfe, And all hys dignite bedene · dryfys into Powder. The fourte was a granate · þat glowys all þar fynest; Is none so rede, as I rede · of all þe ryche stones; Suche colour aght a kyng wele · in countenaunce to bere, Þat he shope to no cheualdre · þat shend shuld hys name. The fyft was all of Adamant · as þe buke tellys; Þat is he þat is so hard · þat hurt may no tule; Is noþer stele nor no stone · so styff may it perce, And growys out of þe grete see · in granes & in Craggez. Yff ony navy to it negh · þat nalyd is with Irne, Þen clefys it ay to þe clyff · carrak & oþer; Withowte blode of body, says þe buke · beys it neuer persyd, Or þe nature of a-noþer thyng · þat nedes noght to rekyn. The same kynd shuld a kyng · of hys craft vse, So stabyll & so stedfast · to stond in hys werkez, Þat for no prayer ne preese · ne plesaunce MS. plesaaunce. on erth, Oute of þe rakke of rightwyssnes · rynne shuld he neuer. The sext degree was of gold · graciously hewyn, Off all þe metallys of mold · þe maister & þe syre; The same cure is a kyng · be kend of hys leigez, To gye & goueryne hys gomes · þe grettest is he grathyd. The Seuente vp to þe sege · was of þe self erth, Þat is no more for to mene · as me þe writte tellys, Bot euerilke kyng shuld hym knawe · create of þe soyle, And to þe same substance · sodanly to worth. Þus sett our Syre in hys sete · with septour in hand, In pelour & in palle · & prouude men hym vmbe. Þen lete he letterys belyfe · with ledes oute to send, Þorow all þe prouynce of pers · pronounsand þees wordez: " The kyng withowtyn compere · of kyngez all oþer, Of all lordes nowe lord · þat lefyn vppon erth, Sir A[lexander], athyll son · of amon hys drightyn, And also of Olympades · only consaved, To þe souerayns & senescallez, · þe syrez & þe maisterys, And all þe peres oute of pers · princez & dukez, Þe iustice & þe gentyles · þe iuggez of þe lawe, Both cyte&yogh;eyns & sergeantez · salutes of grace. Seth lukkyd hath þe largenes · of þe lord of heuen, Þat me þis Diademe of Dary · demyd is & grauntyd, And to be here þus inhaunsyd · in hys hye trone, &YOGH;e shall be glad of my degree · & gretly reiossed, And ordayns ouer all & ay · honorable princez, Gouernours & gardens · of all my grete burghez, As was in Darius days · to deme men þe right, And clene all our clientes · to kepe þair demaundes, Iche peple þair possession · in pease myght þai broke, Armors & actons · lat all þat be kepyd, Cayrez þaim to castellys · & to kyngez housez, And none so bold, or I byd · to bere þaim no more. And fro þis marche to massydoyne · whil I am maister here, The passage shall in ather parte · plane be & opyn, Þe Comers oute of athir coste · to cayre vndistourblett, With message & with merchaundyse · & all maner of nedes."
