Nowe er hys pistellys forth past · & pease he Commandez; "Which of my frendes er þe folke · þat my foe slogh, Þat wer þe drepers of sir Dary · nowe doys þaim apere, Þat þai may weld for þair werk · worship & mede. My mekyll myghtfull goddes · I maynly you swere, And on þe lay þat I lefe · & be my lofyd moder,
1.2: [ Here ends the fragment in the Dublin MS.]

text.14: Quintusdecimus passus Alexandri. Lordis, will &yogh;e me lithe · & lestin a stonde, Now sall I kithe vs a carpe · of a kyng riche, Of þe auntours of ser Alexander · þat aire was of grece, How all þe werd at his will · he wan or he deid. Þe lattir ende of his lyfe · me list &yogh;ow to tell. For all þe first is in fittis · & folowand þe lettir, And he þat made &yogh;ow þis mirth · oft mynes his saule, Þat dri&yogh;tin deyne him to dele · a dele of his blis. Sone as ser Dary was deid · & done out of lyue, And Alexander as MS. as ar; with ar struck out. aire · had all for to wild, Resayued to his riche quene · Rosan his do&yogh;tir, And was þe croune be-kend · of clene all þus ends, He gedird him a grete ost · & graythid him to ride, A powere of þe Persens · & of þe prowde grekis, Þe Messedones & all men · he [maynly] comandis On kyng Porrus to preke · & prese him with armes. Now gase he furthe with his ging · þe gaynest in-to ynde. Þare many daies be dissert · he dryfes with his ost, Be hi&yogh;e hillis & howis · & be holu&yogh;e doūnes, Be wast & be wildirnes · & be watirles bournes. Sone was he wery of þe way · so was his wale kni&yogh;tis; Menyd þaim þe Messedones · emang þaim-selfe, Þai said, it mi&yogh;t be sufficient · þe sesyng of Persy, And him þat MS. þat se; with se struck out. trouage on tyme · has tane of oure eldirs. "Quat suld we fonde any ferre · now faylis oure strent[h]is; Þis erd of ynde is ilk dele · enhabet with bestis, And he bet willis all þe werd · be weris him to loute, His flesche is fostard & fedd · be fi&yogh;t & by sternes. And were his person in pes · bot for a pure tyme, Þan suld he faile as a freke · at þe fode wantis. Bot lat vs leue him at longe · & lende to oure hames, And pas quedire as him plese · with þe proud barbres." Sone as oure kyng of his kni&yogh;tis · þis carpe vndire|stondis, He mas to stand all þe stoure · & standis vp in þe myddis, "Bald baratours on bent · blythly me heris, All þe pepill out of Persy · ere put in my will; All ware rebell in arest · now is þe rewme MS. rewe, altered to rewme. &yogh;old, And I your kyng as &yogh;e knaw · with croune & with septour. And now &yogh;e leue me þus li&yogh;tly · bot for a litill pyne, To caire a-gayne to &yogh;our kithid Or kichid. · I can no&yogh;t þare-on. Knaw &yogh;e no&yogh;t how in &yogh;our care · I cu[m]furth &yogh;ow anys, Quene &yogh;e dout so þe dites · of Darus in his pistill? Eft quen we ferd in-to fild · & with oure faes mett, I was þe first &yogh;ow before · þat þe fild entrid, So&yogh;t in-to Sussys · my-selfe for MS. oo, corrected to for. &yogh;oure hele, In þe habet of Amon · oure MS. a oure; with a expuncted . allirs dri&yogh;ten, Put my person in plegg · & perils a hundreth, And in-to tourment on-tald · me tuke for &yogh;our sake. Bot wetis it wele with-out wene · I wene in my saule, As I &yogh;it haue hediretoward · heried all my faes, So sall I gete hus ay þe gree · with my gud helpe, And for na tene at may betide · turne sall I neuire, If &yogh;e will lend in-to &yogh;our landis · loke at &yogh;our hertis! Bot me to do slike a dede · dri&yogh;tin it schilde! I sall neuire graithe me to grece · gase quen &yogh;ow likis, Or mare wirschip I haue won · for wathe vndire heuen." Quen he þis reson had redd · þan rewid his princes, And of forge[f]nes of þaire gilt · his grace þai be-seke. Kni&yogh;tis callis Read fallis. him on kneys · said: "kid emperoure, All oure life & oure lose · is lent in &yogh;our handis, Oure-selfe & oure seruage · is surely &yogh;oure awen, Ai at &yogh;oure beding to be · oure bodi & oure gudis, Quare-euer &yogh;e wend in all þe werd · in watir or in erthe, Ay mekely at &yogh;our mandment · &yogh;our maieste to folowe. If we suld die all-bedene · at an day tyme, We sall neuer spise &yogh;ow ne sporne · in speche ne in dede, Ne neuire &yogh;our rialte renay · bot rede to sewe, Quils any blast of oure breth · in oure brest lengis." Þan &yogh;ede he furth in-to ynde · & in þase Iles weres; Quen all þe iolite of giugne · & Iulus was endid, And messangers a-pon þe marche · him metis belyue, Fra kyng Porrus þe proude · þis pistill him bro&yogh;t. ¶ "I, Porrus, þat as principall · possessid am in ynde, To þis michare out of Messedone · þis mandment I write. Þou, Alexander, þou Ape · þou Amla&yogh;e out of grece, Þou litill thefe, þou losangere · þou lurkare in cites, Sen þou ert destayned to die · & dedely þi-selfe, Þat Read As; the usual idiom . agayn dri&yogh;tin of vnde[d]lynes · quat may þi dede vaile? Madding marrid has þi mode · & þi mynd changid. Sen god has sent þe with to see · & &yogh;it þi witt failes, I hope þou wenes at we be like · to þire lethire Persyns, Þat þou þi lordschip to loute · has now on late strayned. And for þou fellid has in fi&yogh;t · a fi&yogh;t at was sympull, MS. symplille. Now muses þou to þi miserie · my maieste to bowe. If gomes be gouerners of gods · þan mai þi gesse worth; And if þe land here on lawe · be lickned to þe heuen, Þe ministracion of men · to me were to febill. All dri&yogh;tens & dewessis · ere dute of my name; Ane ser Denys, a duke · gane many wintire, He bed vs bataill on bent · & þe back turned. And or þat Sexes him-selfe · sesid was in Persy, At þe marche of Messedone · made vs trouage. Bot for þe In the margin . partise ere vn-prophetable · vs plese þaim na langir, Ai wald þe wise haue wale soile · mare þan a wast lee. Caire agayn to þi kith · caiteffe, I bidd, Here na lordschip þe limpis · quat list þe disyre." ¶ Sone as þis clause to oure kyng · [was] comyn & deliuere, Read deliuered. Be-fore his bachelers on brade · he bedis it to rede. His tulkis of þis titill · quen þai þe tenour herd, Þan ware þai sory of þa sawes · & selly frayed. "Quat now, my worthe werrayouris?" · þe wale kyng sayd, "For Porrus pistill, I pray · ne for his proud wordis, No for na manas he mas · mayes no&yogh;t &yogh;oure hertis. Did no&yogh;t ser Dary to vs write · his pistill with pride, And all þe berbrens bernes · in bestis þam affyed, As lebards, lesards, & lenxis · lions & tigris?" With comfurth of his contenance · his kny&yogh;tis he gladis, And þan to Porrus apart · þis pistill he writis. ¶ "I, þat MS. þat at. þe kyng am of kyng[s] · & crouned of lordis, Þe eldist child of Amon · þat all has to wild, And honourd Olimpades · with him ane geten, To þe oddest aire out of ynde · þis answare I make. I-wis, oure wittis with þi wordis · þou has wele scharpid, And made vs bald with þi bost · þe bataill to &yogh;eld. Oure boundis ere barrayne & bare · & þine full of welth; Þe kenir is oure corage · &yogh;oure kyng-dome to wyn, To put away oure pouerte · & pas to &yogh;oure hi&yogh;tes. And ga no&yogh;t, as &yogh;e gude ware · agayn &yogh;ow to fi&yogh;t, Bot a berne full of bost · a barbrene prince, Wenand me & all þe werd · to waike to &yogh;ow-selfe." Quen Porrus with his preue men · þis pistill had redd, Þan was he wondirly wrathe · & wi&yogh;tly asembles Þe kni&yogh;tis & þe captayns · of all þe coste by, His champions, his chiftans · his cheualry to-gedire. He feris him a faire flote · was fed for þe nanes, Of vnicornes, of olyfauntis · & wondirfulle bestis, As ilkane vsyd with in ynde · vmquile with to fi&yogh;te, And aires agayne Alexander · with armes him to mete. Þe powere of sir Porrus · was passandly many; A stour stiffe vndire stele · þe strangest of þe werde Of sithid chariotis him sued · a selcuth nombre, At þe fewist, as I find · a fouretene thousand; With-outen bachelers on blonkis · & bowmen on fote, Foure hundreth Olyfants in-fere · folowid him enarmi[d], With ilkane bunden on his bake · a borden castell, And thretty tulkis in ilk toure · tired in platis. Oure mey-he MS. be before. out of Messedone · quen þai so many sa&yogh;e, Þan ware þai storbet of þat stoure · so was þe stythe Persyns. All þe athils of sir Alexander · was ar&yogh;ed in þaire hertis To mache with sike a multitude · of men & of bestis. Þan was þir chiftans chosen · cheualous kni&yogh;tis Þat buskid ware on bathe halfe · þe bataill to rewle. With þat þai tuke vp þe trumpis · be thretty at anes, A-grydis grymly to-gedir · þe grekes & barbres. Sire Alexander was armed · & askis his stede Þat was þe bald bocifalon · & on his bake worthes; Mare þan a stanecast at a count · be-fore MS. be before. his kni&yogh;tis all He standis vp in his stereps · in starand maylis. Þe men out of Medy · he mas, & of Pers, To enverom alle þe vaward · of all þe vile yndes, And he was graythid [with] a ging · of grekis kni&yogh;tis And maistres out [of] Messedone · þis meyhe Read meynhe. to helpe. Þe pepill out of Persye · ware petusly woundid Of Olifauntis ouir all · with horrible hurtis; All at vnweried a-way · wynnes in þe stoundis Durst neuir his face to his faes · eft on fold bide. Sire Alexander him a-visis · & ames in his wittis How he mi&yogh;t bring it a-boute · þire bestis to devoide; And mas to beete all of bras · as bernes it ware, And full of glorand gledis · þaim to þe gorge fillis; Ane instrument all of iren · þare ymage to bere, Was compast on carte-wise · & cursoures þaim dre&yogh;e. Þire Olifantis of ynde · quen þai þare-on waite, Þai wend þai ware wees · & wyndis þaim agayn To drepe þaim as þaire first did · disclosid þai þe chaviles, And sone was snaypid on þe snowte · with þe snart hetis. With þat þai fonge to þe fli&yogh;t · be fifty at anes, Of ilkan athill ware þai a&yogh;ed · þat any armes werid. Sone as ser Porrus of þe poynte · & o þe plite waytis, Þan was he tangid with tene · & turbled vnfaire. Þan preses in þe Persyns · & of þe proud Medis With arowis & with othire armes · agayn all þe yndis, Tolls of þe tirantis · & termynd o lyue, Se&yogh;es doun on aithire side · a sowme out of nounbre, Thretti dais on a throm · þai threpid euire elike, So lange at þe lest way · as lastid þe bataill. Þare was þe Medis martird · & many of Perses Gorred & gais Read girt (struck)? cf. l. 3651. þur&yogh;e · & grysely woundid. Oure mody kyng of Messedone · þe myschefe be-haldis, Seis þaim faile so ethfully · & felly was greued. Apon þe bald bucifelon · brant vp he sittis, Springis out a spere · sperid all þe platis. Þe brest of þe bataill · he baldly a-prochid, Girdis doun of þe grettis · & þe gree wynnys. His awen men of Messedone · maynly þai fe&yogh;t, So did his gomes out [of] grece · & gate a grete name. Sone discendid þare doun · þe du&yogh;tiest of ynde, And Porrus prekis fra þe place · & þe playn voidis, His ledis at left ware o lyue · lendis him eftire. And Alexander in þat angle · all þe ni&yogh;t logis, Offirs all his old gods · his honour þam thankis, As wele þe ynde as his MS. he. awen · he graue þaim all.
text.15: Sextus Decimus [passus] Alexandri. Þe secund MS. sedū. day with a saute · a cite he takis, Þe proddest ane at Porrus · possessour was In the margin . euire. He past in-to his palais · & in þe place findis Þat semed no synfull saule · þe selcuthe to trowe. First fand he þare of fyne gold · a foure hundreth postis, With crafti coronals & clene · coruen of þe same. Be-twene þe pelers was pi&yogh;t · with precious leuys, Gilden wynes with grapis · of gracious stanes. Sum were of cristall clere · clustrid to-gedire; Sum made ware MS. wade w; but corrected . of Margarits · þe mast of þe werd; Sum was smeth smaragdyns · & oþire small gemmes, And new nychometis · nemellus endentid, Þat ware as semely · quen þai ware samen, And all pargestis of plate · as pure as þe noble. Þe Messedons in þam merkid · with þaire mekill brandis, And þe thinnest was a nynche thicke · quen þai ware þur&yogh;e persed; And þo ware strenkild with stanes · as sterne o þe heuyn, With charbokl[e]s on þe champ · & with chefe perles. Smeten was smaragdans · in-to þe smeth werkis, And athill amytists als · in aungels licknes; Of Euor & of Olifants · was ordand þe &yogh;atis, With barrers of ane Ebyn-tree · bonden with cheynes. Þe Ebyn, as þe buke sais · brin will neuir, And growis in þe Iles of ynde · as Isodry tellis. Þe solers was of Sypris · all of a soyte makid; And Symolacres in þe sale · was sett vp-on trones All of glittirand gold · as gomes it were, Discheualer with chaplets · of changand hewes; And ilka tulke a tabernacle · tildid was ouire, And þat was grauen all grayd · of gilden platis, Flamband all in filour · & fewlis en-blanchid, Mekely merkid & made · of all manere of kyndis; And þa ware proudly depaynt · þe pennes & þe wingis, Of all colours to a-counte · as þai ere cled here; Of fethirhame & all fare · as feetely enjoyned, As þai ware shapen o þe schell · to schew to oure e&yogh;en. Bet was all of brent gold · þe billis & þe chauyls, And, quen as Porrus con plese · in presens of lordis, Þai made as mery melody · & musik þai sanng As in þe moneths of Mai · or mydsomere euyn! Þare fand he vessale of value · to vyse out of nombre, Gurds & Goblets · of gold althire-finest, Coupis all of cristall · & oþire clere gemmes; Þai fande bot a fewe dele · forged of siluir. Þan rade he fra þa regions · & remewid his hostis; To þe &yogh;atis of Caspy he come · & sett doun his tentis, A lande, as þe buke tellis · a large & a noble, All sauand bot serpentis · & oþire sere bestis. To þe mode qwene of Amazoyne · þan makis him þis pistill. "I, þat þe kyng am of kyngs · & kiddist of lordis, Alexander, athil child · of Amon oure dri&yogh;tin, To Calistride þe conquirese · comfurth & ioye! Oure weris & oure wirschips · & of oure wale notis, How we MS. h we. haue done ser Dary · & drepid his kni&yogh;tis, Couerd all his kyngdoms · & conquirid his landis, I leue it to &yogh;our ladyschip · þis lange no&yogh;t vnknawen. With Porrus in þe playn fild · proued haue my strenthis, And oþire fele, þat ware to faynt · oure force to with|stand. For-þi &yogh;our landis, if &yogh;ow list · to leuire fra oure handis, Tas tite vn-to &yogh;our tresory · & trebute vs pays." Þan writis agayne þe wale quene · & on þis wyse spekis: "I, Calistride, þe conquirese · þat kepis all þis endis, With þe mery mai[d]ons MS. maīos. of Amazoyne · þe mi&yogh;tist in erthe, And othire birdis ebland · þe biggist in erthe, To þe modi kyng of Messedone · message of blisse. &YOGH;oure saule sa full of sapient · sedis & floures, Þat all þe present is apert · puttis þou in mynde, And has of cases þat ere to come · a knawlage in dole. For-þi oure soile or þou seke · vmse þe be tyme, Quat tene & torfare may tide · & tent to þine ende. Þare werraid neuir with vs na wee · þat wirschip achewid, Þat he ne was heried in hast · or had a he&yogh;e schame. For ilka lered man of lyue · him so lethir haldis, If he þat for distruccion doun · in-to þe depe fallis. Bot oure werkis & of oure wonynge-stede · if &yogh;e wald knawe, I sal declare &yogh;ow þe cas · clene by þire writtis. Oure inhabetting, ser, is in an Ilee · & amed as a sercle, With rynand all aboute oure erd · an endles wattre. And we ere of females at þe fewis · foure & xx ti Mille, I. e. thousand. And twa hundreth þar-to · & all of tried ladis. A preue planke is at a place · to pas & to entre, Oure bernes bildis no&yogh;t vs by · bot ouir þe bourne wyndis. Bot &yogh;et be-&yogh;onde ilka &yogh;ere · make we vs festis, And thretti dais all be-dene · oure delitis hauntis. If any consaue þar a knaf · þan kepis him his modire Vij &yogh;ere with-in oure-selfe · & sendis him his fadir. And be scho lyuir of a lasse · scho lengis in oure bur&yogh;e, And is oure thewis of oure thede · thryfandly enfourmed. Quen we to fe&yogh;t with oure faes · fares out of wanes, A hundreth thousand I hope we be · on horses enarmed, Þa leues in oure lede · oure lithis to defend. Quen we repaire with þe palme · þan prayses vs oure feris. And, buske &yogh;e to oure bondsward · vs bataill to &yogh;eld, &YOGH;et sall we maynly on þe marche · mete &yogh;ow in In the margin . armes. To lithe vs all if þou limpes · na louyng þou gettis, For þou wynnes no&yogh;t bot wemen · þare-of na worde rysis. Bot & god graunt vs þe gree · grete glorie haue we þan, For þe athelist emperoure we wan · euen at oure will. Be no&yogh;t to sturten with þi sturte · to stryue vs a-gayn, For many leres may þe limpe · slik as þou no&yogh;t wenes!" Quen he had lokid ouir þe lyne · he la&yogh;es at hire wordis, And to þat lady belyme Read belyue. · þis lettre he writis. ¶ "I, Alexander, þat am aire · of Amon him-selfe, To þe maistres out of Amazoyne · many-fald ioyes! Thre partys of þe proud werde · I playnly haue won, Affrike & Asye · and Europ þat othire. &YOGH;it was neuire man a-pon mold · oure mi&yogh;tis to with|stand, And fe&yogh;t with vs in In the margin. þe fild; · &yogh;ow fallis þe same. Bot be-cause we lufe &yogh;our comyng · we consall &yogh;ow blyth To pas out with &yogh;our paramours · & pere vs be-forne. On Amon oure athill sire · an athe I &yogh;ow make, Of vs to suffire na sare · to sauely to wende, Bathe oure gold &yogh;ow to gefe · & of oure gud kni&yogh;tis, To mary to &yogh;oure maidens · & make þam a vaunced." Sone as þai wist of his will · þai wi&yogh;tly him sente Ten vncorsayd coltis · þe clennest of þe werd, And as mony to amend · of milk-quyte stedis, Of mony & of mekill quat · mayn giftis. Dame Calistride þe conquiris · comes with hire ladis, Mas hire pes with oure prince · & pas to hire landis.
text.16: ¶ Decimus septimus passus Alexandri. Þen come a sande to þis sire · in þe same tyme, Þat kyng porrus þe proud · with pers out of ynde Was in þe bonds of Batriane · & eft MS. oft or ost. had assemblid Anoþire ost of odmen · him eft on to ride. As hastely as he it herd · his ostis he flittis, And athils harnest on hors · a hundreth & fyfti Was chosene MS. chosens. to chiftans · & all of chefe MS. chede, altered to chefe. dukes, Ordand of oure emperoure · his ostis to lede. Þus pas he furthe with his princes · ser Porrus to mete, In August eftir Iuli · as þe boke tellis. All ware þai swollen of þe swete · & sweltid on þe son; Sum in þaire harnais for hete · was honest for euire. Þai went be waldis & be wastis · þar watirs ware nane, And armed bud þam all bee · for angwischis o bestis, As colwers & for coltris · & crabbid snakis, And oþire warla&yogh;es wild · þat in þe wod duelled. As ai stremand sternes · stared all þaire wedis, Of gai glitirand gold · glesenyd þaire schildis. Þai dro&yogh;e furth be dissert · & drinkles þai spill, Was nouthire waldis in þar walke · ne watir to fynde. A kni&yogh;t þat zephall was callid · fand in a cole schade A litill drysnyng of dewe · was droppid fra þe heuen, Þat it was in a holo&yogh;e stane · & in his helme fillis, And bringis it to oure bald kyng · to brigge with his hetis. Þan Alexander to þis athill · all þus he spekis, "Þis solayne sope if I sup · quethire sustene it may Þe menbris of þe Messedones · & of þe many Persens, Or I my-selfe sall be serued · & þai sitt with nyfils?" "Sire, &yogh;e sall first be refreschid" · faythly he sayd. "Quat? & &yogh;e perisch?" quod þe prince · "& pas out o lyue? Queþir euir me list þan to lefe · with langour & sorowe?" And hilds it doun out of þe helme · befor his athils all. Þan slike a comfurth þam enclosed · for his kynd wordis, As all þe watir of þe werd · ware in þaire wambs hellid. Þan ferd þai furth till a fflode · & findis all þe strandis Full of Redis, as I rede · rughere þan thornes. His folke fell to it fast · & freschely þai drynke, Bot was na MS. r na. renke at to it ran · at euire rase eftire. It was so keruand & kene! · þan was his kni&yogh;tis stroubid Mare for þe bale of þaire bestis · & Put for than. brist of þaim-selfe. For with his florantis olifants · him folowed a thousand, Of sithid chariotis & soo · & sextene hundreth, With co&yogh;rres Sic . & with clene floure · camels and mules, And out of nounbre of nowte · at nedid to his ostis, Thre C Mille I.e. Three hundred thousand. in thede · of thra men of armes. Be now þai ware so ne&yogh;e tane · þat þai for nede supposid, Sum of his awen vryn · & sum on Iren lickid, Þat it was sorowe any segge · þe si&yogh;t to be-hald! Þan aires him on ser Alexander · with angwischis & payne, Ay folo&yogh;e furth by þe flumme · at I first tald, And at þe a&yogh;tand houre · I ame, of þe day, Þan comes þaim to a castell · was closid in þe borne. It was a mervalous mote · made all of redis, And foure forlange, I finde · þe flode was o brede. A fewe within þe forslet · of folke þare a-perid, Waiteand out at wyndows · to wondire on his ostis. Sire Alexander bad his men · aske þaim of ynde, And frayne quare þai find mi&yogh;t · any fresch watir; And þai þan hent in þaire hedis · & hidd þam belyue. And he felly with flane · flingis at þe wallis, &YOGH;it for na spell at he spirid · spek wald þai neuire. And þan comandis he his kni&yogh;t[is] · kenely to swymme, And þai all bare, saue þe breke · with brandis in hand, Þan thringis in on a throw · thretty & seuyn. Als fast as þai þe forthing-dole · had of þe flode past, Þan girds þare vp fra þe ground · & grymly þaim woundis Of Seeles & of see-Bules · a swyth grete nounbre, Dro&yogh;e þam doun in-to þe depe · & drouned þam for euire. Þan &yogh;ede he þine with his erles MS. el erles, but corrected . · & egirly him thristis; Lebards lendis þaim agaynes · leons & beres; Dragons & dromondaris · & of þir derfe Tigirs Fra morne to þe mirke ni&yogh;t · þaim maynly assailed. Þus ra&yogh;t he fra þis reuir · be many ru&yogh;e waies To it was meten to þe mere · to myd-ouir-vndorne. Þan come he streke on a staunke · þe store me tellis, Was neuir na hony in na hyue · vndire heuen swettir. A foure furelange or fyue · it was of full brede, Umby-thorned MS. Umby-thonred. with a thike wod · thre mile a-boute, Was all of þe Rede ryse · as I redd first; And þat he cuttis doun clene · & kindils in fyris. He gert tild vp his tentis · be þat terne syde, Þo&yogh;t þare a longe quile to lie · & lachen his esee. Þe mone ouir þe montayns · meryly it schynes Or he mi&yogh;t drinke any drope · & þen his dole ne&yogh;es. Þan comes þare-out creuesses · of manykins hewis, Scorpions þaim to scere · & scalid neddirs, And þai so large & so laith · & so lowd schrikis, Þat all þe soile of þa sidis · of þe sound ryngis. Dragons dryfes doun o dri&yogh;t · fra þe derfe hillis, With kene carefull crie · and crestis on þaire hedis, Grisely gapand & grim · with gilden brestis, And flawmes feruent as fyre · flo&yogh;e fra þaire e&yogh;en; Þai drewe toward oure douth · with dedly blastis. Sir Alexander & his ost · was ar&yogh;ed vnfaire, Was þare na freke in þe fild · þat faithly he leued To be deuowrid & devoidid · & vencuste for euire. Þe kyng þan comfurthid his kni&yogh;tis · all if he care þoled: "Mi bald baratours," he bad · "a-baste no&yogh;t &yogh;oure hertis; Seis ensampill at my-selfe · & seke &yogh;e na ferre, MS. ferrre. Bot hedis haly to my hand · & harmes þar-eftire." A brand & a bri&yogh;t schild · bremely he hentis, Fe&yogh;tis freschely & fast · with þa fell bestis, Dasches dragons doun · geuys þaim depe woundis, Slaes of þa serpentis · many sadd hundreth. Þan bildid of his bachelers · & braidis to þaire wapen; If þai ware mased & amayd · maynely þaim fe&yogh;t. &YOGH;it was þar twenti þat time · tangid to dede, And þat þe comliest kni&yogh;tis · at þe kyng ledis; Of athill archars als · as þe buke tellis, A-boute a thretty in þat thede · tharned þaire lyfes. Þus many deid of his douth · as þe boke MS. beke. tellis, And him limpis all þe loose · be þe lattire end. Now comes a company of Crabbe-fische · as calues gret, Meuand of þis marras · oure men to assaill, With backis, as þe buke sais · biggir & hardere Þan ony comon cogill-stane · or cocatryse scales. Quen kni&yogh;tis of oure conquirours · kest at þam lances, Was nane so wele-stelid poynt · at þam perse mi&yogh;te. Bot gomes with þaire greues in twa · in þe gledis spurned, And all at left ware o lyue · in-to þe MS. to, with in and þe in the margin . lo&yogh;e entirs. Be þai had fyneschid þis fi&yogh;t · was ferre in with euyn, Foure houres full farne · & þe fifte MS. fi&yogh;te, altered to fifte. neghes. And leons quyte as lylly · lent þam agayn, Of bodis biggire þan bules · berand vnfaire. Oure kni&yogh;tis at þe first come Ms. cl come. · clenly þaim slo&yogh;e, Alto bretind þaim on bent · & bro&yogh;t þaim on fli&yogh;t. Wild berys in In the margin . þe wast · fra þe wodd comes, With ilka tenefull tothe · as tyndis of MS. l of. harowis, A cubete lenth, sais þe clause · cald was þe lest. Þai seke out be sundres · sexti to-gedire, With wild men of þe wast · & women e-bland, With sex handis, & soo · sett out of kynd. Þai held in hettirly · & hurtis of his kni&yogh;tis; And þai with brandis & bowis · bremely þaim woundis, Slo&yogh;e of þa sauagyus · a sowme out of nombre, And many scopid into þe scoghe · without scath mare. Sire Alexander & his ost · angwisch enduris, Was waik, as na wondre was · & wery for-fo&yogh;ten. And þam he bedis at a braide · to beet vp þe stank, With-out his ost ouir all · horrible fires. Þan come a beste of a busche · with a blak heued, Mad & merkid as a Meere · þe mast of þe werd, Fere fersere þan an olifant · as we find written, Stayrand on to þe staunke Here follows to þe stank, struck out . · þe stour to asaill. Þis breme best bare · as MS. as as. þe buke tellis, Before forne in þe fronte · thre fell tyndis, Hedous horns & hoge · & hi&yogh;t in þaire tonge Adanttrocay with all men · as I am enfourmed. MS. in enfourmed. Before scho drank of þis dam · his douth sho assaild, And oure kyng with his carpe · his kni&yogh;tis he gladis. A&yogh;t & tuenti men of armes · onone scho delyuird, Bernes was di&yogh;t þe deth · with dintis enoghe. Þan mys out of þis marras · as any mayn foxes MS. faxes. Come furth, & fedd þaim in-fere · of þe ded corses. All at was bitten of þa best · was at a brunt dede, Bot &yogh;it þai noyed bot a nykid · to nane þat was ermed. Þan flo&yogh;e þar by þe firmament · of þa foule Backes, Als store & as stalword · as þire sedill dowis With mekill ma&yogh;ten teeth · as it of men ware; And at vn-armed vn in the margin . was · þai asperly wondid, Of sum þai nyppid fra þe nebb · þe nose be þe e&yogh;en, Of sum þai ete of þaire eris · euen by þe rotis, Sum þai luggid of þe lippis · þe lire fra þe chekis, Bot þar bitis, as þe buke sais · blemest na kni&yogh;tis. Þan come a fli&yogh;tir in of fowls · as fast as it dawid, To vise on as vowtres · as vermeon hewid, Þaire boukis & þar bathire fete · was of blak sable, And did bot plaid by þe pepill · & fed þaim on fyschis. Quen he had voidid þis vermyn · & vencust þat of ynde, Out of þis perlaous Sic; read peralous. place · he past with his ost In-to the boundis of Bactry · þar bildid he his tentis. Þare reches was of redde gold · & many riche gemes; And clene all þat contre · qwen þai his come wist, Þai mett him full manerly · & mekely resayued With presentes of pirre · & many proude giftes, And thretti dayis in þat thede · he tholes & abidis. A sertane folke was in þat soile · þat Serres ere callid, And all þe lyndis in þat land · with leves MS. levys, altered to leves. as wolle. And so þire Serres, at I said · þaim in þe Somere gedirs, And makis þaim wedis þar-of · to were for wintris blastis. Þire baratours bawers · ere bremly reioyed Of þe conquest of þire cocatrices · & of þa kene bestis; And now he caire[s] fra þat kithe · & comes in a stounde Quare Porrus with his powere · on a playn lengis. Sire Alexander & his ost · caires MS. a cayres. þaim a-gayne MS. a gyn gayne; corrected . With brade MS. brade brade; corrected . baners & bri&yogh;t · & bragging of troumpis. Apon þe bald bocifalon · before his men all He flingis out a forelange · his feris to assaile. Þe Persens putt þaim in pres · & þe proude grekis; Þe Medis & þe Messedons · maynely þai fe&yogh;t, Þai swey doun as swiftly · þa swart men of ynde, As euire did corne in a croft · be-fore a kene sithe. Quen sir Porrus sa&yogh;e his princes · in þe prese faile, Þan aires he out be-for his ost · on Alexander callis: "It comes," he said, "to na kyng · ne kidd emperoure To latt his pepill þus pas · & perisch in ydill; It fallis mare faire him þe fi&yogh;t · to fynesch him-selfe. Forþi lat stedill all oure stoure · & stedd þam esoundire, Þi semble o þe taa syde · & myne on þe tothire; Lat vs twa termyn þe taite · be-twene vs alane. If I be vencust in þe vaile · & voidid of my lyfe, Lat all my seggis & soile · be to þi-selfe &yogh;olden; And if þou failis in þe fild · & I þe floure wynn, Latt þan þine erlis & þine erd · myne empire obeyi." Thus porrus in his hi&yogh;e pride · to oure kyng spekis, For he was litill & laghe · him laythly dispices. For quen he wan to wax · þe writt me recordis, Thre cubettis fra þe croune doun · his cors had a lenghte. Þe person of ser Porrus · past him þat hi&yogh;t twyse, He feetis him forth in his force · & in his faire hi&yogh;te. Bot þe prowis & þe prouidens · & of þe pure thewis Þat lurkis with-in þis lede · full litill he kennes. Now is þe partise in pes · & þai þe place dele; Aithire kyng with his cause · encontres on othire. Sire Porrus with a proude swerd · him on þe pan strikis So snelle at he snatirs with · nere snaypid him for euire. Þan kastis vp a kene crie · þe kni&yogh;tis out of ynde, For he was dased of þe dint · & half dede him semyd. Porrus, as a prince suld · persayued þar latis, Turnes him toward his tulkis · & titely rehetis. Sire Alexander him avises · & his aande takis, As bald barratour & breme · his brand vp he liftis, With bathe his handis in-to þe brayne · his basenet he cleuys, And he fallis doun fey · & fynes in þat stound. Þe pepill of ser Porrus · quen þai [him] pas sa&yogh;e, With all manere of men · maynly þai fi&yogh;t. "A! wriches!" quod þe wale kyng · & wisely he spekis, "Eftir þe deth of &yogh;our duke · quat deynes &yogh;owe to stryue? Wete &yogh;e wele," quod þe wee · "be werrayours la&yogh;es, Þat quen þe gouernoure is gane · þan is þe gomes wastid." "Sire, it is better for to bate · & on þe bent faile, Þan se þis rewthe on &yogh;our Read our. renkis · & reft be &yogh;our Read our. gudis." "Sirs, blynes of &yogh;our bataile · & bowes to &yogh;oure landis; &YOGH;oure fermes & &yogh;oure fraunches · I frely &yogh;ow grant; For &yogh;e haue cockid for &yogh;our kyng · &yogh;e sall no care suffire!" And þan callid him on knese · & kest doun þaire armes. Þai come to þis conquirour · comend him as dri&yogh;tin, Þan sett he sales vp of In the margin. silke · & sacrifece makis. Sire Porrus, as him wele fell · he proudely enteris, And all þe fey in þe fild · & here a fitt ende.
text.17: Decimus octauus passus Alexandri. Þan aires he furth with his erlis · & entris an Ile, Quare þir Exidraces as Ermets · inhabet in caues, A progenie of pore men · þat neuir pride hauntis, And &yogh;it þe gentill genosophis · þam in þe gest callis. Is þare na bost þaim ebland · ne bataills vsyd, Nouthire cites in to sytt · cellis, nor na tounes, Bot crepis in-to creuesse · & craggis on hillis, And ay is naked [as] a nedill · as natour þam schapis. Þe kyng of þat contre · quen he þe come heres Of þis prince & his parray · þis pistill he him sendis. "We, corruptible creatours · & cald as be-fore, To þe mode man of Messedone · all þus-gate I write. Sire, it is sayd to oure-selfe · with sere mens tongis, How þou comes in-to oure kith-ward · to cumbre vs with care, And þat Vs wondres, I-wis · for wyn may &yogh;e nouthire Read neuir? Nouthire gold ne na gude · at euer gode fourmed. MS. fourmned. Sen at we Ioy nouthire gemmes · ne Iuwels in cofirs, Pelour, pirre, ne perle · ne na proude wedis, Ne sauand bot to sustene with · oure awen sary craftis, Quat in þis time may &yogh;e take · if &yogh;e oure termes entre? If &yogh;e will seke in-to oure soile · & sett vs agayne, Oure simpilnes & oure sobirte · forsake sall we neuire." Quen he had lokid ouire þe lefe · a lettre he in-dities, Þat he aproched all with pes · & in na plite ellis. Quen he was entrid þar erde · & sees þaim all nakid, And won as it ware wildirnes · in wastis & greues, Darke in dennes vndire dounes · & in derne holis, And bath þar bridis & þar barnes · with bestes on þe fellis, MS. fild fellis; corrected. Þan Alexander at þam askis · & all him a-wondres: "Haue &yogh;e na houses ne na hames · ne holis in to bery?" And þar þai schewid him in schurrys · to schellis & to caues, Said, "here we ilka day duell · deuyse how &yogh;ow likis." Quen he þaire simpilnes sees · he soro&yogh;es in his hert, Pleynes of þaire pouerte · & profurs þaim full faire, "Quat euire &yogh;e will in all þe werd · or I wend, askis, And I sall gladly &yogh;ow geue · with a gud will." "Sire, neuire to dee," quod þai þan · "bot euire dure o lyue, Þat we desire &yogh;ow bedene · & þan do vs na mare." "Be dri&yogh;tin, sirs, I am a duke · dedelike my-selfe, Forþi vnde[d]lynes to dele · I dowe be na ways." "Now sen it worthis," quod þa wees · "wriche, for to die, Quarto hi&yogh;is þou fra half to halfe · & all þis harme wirkis?" "Sire, be my croune," quod þe kyng · "þe cause at I haue Is purly gods prouidens · predestayned it is before. &YOGH;e se, wele seldom is þe see · with him-selfe turbild Bot with þir walowand windis; · my will ware to rifte, Bot a-noþir gast, & no&yogh;t my gast · þar-of my gast lettis;" And wendis a-way with þat word · & wemles þaim leuys. Þe secund day with vp son · he with his sowme ne&yogh;es, Quare þire Imagis ere þat Arculious · had in an Ile rerid. Þe tane was all athill gold · of siluir þe tothire, Twelfe cubettis fra þe topp doun · & twa was þe brede. He made his pepill þaim to perse · to proue þam with-in, Quethire þai ware hologhe or hale · & hale he þam fyndis, Sa&yogh;e þaim thike þur&yogh;e-out · & aithire thrill stoppis, And fillis þam florentis · a fyftene hundreth. Þan drafe he þine with his dukis · in a deyne entris, A wilsom wast & wild · & wondirly colde, As mirke as any mydni&yogh;t · quen þe mone failes, Þat vnnethes ken may a kni&yogh;t · to se to his fere. Fifty days be desert · he foundis with his folke, Till he come blesenand on a brym · was welland hate, And on þe ferre halfe of þe bourne · was wemen on hors, Þat frely faire ware of face · bot foule ware clethid. Sum beris all of brent gold · brandis in þaire handis, Sum bataill-axes & with bowes · all of bri&yogh;t siluir, For brase is nane with þa bonds · ne no bige Iren; Ne neuire na berne þam ebland · as þe buke tellis. Þan wald his MS. repeats his. pepill & his princes · haue past ouir þe bourne, And mi&yogh;t no&yogh;t for þe morsure · & maynyng of bestis, It was so borely & brade · & bred full of ydres, Of dragons & of othire deuyls · & doukand neddirs. Þan caires furth oure conquirour · with his kid ostis, Lede þam be þe left side · of þe lande of ynde, Sone was he dreuyn with his dukis · in-to a dryi meere, Was full of gladen & of gale · & of grete redis. Þan sny&yogh;es þar, out of MS. if, altered to of. þat snyth hill · as with a snayles pas, A burly best with a bake · as bedell as a sa&yogh;e, Kene tethe as a knyfe · a cowdrife breste, Of sembalaunce as a see-bule · & slo&yogh;e him twa kni&yogh;tis. Wald þar na brande in him bite · ne no bigge launce, Bot alto-maukid hire with maces · & mellis of Iren. A twenti dais ouire ten · with torfare þai ride; To þe formast forest of ynde · oure folke In the margin. all aprochid. Euyn at þe flode of Eumare · oure emperoure logis, And at þe xj houre · I ame, as it ware, Of Olifants out of þe ways · an endles nounbre Come with a carefull crie · oure kni&yogh;tis to assaill. A-pon þe bald Bucifalon · he bremely ascendis, Bedis of his swiers ga swyth · & swyne with þaim take. Þai ware a-baiste all belyue · as þe buke tellis, Þat durst na berne on þe bent · a-bide bot him-selfe. "Be no&yogh;t a-baist, my bachelars" · þe bald kyng sayd, "For with þe sweling of þe swyne · we sall þaim all voide." And so þai did al bedene · & sum oure douth slo&yogh;e, Tuke out þe tuskis & þe tethe · & ternen of þe skinnes. Þat oþer dai be desert · þam destaned to ride, Be þe wild ynde woddis · & wemen þai faund With bare hedes as a barne · & berdis to þe pappis, And had na hattir þam to hele · bot hidis of bestis. His seggis sesid of þam sum · & to him-selfe bro&yogh;t, And he þan askid þam of ynde · & at þam enquires, Quat was þaire viaunce in þa vales · "ser, venyson," þai said, "Slike as we haunt in þar holis · with hunting in tymes." Þen ferd þai furth all in fere · & to fild comys, Euyn to þe heued of Eumaure · as I first rekend. Þare fand þai bernys & bridis · & all bale-nakid, At was resild as a resch · & roghe as a MS. inserts abr, struck through . bere. &YOGH;it was þe custom of þar kinde · as þe clause tellis, Als wele to bide in þe bourne · as on þe brade lande. Onone as þai on Alexander · & on his ost waites, Þai flee as fast in-to flode · & to þe founce plangid. Þan ferd þai furthe be þe frithis · fiftene dais. And sa þai willid in-to a wod · was full [of] wild bestis, Rynoceros, as I rede · þe romance þam callis; And þai assembild on oure seggis · bot þai ware sone drepid. Þan sexti days with his seggis · he so&yogh;t be disert, Till he was won in-to a werd · all of wast fildis, Quare nouthire holtis was ne hilles · ne no hi&yogh;e [h]eggis, Bot all as planir & as playn · as a playn table. Euen at þe elleuynt houre · or euynsange tyme, Quen he had tild vp his tentis · turbils þe welken; Þe semblant sorowis of þe soile · & þe son wadis, Þe werd wannes at a wap · & þe wedire gloumes. Þan fell a fli&yogh;t & a fire · betwene þe foure wyndis, Aquiloun & Affrike · & ewrus þe thrid, Vulturnus þe violent · þat voidis doun þe leuys, Þe south & of all sydis · sadly þai mete, A breme blast MS. A breme a blast. on þe bent · as þe buke tellis, Þat all þaire tents it to-terid · & turned doun þe hallis; þar pauylyons of pirre · þaire payntid clathis It alto-schatird, & to-scailed · þam in sondire. Þan was kni&yogh;tis of þe case · kenely affraid, And ilka segge be him-selfe · said In the margin. vn-to othire, "Þe writhe of þe wale god · I wate, on vs li&yogh;tis, For oure founding ouire his forbod · so ferre to þe est." Þan comforthis þaim þe conquirour · & carpis on þis wyse, Bad, "baise &yogh;ow no&yogh;t, my baratours · ne batis no&yogh;t &yogh;our hertis, It is na greme of oure gode · ne grefe at vs fallis, Bot þe entring of þe equinox · it euire elike-dele kyndils." Sone as þe wedire wex wele · & þe wynde pesid, As, be þe bale neuir so breme · it blynnes at þe last, Þan ferd þai forth fra fild to fild · & freschly assemblis All at was sperpolid on þe spene · & spilt with þe blastis. ¶ Þan fandis he furth, as I fynd · fyue & twenti days, Come to a velans vale · þare was a vile cheele, Quare flaggis of þe fell snawe · fell fra þe heuen, Þat was a-brade, sais þe buke · as battis ere of woll. Þan bett he many bri&yogh;t fire · & lest it blin nold, And made his folk with þaire feete · as flores it to trede; Þe hete was þam a hoge helpe · & hettirly it voidis, And &yogh;it was perischist, or he past · a part of his kni&yogh;tis. Þan vmby-clappis þaim a cloude · & couirs all ouire, As any pynaund pik · þe planetis it hidis, And þat so thestir & so thik · a thre dais eftir, Þai sa&yogh;e na leme of þe lyft · ne li&yogh;t of þe son. Þan fell þar fra þe firmament · as it ware fell sparkis, Ropand doun o rede fire · þan any rayn thikire; Þaire cabons & þar couertours · it kindils on a lowe, And all þar pauillions of pall · it to poudire wastis. It tinds on tend lowe · trappour of stede, And many costious costis · consumes in-to askis, Bages & baners · it blemyschid & swellis, And quare it ne&yogh;es on þe nakid · it noyis for euire. Þan knelis doun oure conquirour · & callis on his dri&yogh;tins, Giffe þam siluir & so · & Above the line. sens at þaim castis. Vnneth his MS. Vnneth is his; with is underlined, and his above the line . prayer was past · quen purid all þe cloudis, And stint was all þe stikill stormes · in a stand-quile. Þen rade he in aray · remowis his ostis, To þe grete flode of Gangem · & graythid þar his tents. His bernes blischis ouir þe bourne · & on þe banke sa&yogh;e Quare thre wees in a wraa · welk þaim allane. Sire Alexander bad an athil · aske þem of ynde, Quase þai ware, quethin þai were · & of quat kind. And þai him swiftly swarid · with a swete steuyn, "We ere bald Bragmenys · þat neuir bale tho&yogh;t." Þan list þe lord on his lyfe · haue with þat ledis spoken, Mi&yogh;t he haue won ouir þe watir · for wounding of bestis, As see-bule & serpentis · & soukand locerhes, Bathe eddirs & ascres · & atterand wormes. Þire Cocatricesse in creuessis · þar kindiles þai brede, Scorpions many In the margin. score · scautand neddirs; And all-way bot in angwisch Read august. · as þe buk sais, And saue þe Iolite of Iuly · þai Iowke in þa strandis. July and August. Quen he In the margin. persayued be na poynt · at he pas mi&yogh;t, Þan was he sary in þat sithe · & sadly he pleyned, Callid to his carpentars · & of his kid wri&yogh;tis, Bad make him boun at a braide · a barge all of redis. Quen it was done at his diuyse · & dra&yogh;en ouer with hidis, Pared & parreld at his pay · pickid & taloghid, Þan bowes þarin a bachelere · to bragmeyn he wendis, To þe souereayn sire of þe soile · & sesid him þis pistill. ¶ "I, þat kyng am of kyngis · & crouned of lordis, Alexander þe aire · of Amone oure dri&yogh;tin, And of þe quene Olimpades · þat I am of sprongen, To þe, ser Dindyn, on þi dese · dities of Ioye. Sen we chapid out of childhede · & cheued to eldire, Þat we cuthe any-gates gesse · betwyx gud & ill, Syne was oure will ay with witt · to warisch oure saule, And kest out all vnclennes · & clene it deuoidid; For þe philisophour in his fourme · vs feetly declares, Þat sa&yogh;e with-outen sapience · it seldoum aproues. And it is wayued vs to wete · & warned now late, Þat all oure leuyng & oure la&yogh;es · &yogh;e wetirly dispice, And &yogh;our manars fra all othire mens · so mekill ere deffirrid, Þat nouthire in see ne in soile · seke &yogh;e na helpe. Bott deyned it &yogh;our doctryne · bedene vs to write, &YOGH;oure customes & &yogh;oure conscience · & of &yogh;our clene thewis, We mi&yogh;t sum connynge per cas · chach of &yogh;oure wordis, And &yogh;our lare of a leke · suld neuire þe les worth. Slike similitude of science · is sett, as of kynde, As of a blesand brand · or of a bri&yogh;t candill. For many li&yogh;tis of a li&yogh;t · is li&yogh;tid othire-quile, And &yogh;it þe li&yogh;t at þam li&yogh;tis · is li&yogh;tid as before." Quen he had waytid ouer þis writtis · his mynd he remembris, And be þe same sandisman · him send sike anothire. ¶ "I, ser Dindimus, a duke · þat neuire deere wro&yogh;t, Blith berne on my benke · þe Bragmeyns maistir, To þe modi kynge of Messedone · þis maundment I write. Sire Alexander, þe athill · at all þe werd loutis, Sire, þe tenour of þi titill · I trow, be na mare, Bot anly wisdom & witt · þou willis in þi saule. And bettir it is to þine a-bofe · þan buschels of siluir, And mare passand of prisse · þan all þi proude rewmes. Sen &yogh;e discrecion disire · we depely &yogh;ow pray; For a kyng with-outen cunnyng MS. cunmynge. · he can no&yogh;t distreyne His subiectis, & to be In the margin . subi[e]ctis · as subiectis a&yogh;e, Bot subiectis till his subiectis · his subiectis him makis. Þou prayes vs to þi In the margin . person · a pistill to MS. inserts pis, struck through . write Of all oure lefyng & oure la&yogh;es · & oure land techis; Quare-of þe proces to preue · vnpossible it were, And if we did it to dome · it dose &yogh;ow na gude. For þi tent is all on terrandry MS. terranrry, alt. to terrandry. · & tourment of armes, In bost & in bobans · in bataills & stryuys, A craft till oure condicions · at a-cordis bot litill; For simpilnes & surquitry · a-sewis no&yogh;t to-gedire. Bot leue &yogh;e no&yogh;t we be to he&yogh;e · ne hauten of will To steryn or to sturtyn · or sterid to enuy; A partie of oure propertes · & of oure pure thewis &YOGH;it sall I send &yogh;ow to say · sen &yogh;e me so&yogh;t haue.
text.18: ¶ Decimus Nonus passus Alexandri. Sire, we þe Bragmeyns blode · birdis & othire, A lowly lyfe in oure land · we lede, and a clene. All ydolatris in oure Ile · ere vttirly devoidid, & to na syn vndire son · a-sent we vs neuire. All þat ouire mesure is to mekill · emell we declyne, And nouthire couet we na corne · bot þat vs kind leues, Þat is þe filling MS. filning, corr. to filling. of fode · þat ilk flesch askis, And þar-to suffirand oure-selfe · & sobire as a mayden. Hald we no hors for na harow · ne na horned stottis, Ne nauthire sondire we þe soile · ne na sede sawis, Seke we neuire no sustinance · to saue with oure lyuys. Set we na saynes in þe see · ne sese we na fischis, Ne nouthire hunt we ne hauke · ne hent we na foules, Bot sike as growis on þe gronde · with-outen gomes werke. And þat we fede vs with in-fere · & fillis full oure tables, A dayntefull diete · þat damage vs neuire. Haue we no cures of courte · ne na cointe MS. comite; but indistinct . sewes, The former e in sewes is above the line . Swanes ne na swete thing · to swell oure wames. All superfluyte of soule · & surfet vs wlattis, To pegge vs as a peny hoge · þat praysis no&yogh;t oure la&yogh;es. Forþi failis vs all infirmit[e]s · of ffeuyre & of ells, Ne for na febill at we fele · na fysyke vs nedis. Vs mistris neuire na medcyne · for malidy on erthe, Bot ay as fresche & as fere · a[s] fisch quen he plays. Oure lord has lemett vs elike · þe lenthe of oure days, For þar leues na lede in oure lande · langire þan othire. If he be sexti &yogh;ere of sowme The me added above the line . · þat a segge lastis, His successoure has bot þe same · & þan þe saule &yogh;eldis. We chaufe vs at na Chymmneys · for chelis of wintir, Ne comes na clathis on oure corps · for na cald wyndis. We bede no&yogh;t to blemysch oure blode · with bodely dissires. Perseuerance of pacience · & pes we reserue; Oure inward enmys ilkane · we inwardly drepis, Þat is to say, all þe syn · at solp may þe saule, As surfet, surquidry, & slawth · þe seuyn all bedene; So þat oure werraours without · vs worthis no&yogh;t at drede. For wele sonere is a cite · sesid, or a castell, Þat segid is on bath sidis MS. sidid, alt. to sidis. · [than] þat segid MS. gegid, alt. to segid. is with-out. And þou wirkis bot on þa witerward · & worthis þaim ouire, And suffirs so within þi flesche · þe faes of þe saule. And we sitt all-way so sure · be sand & be wattir, Þat na supowell vndire son · seke we vs neuire, Ne schroude to scheld with oure schap · bot þe schire banes, And with þe braunches of þe bowis · þat beris vs oure fodis. Haue we na deliteable drinke · of diuerse wynes, Bot watir of a wale well · or of a wild bourne. And þat sullepe sire · at sett all þe werde, In him we lely MS. lyly lely; with lyly struck out . beleue · & in na la&yogh;e ellis. In all oure di&yogh;ans on daies · þat duke we comend, Wele wenand in anothire werd · to won ay o-lyue. And quat as pertenys to na profe · vs plese no&yogh;t at lesten, Ne mekills Read mekill. mellis no&yogh;t oure mouth · bot mesure oure wordis. Quen as we speke any spech · we speke ai þe treuth, And þan is still as a stane · & stirs it na ferryn. Riches ne no rede gold · rose we þam nouthire, Bot ay voide of enuy · & of vayne tho&yogh;tis. Is þar na berne vs eblande · biggir þan anothire, Of land ne of lor[d]schip · bot all elike simple. Þe pouert of oure persons · for plente we hald, Þe quilke MS. quikke; wrongly . is part vs, all þe pake · be parcells euyn. Is þar na brag in oure bondis · ne bering of armes, B[o]t ay perpetuall pes · pi&yogh;t in oure landis. Ne nouthire Iugement ne Iayll · ne Iustice of aire; For dose na douth þar no dere · to dome to be callid. Ne custome in oure contre · contraris oure la&yogh;es, Is þar na mercy ne methe · in oure marche vsyd; And I sall quethe þe forqui · & quat is þe cause: þar dose na modirson o-mys · na mercy to craue, For auyrice & errogaunce · & all we devoide, And to na licherous lustes · leeue ve Sic; for we. oure membris, A-vowtri ne na vayne glorie · ne na vice hauntis, Ne neuire to-pli&yogh;t worth a perle · to-ponyscht be-fore. Fynd we na faute in na freke · þat vs emange duellis, For ay on reson & on ri&yogh;t · rewelle we oure-selfe. Ne se&yogh;es na segge of oure sede · sodanly of lyue, For þe aire within oure habitacle · is ai vn-corumpid. Nouthire to toly ne to taunde · transmitte we na vebbis, To vermylion ne violett · ne variant littis. Oure paramours vs to plese · ne pride þaim beweues, Nouthire ffurrers, filetts, ne frengs · ne frettis of perle. Is þam na surcote of silke · ne serkis of raynes, Ne kirtils of camlyn · bot as þam kynd leues. Ne ne&yogh;e we neuire þaim on ni&yogh;t · to naite for na luste, Bot for to sustayne oure sede · & syn ay to voide. Make we na salues for na sares · ne na somir-bathis, Bot with þe wale dewe · & with þe warme son. Howe durst any be so bald · to blemysche for schame Þe hand-werke of þat hi&yogh;e gode · þat all oure happe haues? List vs na lordschips lache · of ledis as oure-selfe, For all oure libertes elike · ere lante vs & paysed; And to sett him in-to seruitute · a syn vs it thinke, Þat god has fourmed to be free · & to his face licknud. Or licknid; with misformed n. Make we na vessall of virre · ne of na clere siluir, Ne store staned strenthis · ne na stithe hames, Manere mynstre, ne mote · ne marbryn werkis, Bot duells here in disolatis · in dennes & in cauys; Ne nouthire housing we haue · ay quils we here duell, Bot at is fetid of flesch · & of na fraunche piers; Þat is þe carions kistis · þat couers þe saule, A full faynt forcelett · & of fen makid. We ere na sailers on þe see · to sell ne to byi; Ne rede we neuire na retorik · ne rial to speke; Bot certis in all simpilnes · sett we oure wordis, Þat latis neuire lesing · in oure lippis spring. Ne folo&yogh;e we na ficesyens · ne philisophour scolis, As sophistri & slik thing · to sott with þe pepill. It is bot wiles & wrenkis · at þai with dele, And all þare fete & þar fare · in Written above the line . falshede it endis. Lufe we no laike in oure lede · ne la&yogh;and mirthis, Bot quen vs pleses to play · we passe & we rede Of þe actis of oure auncestours · & of þar athill thewis; And quen we gamen suld & glade · we grete & we pleyn. And othire sertis wee see Written above the line. · þat solace oure hertis; First, þe faire firmament · fichid full of sterres, Þe rede son, quen he ryses · & rynnys in his sercle, Þat all þe land with his leme · lewis & cleres; Þe playne purperyn see · full of prode fischis, For tide ne for tempest · it touchis no&yogh;t oure kythis, Ne neuire sondres oure soile · bot sesis at þe brinkis.
text.19: ¶ Vicesimus passus Alexandri. Anothire mirthe is in May · þat vs maste ioyes, Þe faire floryscht filds · of floures & of herbys, Quare-of þe breth as of bawme · blawis in oure noose, Þat ilk sensitife saule · mast souorly delyte, As in þe woddis for to walke · vndire wale schawis, Quen all is lokin ouire with leuys · as it ware littill heuen. Þan haue we liking to lithe · þe late of þe foules, Þe swo&yogh;ing of þe swift wynde · & of þe swete wellis. Þe kind of þire customs · we kepe euire-mare, Þe quilk, I hope, ser, þe to hald · vnhalesom it ware. If þou will chalang þaim be chaunce · chese if þe likis, For here is written all þi will · & we na writh serue. As þe tenour of &yogh;our titill is · oure techis haue we schawid, Oure dedis & of oure disciplyne · a dele of þaim aythir; And of þi lare a litill-quat · likis me to write, MS. lere write; with lere struck out . For þe sothe of oure solitude · will serue þe stille aftir. Sire, &yogh;e haue la&yogh;t now on late · within a lite &yogh;eres All Europ & Asie · & Auffrik þe mare; Þat seising burde sufficiant · þofe so&yogh;t &yogh;e na ferre. Bot ay mekill wald haue mare · as many man spellis; Þe son, for sake of &yogh;our syn · sesys his li&yogh;t, Be-cause of &yogh;oure couatise · to clym to his bounds. And &yogh;e with wodnes of weris · all þe werde fretis, And &yogh;it for-fe&yogh;tils &yogh;oure face · all fasting it semes. A-nothire la&yogh;e is in &yogh;oure lande · at oure lord hatis, As, slaa &yogh;oure sonnes in sacrifice · & othire synnys many, To sawe emang þir simpill men · sedis of debate, And make a terant of a tulke · þat neuire tene tho&yogh;t. Þe soile ne þe foure sees · suffice &yogh;owe nouthire, Bot if &yogh;e mi&yogh;t ken þe costis · of þe clere heuen. &YOGH;oure giltis growis of &yogh;our gods · or god geue þam sorowe, For many modirson þai marre · mi&yogh;t ellis haue bene safe. A-vise &yogh;ow now be Venus · quat vertous him folo&yogh;es, Þe Iusule of Iupitir · & of his Iapis als, Dame Proserpyne, a prophetese · of &yogh;oure praysid la&yogh;es; Latis þis be witnes of In the margin. my wordis · & waitis now þar tetchis. Venus was a-vowtrere · & many vice hauntid, And Iupitir a Iettoure · þat Iapid many ladis MS. dadis ladis; with dadis struck out . ; Dame proserpine in preue place · playd as hire likid. Loo, sary sottis, slike a sowme · of synnars &yogh;e lufe! &YOGH;e lett men of þar libertes · at þam oure lord grauntid, Thryngis þam in-to thraldom · & of thaire þede spoiles. Vn-iust is &yogh;our Iugementis · so is &yogh;oure Iugis all; Þe dedis of &yogh;our domesmen · &yogh;e for dere halde. Is þare na renke in &yogh;oure rewme · þat othire rewill kepis, Bot "þus me þinke" & "so me þinke" · & threpis it is lawe! Þus fra þe rote of ri&yogh;twisnes · rauyst ere &yogh;e clene, And to þe way of wickidnes · be warla&yogh;es gidid. &YOGH;e hald na wee of þe werd · of witt worthe a myte, Bot he can practise & paynt · & polisch his wordis. For all &yogh;oure wisdom, I-wis · is In the margin. wroken to &yogh;our tongis, And all þe sauour of &yogh;oure sauls · is sattild in &yogh;our mouthis. &YOGH;oure grete garisons of gold · vngastly &yogh;e spende In bigging of burgis · & bilding of toures; And quen &yogh;e sitt in &yogh;oure sale · with syris & dukis, Þan haue &yogh;ee seggis &yogh;ow to serue · sowmes enogh. Þan as a Mare at a moghe · &yogh;oure mawis &yogh;e fill, With bakin mete & with briddis · bolnes &yogh;oure paunches, Stuffis so &yogh;our stomake · with stullis & of wynes, Þat vnethis haldis, be &yogh;e hoo · þe hide of &yogh;ow hale! Quat dewis &yogh;ow þan þire diatis · & all þis dere fode, &YOGH;oure sowping in vnseson · &yogh;oure surfete of drinkis, Bot settis &yogh;ow in-to sekenes · of sere-lepy kyndis, And gers &yogh;ow die or &yogh;oure day · many dre&yogh;e wyntir? Þan &yogh;e couett & craue · castels & rewmes, And thristis eftir all thingis · at in &yogh;oure tho&yogh;t rynnes, Iaspre, Iuwels, & gemmes · & Iettand perle: And all sall leue &yogh;ow at þe laste · & in-to laire worth! And maydese &yogh;it, for all your molle · þat modire ws Read &yogh;ow. cried, Þat fourmed þe flode & þe flynt · & þe faire lyndis. And, as I brefe it in þis bull · þe bragmeyns takens Surmontis all &yogh;our sapientis · & oure assemy thewis. MS. twethewis, alt. to thewis. And oþir werkis of wast · is wro&yogh;t in &yogh;oure landis, As, graffis garnyscht of gold · & gilten tombis, Thurghis to thrawyn in · quen &yogh;e þraa worthe, Sum of siluir, sum of sipirs · sum of sere gemmes. Þus make &yogh;e vessels in vayne · to &yogh;oure foule corses, To crom in &yogh;oure cariouns · þat kind &yogh;ow defendis, Þat ilk slymand slugh · quen &yogh;e ere slide hyne, And will no&yogh;t suffire þe erth · to haue at him fallis. For iolite of Iupitir · &yogh;e ioyen vp templis, With Imagis of &yogh;oure ydolatry · all within payntid; Symolacris vp sett · of Seropis & othir, And slees in-to þe sacrifis · many sere bestis. Quen &yogh;e haue tildid vp-on [top] · &yogh;our trouthles gods, Sum of gold, sum of glas · sum of gray marbill, Sum of latoun & of lede · & sum of li&yogh;t siluir, And sum ere tiffid all of tree · & sum of tyn pured, Þan fall &yogh;e flatt on þe fold · with fees þaim adoures, Bath Amon & Appolyne · & asskis at þam welthys; Of any gud at &yogh;e geet · a gift ye þam offirre, A quantite of all-quat · of quike & of ellis; &YOGH;e latt as þai mi&yogh;t all leth · at ony lede wald, And þai may send &yogh;ow bot vnsele · & no&yogh;t oþir godis. Þus &yogh;e comende þaim on knees · as cocards suld, Þat nouthire si&yogh;t has ne saule · bot of segge werke; &YOGH;e haue na sauour, I suppose · how þat þe kyng of heuen He has na hert vs to here · ne no hathill ellis For calues ne for kidis blode · ne for na crispe wethris, Bot an[1]y for oure orisons · & for na noþire giftis. God se&yogh;is oure sa&yogh;es for his son · at in him-selfe duellis; For sekire god is þe son · þat all oure sede loues. And sothly, by þe same son · we ere him all like, And all he sustayned of þat son · þat any saule wildis. Forþi vnhappy we &yogh;ow hald · þat in &yogh;oure hertis leues &YOGH;oure kind with slike a conquirour · to comen or to euen. And othire harlotry &yogh;e MS. inserts to hald, struck through . hant · þat heris þe goste, Of fornicacion & filth · & many foule synnes, Maumentry, & manslatir · mosardry & pride, Þat dose &yogh;ow dompe to þe devill · quen he Read &yogh;e. ere dede hethen. And we MS. &yogh;e, but underlined, and corrected to we in the margin . þe contrari clene · kepis all oure lyue, Þat we may bowe to þat blis · þat neuir sall haue ende. &YOGH;e gronde &yogh;ow no&yogh;t MS. repeats no&yogh;t; but the second no&yogh;t is underlined . on MS. ai (?) a god · þat all of glett fourmed, Þat note newid all of no&yogh;t · þat neuire sall haue ende, Bot oþire many do &yogh;e menske · ere him na MS. no, alt. to na. mare sibbe Þan was þe flesch of þe fysch MS. fesch, alt. to fysch. · to þe faire me[m]bree. Ilk lede þat li&yogh;t is of &yogh;our lede · &yogh;e call þe litill werde, And gesse wele as many gods · as growis in him membris; Ilk a parcele of his person a-proprid · is a-pert dri&yogh;tin, And euire-ilk lym, it awne lust eftir · as him list craues! For marcure was mansla&yogh;t · a mammlere of wordis, &YOGH;e graith him to be gouenoure · & god of þe tonge. And Arcules has aythire arme · in his awen warde, For þe xij wondirfull werkis · he wro&yogh;t with his handis. Mars for his maisterris · & for his many weris, Him brefe &yogh;e for his MS. &yogh;our his; with &yogh;our marked for erasure . baratris · þe breste to defend. Dame Iuno was a iettir · & ioyned full of iree, For-þi scho hedis to þe hert · & has it to &yogh;eme. Bary Read Bacy, i. e. Bacchus; see l. 4525. he was brayne-wode · for bebbing of wynes, Forþi [þe] swire & þe swalow · þat swiere he kepis. Cupido has þe custodi · & cure of þe mawe, For he In the margin . was couatus & cursid · vnclene of him-selfe. Serenon is sustenour · & sire of þe wambe, For hem was quartirs of qwete · vmqwile out of nombre. Dame venus þe a-v[er]ous MS. a vious. · for vices opon ni&yogh;tis, Is possessour & principale · of all þe preue menbris. Þus ilk cantell of &yogh;oure cors · &yogh;e call þam dri&yogh;tins, Deu[i]dis it in-to duesses · & oþire deuels many. Of ilk gobet of þat glett · &yogh;e a god make, And leues no&yogh;t as mekill as a lym · &yogh;our liches on to stand. &YOGH;e haue na hoping in þat hathill · at on hi&yogh;e sittis, How he &yogh;oure nase & &yogh;oure nebb · & all of no&yogh;t cried, Bot þinkis on þir othir thefis · & þam as thrall seruys, And sacrifice to ilk a segge · a sere-lepy gifte. To Mars in his mynstir · at maynteines þe weris, &YOGH;e bringe him a wild bare · for his wale dedis. Þe carcas of a fatt kid · þat carayne is worthe, Þat bring &yogh;e to ser bacus · to bere vp his drinke. And Iupitir þat Ioglour · sum Iape bos haue MS. hs haue, with hs struck out . ; A bullok or a fell bule · is bro&yogh;t to his temple. And Iuno þe Ientill · for ioy of his pride, &YOGH;e presand hire a pakoke · with pennes of an Aungell. Minerua MS. Minuera. was a maistres · of many kingis werkis, A ratland ni&yogh;t ravyn · is him to rent &yogh;olden. To Venus þe vowtriere · may no&yogh;t ells a-vaile, Bot ilk moneth to mede · & Read a. mi[l]ke-quite doufe. Appollo with a quite swan · is paid him to tende; A manere of In the margin . corne to mercure · þat we þi muld call. And Serenon is sone serued þat sees to þe paunche; Haue he a boll full of bran · bedis he na mare. And Ercules as emperoure · emyddis all he MS. y he; with y struck out . standis MS. stondis, alt. to standis. ; And for he preuyd ay þe prise · in prowis of armes, He has a hatt on his hede · hi&yogh;tild o floures, Of palme & of peruyk · & othire proud blossoms. Þe kirke of cupido · is clenly a-rayed, Þe stallis & in all stedis · strowid with Rose. Lo, to so many mayned gods · &yogh;our menbris &yogh;e dele, And will no&yogh;t knaw &yogh;our creatour · at &yogh;ow of clay fourmed. Þire deme &yogh;e for &yogh;our dri&yogh;tins · þat drepis þe saule; For þai may sende &yogh;ow na sele · bot sla &yogh;ow within. As many of þat feleschip · as &yogh;e trow & adoures, As many turmentis & tene · &yogh;ow tidis in hell. A-vise &yogh;ow now quat velany · & vices þai &yogh;ow teche: Ane leris &yogh;ow to be licherus · & leris &yogh;ow to syn; Ane, to be grindand gluttis · & glorand dronkin; And ane, to bragg & to bost · & bate with þe pepill. If &yogh;e be herd of &yogh;our happ happ marked for erasure . · vn-happe þai &yogh;ow ken; Forþi bot harlotry or harme · is at &yogh;e here craue; And if &yogh;e hede to &yogh;our hestis · &yogh;our hert is a-meued, So queþir þai here or els-quat · it hurtis ay þe saule. &YOGH;our doctours ere &yogh;oure duesses · þaire ditis alegis, How þat þai hampire in &yogh;our here · with many hard payn. Þai cause all vnkindnes · & corperall lustis, As surquitry & sacrilag · & othire sere tecches; Constrene &yogh;ow in-to cauatise · to clame all þe werd, To rayme & to robry · to rayme men þaire godis, Wailaway to wriches · & wa is &yogh;ow in erthe; Herefore &yogh;e hinge mon in hell · quen &yogh;e ere hethen passed!" Þan was þe kyng of his carpe · crabbid vnfaire, For he was spetous of speche · & spised his dri&yogh;tins; Quen he had lokid on þe lyne · he lappid it to-gedire, MS. to godire. And notid to him a-nothire new · þat now next fologhes.
text.20: Vicesimus primus passus Alexandri. "Þe kynge crouned of kyngis · o lordis all othire, Ser Alexander þe athelest · of Amons childire, And of þe quene Olimpades · þat I was of geten, To þe best of bragmeyns · blissing & hele MS. helee. ! Sire, be þis sothe at &yogh;e say · of all seggis oute &YOGH;e may be sett be &yogh;ow-selfe · for syn doo &yogh;e neuire! Bot sothely slike a simpilnes · as me my saule demys, It comes bot of acustoumes · & of na clene thewes. And owþir &yogh;e gesse at &yogh;e be gods · for &yogh;oure gud werkis, Or deynes with oure dri&yogh;tins · for MS. inserts we, underlined . þat we þam dere hald. &YOGH;e say &yogh;e sawe neuire soile · ne na citis biggis; How suld &yogh;e telle withouten toles · or any tild rere? Is þer non Instrumentis of Iren · in all þat Ile founden, Ne nakin metall of to make · messelyne ne othire. For-quy as bestis on þe bent · &yogh;e growe on þe greuys, Refete &yogh;ow with refuse · of rotis & of herbys; Þe same wyse dose a wolfe · þat wantis of his pray; Quen he has faute of his flesch · he fallis to þe soile! Lo, if me list in-to &yogh;oure land · with all my ledis entre, Quat wisdom at &yogh;our wricchidnes · or witt mi&yogh;t I lere? Þe lede is litill to loue · þat leuys ay in sorowe, Bot mekill mare he is menskid · þat in a mene duellis. Ware þai so wyse þat has waes · qua ware so MS. inserts wyse h, underlined . wide praysed As þa þat lepros ere & lame · þat neuire of leth knewe? If I &yogh;oure parties aproche · & pi&yogh;t vp my tentis, If I it mi&yogh;t, as I ne may · for missyng of schipis, Þare suld my folk for defaute · be famyscht for euire, And worthe in a wale quile · to wricchis as &yogh;our-selfe! &YOGH;e say &yogh;our women has na wedis · þe werd with to plese, Garlands ne no gay gere · to glyffe A curl over the g. in &yogh;our e&yogh;en, Silke of Sipris, ne say · ne saffrond kellis; For-quy þare is nane to gete · now neuyn I þe cause! Adultery on all wise als &yogh;e deuoyde, Echchewis MS. Ethchewis. ay þat caffare · as castite wald; If &yogh;e na will haue to þat werk · it wondres me littill; How suld &yogh;e nayte euir þat note · þat ne&yogh;es neuir þe fode? Slik lust is lang on þe leuir · & likand spices Mast cherischid & encheson · of chasteand metis; And &yogh;e In the margin . bot fede &yogh;ow with frute · at flays no&yogh;t &yogh;oure hongir, For-þi neuire ailes &yogh;ow þat apetite · þir artis with to dele. Is þar na lare in &yogh;oure land · labour of scolis, Fesike, ne no philosofy · ne no fourme ellis, Piromancie, ne poisei · ne practyse of lawe, Ne neuire na mercy &yogh;ow emell · as mynes me &yogh;our pistill; All þis condicions I call · bot comon of bestis, Þat has no sent in þaire saule · ne sauour in na gude. Bot we þat fourmed is & fast · & has a fre will Differris as in oure fraunches · fere fra &yogh;oure kynde. It ware no possible poynt · to paise in my witt, Þat all mi&yogh;t ay be eftir ane · with-outen any chaunge. For eftir baret or bale · blis vs aperis, And eftir wele comys wa · for so þe werd askis. Ouir Or On. wild is many ways wraiste · as þe wedire skiftis; For a clere cloudles day · mas a clene mynde; Quen it is In the margin . bri&yogh;t all a-bowte · it blithis oure hertis. And be þar gold in oure gate · or any gud stanes, We do bot foules it with oure fete · vs fayns it na more, And quen it walows · & wannes all oure thestres, &YOGH;et ere we toghid to & fra · be turnyng of eldris. For quilk a frek is bot a fant · þan is he first simple, And quen he preues fra þat prike · þan is he proud-lokid, Metis on þe medill merke · & þare his mynd stablis. Mekill variaunce of vertus · enveronis oure saules, For we ere fetid full faire · & has oure fyue wittis. Ane, oure si&yogh;t with to see · & sauour at þe nasee, And ane to tast & to touche · & þen oure twa eris. Of all þe frutis on þe fold · we fange at oure will, Bath venyson & volatile · & variand fisches. If &yogh;e refreyne &yogh;ow þar-fra · it falis bot of pride Or ellis &yogh;ow writhis with &yogh;our wele · for &yogh;e na welth haue! Be many opynion I prefe · þat pure is &yogh;oure tecches Mare fonden opon foly · þan ficchid on reson." Sone as þe kyng of þe kith · þe clause had devysid, He settis him doun full sobirly · & sendis him anothire. ¶ "I, sir Dyndyn þe derrest · at duells in þis Ile, Þe best of þe bragmeyns · of bounte & of thewis, To Alexander, þat aire · þat erles all þe werd, Þe souerayne sire of all þe soile · salus & ioye. Sire, we erd no&yogh;t in elementis · as euirmare to duell, Bot as qua pas a pilgrymage · fra Parysch to rome; To othire hames vs hi&yogh;e · quen we ere hethen voided, And in þe cites of syn · þan sitt we na langire. Vse we nane Epocrise · ne ire, ne no theftis, Ne nothire gesse we vs gods · ne grym at oure dri&yogh;tin. For many seerties we seet · þat sysed all þe werde, And wro&yogh;t þe will of ilk we · to wale as him likid. And he þat wayues ay þe werst · & wirkis þe bettir, Þat MS. þate, with e expuncted . gome is gods gud frend · & god neuire þe hildire. And þis similitude þat oure sede · þou settis [in] my pistill, Þe same ensampill, as me semes · in-to &yogh;oure-self touches, For so þe qwele of qwistounes · &yogh;oure qualite encreses, Þat noþir gesse &yogh;e gouernour · no god bot &yogh;our-selfe! &YOGH;e brixsill our MS. &yogh;our, altered to our . benignite · oure bonerte repreues, And beris a-pon vs blasfeme · þat neuire bale tho&yogh;t. All be we suggets in oure-selfe · & simpill oure latis, Voide & vacand of vices · as virgyns it ware, Neuir-þe-les of a la&yogh;e · hald we vs dri&yogh;tins. It is &yogh;oure-selfe & no&yogh;t oure-self · þat ai þe self hantis; Aboundance of Auoure · &yogh;ow all has englaymed, For &yogh;e bot fage ay þe flesche · & felsen it wele. &YOGH;e bide no besynes of bedis · bot to þe body clethe, Els &yogh;e may cast &yogh;ow to be coynt · &yogh;e count for na ferrir. With soft serkis of silke · &yogh;oure sidis vm-loke, Doubeletis of damaske · & sum of dere tars, With ilka fingire on &yogh;oure fist · fillid full of ryngis, Schard al of shire MS. schre, altered to schire. gold · as it a schryne were. Quat profetis &yogh;ow þis paraile · & all þis proud iettis? For nouthire saues it þe saule · ne &yogh;our-selfe fedis. Bot we, þat knawis wele & ken · þe kynd of þe noble, Quen we ere drinkeles & dry · we draw to þe bourne; And be þar gold in oure gate · or any gud stanes, We do bot foulis it with oure fete · vs faynes it na more. For nouthire purgis it oure pli&yogh;t · ne priues it oure hungir, Ne nouþir salues it oure sares · ne sesis it oure thrist. For folowid it slike a fraunchis · at it In the margin . vs fede wald, Þe cursed laike o couatis · ware clene MS. chene. with it drenchid. &YOGH;e vise &yogh;ow þar-of vessell · for vanyte & pride; As gud ware crestyns of clathe · þe caryon to serue. I se na godlaik in gold · bot grefe to þe saule, For þe fastir it fallis on a freke · þe fastir he couettis." Sire Alexander all at ese · avisis him on þis pistill, And wayues Or waynes. to him a-noþire writt · at on þis wyse spellis. ¶ "Hi&yogh;e kyng with-out comparison · of kyngis all oþire, Of all lordis þe lord · þat leues vndire heuen, Sire Alexander, þe aire · of Amon oure dri&yogh;tin, To þe, ser Dyndyn on þi dese · þis dities I write. In slike a side of þe soile · &yogh;our-selfe is in-closid, May wele na wee, if he wald · wyn to &yogh;our kithis. Forþi enhabete &yogh;e in angwysch · at &yogh;oure vnthankis; And all &yogh;oure lefing & &yogh;oure lare In the margin . · at &yogh;e so loude prayse, It comis bot of a kyndnes · & of na clene thewys. And als &yogh;e fonde may na forþire · to hi&yogh;en &yogh;oure name, Bot pyned þar in a parroke · inparkid as bestis, þus pere to þir presons · þat ay in payn lengis, And he þat se&yogh;is to vs sage · &yogh;e bot a sott call. Be þe MS. Be þe be þe; with Be altered to Bet, and the second be þe underlined; Bot be þe is probably intended . grace of my god In the margin . · mi&yogh;t I &yogh;our grond entre, I suld &yogh;ow ken to be kni&yogh;tis · & clethe &yogh;ow with armes." Þan pi&yogh;t oure prince in þat place · a pelare A curl over the e. of marble, Quare-on a tulke with a toile · þis titill vp he wrate, Sum langage on latine · & lettres of ynde, Sum was graithid o grew · þat þus to-gedire spekis: "I, Philip son þe fell kyng · þe fondere of grece, Sire Alexander þe athill · þ[a]t a&yogh;e all þe barbres Eftir þe day & þe dethe · of Dary & of Porrus, Þus fere I folo&yogh;ed haue my faes;" · & here a fitt end. [ End of Alexander and Dindimus.]
text.21: ¶ Vicesimus secundus passus Alexandri. Now gase he fra gangan · and all his ging eftir, Fondis forth with his folke · & a fild entris, Vmfaldin with a faire wod · florischt MS. florischst. out ouire Of Appils & almands · & all manere of frutis. All þe chiere of þe champe · was chargid with floures, Acrea, sais oure autour · þat angill is hatten. &YOGH;it wont men in þa woddis · as þe buke tellis, Of Ioynttours as Ieants · in Iopons of hidis, And þai ware fedd all of frute · & of na fode ellis, Of grapis & of gernets · & othire gude spices, Of sike as growis in þe grewis · I tald of before. Þai ware as rughe as a resche · þe bake & þe sidis; Quen þai persayued of oure prince · & slik a pake Armed, Þan stode þai glorand on his gome · with grisely mawis. And he mas heraud & heres · to hant for þe nanes, And sett vp a scharp schoute · at all þe schaw ryngis. And þai for skere of þe skrike · in-to þe schaw fledd, For þai hadd herd neuire of how · ne of mans noyse; And sex hundreth was slane · & sesid with oure kni&yogh;tis, And foure and threti, as I flode MS. flode, in the margin, substituted for fynd. · was in þe fild drepid, And iiij In the margin . score on þis side · & seuen at was armed Was with þe churles in þe chace · choppid to deth. þus thre daies in þat thede · thurgh-out þai lengid, And dietis þam with damysens · & oþir dere frute. Þan ferd he furth to a flumme · & sett þare his tentis, And newly eftir þe none · or nere þare-aboute, Þare coms a bonde of a brenke · & breed þaim vnfaire; A burly best & a bigg · was as In the margin . a man shapen, Vmquile he groned as a galt · with grysely latis, Vmquile he noys as a nowte · as a nox quen he lawes, &YOGH;armand & &yogh;erand · a &yogh;oten him semed; And was as bristils as a bare · all þe body ouire; Dom as a dore-nayle · & defe was he bathe, With laith leggis & lange · & twa laue Or lane. eres; A heuy hede & a hoge · as it a hors ware, And large was his odd lome · þe lenthe of a &yogh;erde. With þat comands oure kyng · his kni&yogh;tis him to In the margin. take, And þai a-saillid him sone · bot he na segge dredis, For nouthire fondis he to flee · ne na fens made, Bot stude & stared as a stott · & stirred he na forthire. Þan callis to him þe conquirour · a comly mayden, Bad hire be bro&yogh;t be-fore þe best · & bare to be nakid. And he be-held on þat hend · & hissis as a neddire, He wald haue strangild hire stre&yogh;t · ne had stiffe men bene; He wald haue schowid on þat schene · had no&yogh;t men halden, And to þe prince pauelion · prestly him lede. Quen he had ferlied his fill · on his foule schapp, He gers þaim bynde him at a braid · & brent him to poudire. Þen rade he fra þat reuir · & remowid his ost In-till a brade bent fild · & bildid vp his tentis. Þare fande he lindis on þat lande · þe MS. a þe, but corrected. lenthe of a spere, And þai ware frett full of frute · þe fairest of þe werde. It ware to tere any tong to tell · of þa trees kinde, For þai wald sett with þe son · & with þe son rise. Fra morewane to þe mydday · merely þai spring, And þan discende þai doun · as þe day passis. Lo, þis was a wondirfull werk · bot gods awen will, Þat þai suld wax soo & wane · within a wale time. For, fra it dro&yogh;e to þe derke · ay till it dawid eftir, It was bot vacant & voide · as vanite it were. Þe kyng in his caban · with his kni&yogh;tis he ligis, Tutand out of his tents · & þe trees waitis. A bad a berne of a bobb · bring him a nappill; Þan bowis furth a bachelere · his bedinge to fill; And he was sodanly sesid · & slane with a sprete. With þat enverrouns all þe vale · a voice fra þe heuen, Said, "qua so fangis o þis frute · bees fey in a stounde!" &YOGH;it bred þar briddis in þa braunches · at blith was & tame, And if a man had þaim hent · or with his hand touchid, Þan flo&yogh;e þar flawmes out of fire · before & be-hind, And quare it li&yogh;t on his like · it lichid him for euire. Now bowis furth þis baratour · & bidis na langire, Vp at a ma&yogh;te Written ma&yogh;tene; see l. 4883. mountane · he myns with his ost, And viij daies be-dene · þe dri&yogh;e was, & mare, Or he mi&yogh;t couire to þe copp · fra þe caue vndire. Quen he was comen to þe crest · his kni&yogh;tis wald haue esid; And namely a new note · neghis on hand, Of dragons & of dromondaris · & of diuerse neddirs, Of liones & of leopards · & othire laith bestis. Þare was hurling on hi&yogh;e · as it in hell ware, Quat of MS. ost. wrestling of wormes · & wonding of kni&yogh;tis. As gotis out of In the margin. guttars · in golanand wedres, So voidis doun þe vemon · be vermyns schaftis. At oþir time of MS. of of. oure tulkis · was tangid to dede, And slayn with þa serpents · a sowme out of noimbre. So hard þai hampird oure heere · & herid oure erles, Vnneth it chansid þaim þe cheke · þe cheffire to worthe. Quen he sckonfet & skerrid · all þa skathill fendis, Þen metis he doun of þe mounte · in-to a mirk vale, A drere MS. dre&yogh;e. dale & a depe · a dym & a thestir. Mi&yogh;[t] þare na saule vndire son · see to a-nothire; Þai ware vmbe-thonrid Or vmbe-thourid. in þat thede · with slike a thike cloude, Þat þai mi&yogh;t fele it with þaire fiste · as flabband webbis; With all þe bothom full of bournes · bri&yogh;t as þe siluire, And bery-bobis on þe braes · brethand as mirre. þus drafe þai furth in derknes · a ne&yogh;en daies euen, So lang þaim lackis at þe last · þe li&yogh;t of þe son. Þan come þai blesnand till a barme · of a brent lawe, MS. lawe, substituted for schawe. Ne&yogh;e throtild with þe thik aire · & thrange in þare andes. Þai labourde MS. babourde. vp a-gayn þe lift · an elleuen dais, & quen þai couert to þe crest · þen clerid þe welkyn; Þe schaftis of þe schire son · schirkind þe cloudis, And gods glorious gleme · glent þam e-maunge. Þan past þai doun fra þat pike · in-to a playn launde, Quare all þe gronde was of gols · & growen full of Impis, A cubete lenth, sais þe clause · cald was þe maste, Quare-of þe feloure & þe frute · as fygis it sawourd. Þare fand þai Revers, Written in the margin, as a substitute for þiuers. as I rede · ricchest of þe werd, Þof it ware Ioly Iurdan · or Iacobs well; Was neuir no mede ne no milke · so mild vndire heuen, Ne cliffe of cristall so clere · at euire god fourmed. A hundreth daies & a halfe · he held be þa playnes, Till he was comen till a cliffe · at to þe cloudis semed, Þat was so staire & so stepe · þe store me tellis, Mi&yogh;t þar no wee bot with wyngis · win to þe topp. &YOGH;it fand he clouen þur&yogh;e þe clynt · twa crasid MS. traside. gatis, Ane to þe noke of þe north · a-nothire to þe est. Sire Alexander him a-vises · & In the margin. all him a-wondres, And trowid it was wro&yogh;t · of na lede werkis. With þat stairis he forth þe stye · þat stre&yogh;t to þe est, And seuen dais with his men · he so&yogh;t be þa costis. And on þe a&yogh;tent day · eftire þe prime, A Basilisk in a browe · breis þaim vn-faire, A stra&yogh;till & a stithe worme · stinkand of elde, And is so bittir & so breme · & bicchid in him-selfe, Þat with þe stinke & þe strenth · he stroyes no&yogh;t allane, Bot quat he settis on his si&yogh;t · he slaes in a stonde. He vemons in þe vaward · valiant kni&yogh;tis, Maistirs out of Messedone · of Mede & of Persee; Þai se&yogh;e doun sodanly · slane of þaire blonkis, To step & to stand-dede · & in þe strete liggis. With þat areris all þe route · & radly þai said, "Þe writh of þe wale god In the margin. · vs of þe wai lettis." Þe kyng to knaw of þat case · vp to þe cliffe wendis, Sa&yogh;e quare þe same serpent · slepit in a roke. Þan mas he bonds in a braide · at sall na pepill pas, In bole & in balan · buskes he his fetes, A blason as a berne-dure · þat all þe body schildis, And fiches in a fyne glas · on þe fere side. Þe sc[h]rewe in þe schewere · his schadow be-haldis, And so þe sla&yogh;tir of his si&yogh;t · in-to him-selfe entris. Þan cals oure kyng him his kni&yogh;tis · & comandis him to bryn, And þai as sone as þai him sa&yogh;e · him for his sle&yogh;t thankis. Sone MS. Cone. as þis balefull best · was bro&yogh;t out o lyfe, Þan ridis furth oure riche kyng · & remowis his ost. And of þis way at he went · sone worthis him a nende, So at he flitt may na ferre · ne his folke MS. fokke. nouthire. Þare was so hedous & so hoge · hillis þam beforn, Clo&yogh;es at was cloude · he clynterand torres, Rochis & rogh stanes · rokkis vnfaire, Scutis to þe scharpe schew · sckerres a hundreth. Þan &yogh;aris he him &yogh;apely · & a-&yogh;ayne turnes, And past in-to þe proud playn · I proued to &yogh;ow first, Þat all was brett-full of bowis · & blossoms so swete, Þat bawme ne braunche o aloes · bettir was neuire. Fra þens oure note Here follows o, expuncted . men be northe · nymes þaim þe way, And þat þan Perhaps þaim. fonde all þe flote · fiftene dayis.
